text:
Sections

Indigenous Tradition
Hispanic Tradition
American and Contemporary Traditions

Philippine music has been performed in different spaces, to different audiences, at different times and occasions, and for various purposes.

 

Indigenous Tradition

 

Among indigenous cultural communities where music is an adjunct to everyday living, the venues for performances are as diverse as the occasions for which they are played. Within the confines of the home, the Ibaloy mother sings a tami to lull her child to sleep just as the Ata mother sings an a-di-ya-di for the same purpose. For relaxation, Tagakaolo maidens play the sluray (bamboo zither) while seated on the floor of the house, while the Bontok youth plays his kalleleng (nose flute) to serenade a loved one at her doorstep or merely to pass the time away in his abode.

 

On more solemn occasions, the home is the venue for a curing ritual such as the gasumbi of the Kalinga where the mandadawak (priest or priestess) dances and chants around the sick person to drive away the evil spirit. Preparations for the ritual, which include the butchering of a pig and the making of a tongatong (bamboo stamping tubes), take place in the yard beside the house.

An elaborate ceremony among the Subanon called pegayep is performed in the home of the balyan (shaman) to invoke the good spirits. Numerous paraphernalia consisting of a binalay (altar), a bahangsu (a seven-step ladder) containing food offerings, a miniature boat which the seven diwata (spirit deities) are supposed to ride to and from the ritual, a large gadyong (swing) hanging from the rafters on which the balyan dances, a low platform for the musicians who play on the gagung pon and gandingan (bossed gongs), and strike porcelain bowls are prepared. The balyan alternately chants and dances, and shakes dried rattan leaves on whose handle a pair of dumala (bells) is attached. The small hall is dimly lit by kerosene lamps which are extinguished when the balyan goes into a trance. The audience then, consisting of the village folk, sits on the floor, against the walls of the hut, and requests for cure or medicine from the spirits through the balyan. Questions are also answered. During the three-hour ceremony, incense is burned intermittently from a bowl containing dagtu (extracts from a tree), daga (chicken blood), pulinan (charcoal), balasi (shells), sulu (an orange-colored stone), and dlemuga (tree bark).

Rituals performed among other groups of people take place in open fields, beside a holy tree, or even by the riverbank. In the fields, music accompanies planting and harvesting activities. The Bontok sing the ayoweng while working in the field, and the Kalinga sing the sungiyaw to help reapers forget the heat of the sun. The Yakan of Basilan prepare the holes for seeds with a tabbak (pointed bamboo stick) whose other end is connected to a daluppal (split bamboo pole). When the pole strikes the ground, it creates varying rhythmic and melodic structures. Once the seeds are planted, the kwintangan kayu, which is made up of graduated wooden beams, is hung from a tree facing the field. It is played continuously as a means of giving life and strength to the palay seeds. Only after the seedlings have sprouted is the kwintangan kayu silenced.

Among the Palawan, the village meeting house is used as the venue for the tambilaw, a harvest thanksgiving. Great quantities of food are cooked. The community and relatives from neighboring villages gather together for the sharing of food, merrymaking, and wine drinking, accompanied by the music of basal (gongs).

Music is also part of ceremonies performed for the dead. The Ifugao play the bangibang (percussion yoke bar) during a himong ritual, a rite for deaths due to foul play. Many men participate as they dance in a long line, striking the bangibang and producing a rhythmic continuum of alternating light and heavy sounds. This is done in an open space. During wakes, the Alangan sing the ambuwaday. The Bontok extol the dead person with a fulayao, which relates the life and good deeds of the departed. The didiyaw is a special song sung for a dead child. It is both an expression grief and a prayer for a good life after death. The Kalinga sing the dassar before the burial of a murdered person asking for vengeance. Among the Mandaya, the family of the departed requests for the wake song called diaga. On a death anniversary, the Subanon sing the bahay-bahay.

Epic singing takes place during festivals or funerals or at events where more than the usual number of people are around. Some accounts speak of epic singing during voyages at sea where the cadence of the singing coincides with the motions of the rowing.

 

Hispanic Tradition

 

With the coming of the Spaniards, new venues for music making were added, notably the church, the church courtyard, the town plaza, the streets, and the big halls or the sala of the large homes of ilustrados (educated). Later on, music performances took place in public theaters.

The church was the scene of liturgical music sung and played during the mass and other church services. The friars took pains in teaching canto llano (Gregorian chant) and canto d’organo (polyphony). They also taught the playing of instruments—organ, violin, flute. Historical chronicles speak of organ playing during the mass and the proficiency of church singing comparable to that in Spain.

Eventually, nonliturgical songs were performed on the various feasts of the church calendar. Many of these are still done today. In May, songs are sung during the flores de Mayo as young girls offer flowers to the Virgin Mary in church. In southern Luzon, the “Alay kay Maria” (Hymn to Mary) begins with a procession of young men and women around town which ends in the church. Inside the church, hymns are sung in between prayers by the youths who offer flowers to the image of the Virgin Mary. Also in May are the processions along the town streets like the santacruzan, which celebrates the finding of the Holy Cross by Queen Helena, and the kristiyanong turog, pamukaw, and aurora.

During the Christmas season, carolers walk through the streets and stop to serenade households with Spanish villancicos and vernacular songs. These carols are called pastores in Bicol, daigon in the Visayas, or galikon in Pangasinan. The reenactment through song of the search for a lodging by Mary and Joseph in Bethlehem called panunuluyan, pananapatan, pananawagan, kagharong, or solomon takes place in the streets on Christmas eve. The singers playing the Virgin and Saint Joseph stop at designated houses, seeking shelter, but are rejected a few times. Eventually, the holy couple ends their search at the church, where the nativity scene is revealed on or near the altar at the “Gloria.”

The Lenten season calls for the singing of the pasyon, the versified story of Jesus Christ and his death on the cross. Done as part of a panata (vow), the pasyon may be sung on Ash Wednesday, on the Sundays of Lent, and on Holy Week, in homes, makeshift sheds built along streets, or barrio chapels. During Holy Week, processions feature the carro (floats) bearing images of saints and scenes from Christ’s passion, followed by brass bands playing slow marchas (marches). During Lent and especially on Holy Week, the passion play called sinakulo or tanggal is staged in town plazas or church patios in the Tagalog, Kapampangan, Bikol, and Ilonggo regions. In the play, actors’ lines are cantada (sung) or ablado (spoken), and characters march to lively paso doble or punebre played by the band. Easter is celebrated with the salubong, the reenactment of the meeting of Christ and his mother on the first Easter Sunday, which is performed in the church courtyard, with a young child dressed as an angel lifting the veil of the grieving Mary, and singing “Regina Coeli, Laetare” to the accompaniment of the brass band.

In November, the eve of All Saints’ Day and All Souls’ Day is the occasion for singing the pangangaluluwa songs from house to house. The revelers pretend to be souls of old unmarried men and women in purgatory.

Feasts of patron saints are preceded by nine-day church novenas that feature songs called gozos. Processions feature the town band as well as those from neighboring towns. Celebrations are a mixture of the religious and the profane. Besides the masses and processions, there are dining and dancing with the hermanas mayores (sponsors) splurging on the affair.

To celebrate town fiestas or family affairs or the visits of important dignitaries, the sala or living room of ilustrados become the scene for elegant balls where music and dancing last until the wee hours of the morning. Writers speak of the presence of pianos or harps in homes. Young ladies were taught to play these instruments, and it was customary for homeowners to ask their daughter to perform for visitors.

Travelogues written in the 19th century attest to the excellence of the military bands that played regularly at gathering places all over the islands. In smaller towns, performances took place in the town plaza. In Manila, the most famous venues for an evening of band music were the Plaza Mayor, the calzada (street), and later, Luneta—all in or around Intramuros. Performances at the Luneta took place nightly from six to eight. This major form of entertainment continues until today.

In the town plazas of the past, music was also heard in the komedya performances during fiestas. Travel writers made much mention of the calzada near the Manila Bay, that part of Luneta where military bands performed two evenings in a week. Formerly known as Bagumbayan, Luneta is known today as Rizal Park where the national hero Jose Rizal was executed. The Rizal Park Amphitheater has been the setting for the Concert at the Park held every Sunday since 1978. This program received the Hall of Fame Award from the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) in 1990 as the longest running performing arts series. Concert at the Park, managed by the National Parks Development Committee, also produces Paco Park Presents held at the Paco Cemetery in Manila, a weekly Friday evening concert program which started in Feb 1980.

Within the walled city of Intramuros, the Puerta Real Gardens was the venue for the Puerta Real Evenings which presented on and off-season productions of local and foreign performing arts groups, dance, music, and theater productions from 1979 until the 1990s. It garnered the CMMA for Best Cultural Program in 1983. This project was under the Intramuros Administration which to date also presents concerts at the Fort Santiago, including a cultural show held on Saturday and Sunday afternoons. The Maestranza Plaza was the setting of the Euro-Pinoy Jazz Concert held in Feb 2014. Other open-air venues include the Dulaang Raha Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Paco Park, and the Hinulugang Taktak Park in Antipolo.

In modern times, churches in different parts of the country have become alternate venues for performances and special celebrations. The San Agustin Church in Intramuros, the country’s oldest church and a UNESCO World Heritage site, mounted the San Agustin Music Festival from 1999 to 2009. The St. Joseph Parish Church in Las Piñas City has hosted the International Bamboo Organ Festival every February since 1976. This followed the inaugural concert on 5 May 1975 celebrating the return of the bamboo organ to the Las Piñas Church from the Johannes Klais Orgelbau factory in Bonn, Germany, where it went through two years of restoration work. The festival is organized by the Bamboo Organ Foundation Inc., through the combined efforts of parishioners, sponsors, and patrons, including the Diplomatic Corps. The Las Piñas Boys Choir, the organist Armando Salarza, and many local and international musical artists and groups have performed for the festival. Outside Manila, other churches have hosted musical events. In 2016, Kabataang Gitarista performed in front of the main altar of the church of Pila, Laguna.

Tertulias (soirees) used to take place in the homes of the gentry, the ilustrados, and Spanish government officials in the 1800s. Today, music performances are also often held in private homes to celebrate important milestones, as well as in residences of the Diplomatic Corps who introduce international visiting artists. In the late 19th century, Malacañan Palace and the Casino Español were also venues for occasional chamber music concerts.

The rise of the bourgeoisie in the middle of the 19th century gave rise to the cultural practice of attending musical events in public. The music concert, which initially was done hand in hand with, but which later supplanted, the literary-musical event called veladas, began to have regular performances only in the last quarter of 19th century and in the early 20th century. From the mid-19th century, the public primarily patronized musical theater, such as the opera and later on the sarsuwela and stage plays with incidental music.

As Western influence became more pronounced, the outdoor makeshift performance venues gradually gave way to a more formal setting. Public theaters were built, with the audience paying entrance fees. Performers now appeared onstage with the audience as spectators. The komedya, sarsuwela, opera, and concerts were presented in these theaters. Writing in 1909, Wenceslao Retana cited the existence of 13 theaters in Manila: Teatro Comico, established in 1790; Teatro Arroceros and Teatro de Tondo, both established in the early 1800s; Teatro de Binondo, also known as the Teatro Castellano, the first formal Spanish theater in Manila, which opened in 1846; and Teatro Lirico de Tondo, Teatro del Principe Alfonso, Teatro Circo de Bilibid, Teatro de Variedades, Coliseo Artistico, Teatro Filipino, Teatro Lirico de Quiapo, Teatro Calderon, and Teatro Zorrilla, all built after 1850. Other theaters built were Pandacan’s Opera Theater, Teatro Infantil de Dalumbayan, Teatro Infantil Tagala, Teatro Infantil Malateña, Teatro Tagalo de Aranque, Teatro Tagalo de Tanduay, Teatro Tagalo de Infantil de Barrio Aguila, and Teatro Infantil de Oroquieta. These theaters had the patronage of the bourgeoisie and ordinary citizens of Manila. During the American colonial period, theaters in the Visayas included the Teatro Oriente in Cebu, Teatro La Carlota in Iloilo, Teatro Talisay north of Bacolod, Teatro Kahirup in Silay, Negros Occidental, and the Bohol Opera House. In Pampanga, Teatro Sabina showcased the drama and sarsuwela of prominent Kapampangan playwrights like Crissot.

While these theaters were built primarily for stage plays, some were used for musical presentations, particularly the Spanish zarzuela. In 1862, a visiting French operetta company performed in Teatro del Principe Alfonso, which likewise showcased a symphonic concert in 1871 under the baton of Ignacio Morales. Circo Teatro de Bilibid featured the Assi-Panades Italian Opera Company in 1874. Concerts by visiting artists Remenyi, 1886, and Freidenthal, 1892, as well as local artists Jose Silos, 1900, and Jose Estella, 1901, were held at Teatro Filipino on Echague Street. Lucia di Lammermoor was staged at Teatro Lirico de Quiapo by the M. Maugard French Opera Company. However, it was at Teatro Zorrilla, established in 1893, where many memorable concerts and sarsuwela were held, including the first Filipino opera, Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), 1902, by composer Ladislao Bonus and librettist Pedro Paterno.

 

American and Contemporary Traditions

 

The biggest show house constructed after the Philippine revolution was the Manila Grand Opera House, described as the “National Theater” in 1902. It was the site of many important musical events—Rizal Day programs, grand concerts of foreign and Filipino artists, sarsuwela, and operatic presentations, notably the Philippine premier of Giuseppe Verdi’s Aida in 1933. Eventually, these shows gave way to the vaudeville and musicals which replaced the sarsuwela and concerts in popularity.

The Metropolitan Theater, inaugurated in 1931, presented the best foreign and local artists performing in operas, zarzuela, orchestral, choral and solo concerts, musicals, dance, and theater productions. Its opening was a welcome event, as the Manila Grand Opera House, inaugurated in 1902, and the Teatro Circo de Zorrilla, inaugurated in 1893, were both deteriorating. The Metropolitan Theater was severely damaged during World War II and was restored three decades after, opening with an inaugural concert held on 17 Dec 1978. Its two halls were the main Conchita Sunico Hall and the more intimate side hall, Dalubdulaan. The theater closed down in 1996 due to a dispute between the City of Manila and the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) regarding the ownership of the building. Its last concert on 18 Jun 2011 featured the local rock band Wolfgang in celebration of the 440th year of the City of Manila. In 2015, the National Commission on Culture and the Arts won the bid to restore the theater, though the building still remains unrestored.

Other concert halls and auditoriums in Metro Manila are attached to the institutions where music degrees are offered. In Manila, the St. Cecilia’s Hall, inaugurated in 1932, presents recitalists of the St. Scholastica’s College School of Music, the oldest music school in the country, existing since 1906. The Hall, destroyed during World War II, was rebuilt in the 1950s and renovated in the late 1990s. The Corazon Aquino Hall in the new building inaugurated in 2011 presents smaller recitals.

The Fleur-de-lis Auditorium is the concert venue of the St. Paul University College of Music. The Sister Catalina Ledesma Recital Hall and the Santo Cristo del Tesoro Auditorium present recitals of the Santa Isabel College Conservatory of Music. In Quezon City, the Abelardo Hall Auditorium of the College of Music of the University of the Philippines (UP) celebrated its 50th anniversary through a formal gala concert held on 24 Sep 2013. Adjacent to the College of Music is the University Theater, which houses a main concert hall and a small recital hall at the back named Dalisay Aldaba Hall. In the Visayas, the recital venues include the University of San Agustin Auditorium in Iloilo and the Luce Auditorium of Silliman University in Dumaguete. In Mindanao, the Rodelsa Theater at the Liceo de Cagayan University in Cagayan de Oro is where its College of Music majors hold recitals.

Auditoriums of education institutions in Metro Manila include the Far Eastern University (FEU) Auditorium, the University of the East Theater, the Teresa Yuchengco Auditorium of De La Salle University in Manila, the James B. Reuter Theater of the St. Paul University, and the Marian Auditorium of Miriam College in Quezon City. The performing arts groups of De La Salle Zobel in Alabang, Muntinlupa City, present at the Angelo King Center for the Arts. The Marie Eugenie Theater of the Assumption (META) of the Assumption College in Makati and the Assumpta Theater of Assumption in Antipolo, Rizal, feature their respective students enrolled in their theater and ballet programs.

In the regions, school auditoriums, function halls, gymnasiums, sports complexes, and convention centers serve as concert venues. In Luzon, these include the Ilocos Norte Convention Center, the Laoag City Hall Auditorium, and the Don Mariano Marcos State University Sports Complex Auditorium in Ilocos Norte; the Vigan Culture and Trade Center and the Vigan Convention Center in Ilocos Sur; the Baguio City Convention Center Hall, the Baguio CAP (College Assurance Plan) Building in Camp John Hay, the University of Baguio Gym, St. Louis University Center for Culture and the Arts (SLU-CCA), and the University of Cordilleras Multi-Purpose Function Hall in Baguio; the Dagupan Sports Complex and the Sison Auditorium in Pangasinan; Casa San Miguel, the venue of the Pundaquit Arts Festival, a community arts program since 1996 designed to develop the local fishing community, and of workshops of the Pundaquit Virtuosi, a children’s ensemble, in Zambales; the Angeles University Foundation Theater and the Bren Z. Guiao Convention Center in Pampanga; Diwa ng Tarlak Convention Center, Muñoz Gym, and Central Luzon State University Auditorium in Nueva Ecija; the Malolos Sports and Convention Center, the Barasoain Kalinangan Nicanor Abelardo Theater, and the Hiyas ng Bulakan Convention Center in Bulacan; the Batangas City Convention Center and the Manuela Q. Pastor Auditorium of St. Bridget College (SBC) in Batangas City; Baler Gym in Aurora; Quezon Convention Center and Alcala Sports Complex in Lucena, Quezon; and the Universidad de Santa Isabel Auditorium, the Nueva Caceres Gym, and the Albay Astrodome in Albay.

In the Visayas, the venues include Cebu Coliseum, Cebu Cultural Center, St. Theresa’s College Auditorium, the Rudolf Rahmann Cultural Center of the University of San Carlos, and the CENEWOF (Cebu Newspaper Workers Foundation) Theater of the Marcelo B. Fernan Cebu Press Center in Cebu; the San Agustin College Gymnasium and the University of St. La Salle (USLS) Coliseum in Bacolod; Sentro Kansilayan in Silay; West Visayas State University Cultural Center in Iloilo; People’s Center in Tacloban; and the Capiz Gymnasium in Capiz.

In Mindanao, there are Capitol University Gymnatorium and the Xavier University-Ateneo de Cagayan Little Theater in Cagayan de Oro; the Mindanao State University-Iligan Insitute of Technology (MSU-IIT) College of Arts and Social Sciences Auditorium and St. Michael College Auditorium in Iligan City; Kambayoka and the Mindanao State University Gymnasium in Marawi City; Bukidnon State University Gymnasium, Central Mindanao University Gymnasium, and Kisolon Gym in Bukidnon; CAP Theater and Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Convention Center in Davao City; and the Tagum City Trade and Cultural Center Pavilion in Tagum.

Today, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) is the premier venue for presenting all types of music performances. It was designed by the late National Artist for Architecture Leandro Locsin and inaugurated in 1969. CCP has three theaters: the Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo, formerly known as the Main Theater; Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, formerly Little Theater; and Tanghalang Huseng Batute, its experimental theater, formerly Bulwagang Gantimpala. Occasionally, CCP’s ASEAN Park and the front lawn are used for performances of brass bands, choirs, and instrumental ensembles. During its annual Pasinaya Open House Festival, a one-day multi-arts Festival initiated in 2005 and held usually in February, the Center also opens the Bulwagang Amado Hernandez, its conference room; Bulwagang Francisca Reyes Aquino, its rehearsal hall; the Main Theater ramp and lobby; the eskinita (alley) in between the CCP and the Production Design Center; and Pedro Bukaneg Street, fronting the Little Theater entrance. In celebration of the Pasinaya Festival’s 10th year on 15 Mar 2014, the CCP partnered with several museums in Manila in presenting performances: the Metropolitan Museum and Museo Pambata (Children’s Museum) along Roxas Boulevard, the National Museum located next to Rizal Park, Casa Manila, and Bahay Tsinoy or Museum of Chinese in Philippine Life in Intramuros. The Center also manages the Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas or Folk Arts Theater, and the Manila Film Center, both located at the CCP Complex. Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas, which seats 8,000, used to present large popular concerts. The Manila Film Center, with a large main hall called Tanghalang Gerardo de Leon and two small halls called Tanghalang Severino Reyes and Tanghalang Antonio J. Molina, has been leased, since 2001, to Amazing Philippine Theater Inc, producer of the Amazing Philippine Show, a variety show catering to Korean tourists and featuring transgender performers.

Aside from the formal halls, other areas in the CCP complex have been used for performances. In 1975, the CCP parking lot was the venue of Jose Maceda’s Udlot-Udlot (Fluctuation), a 40-minute piece for bamboo instruments and voices. This was participated in by 850 high school students from the University of the Philippines Integrated School (UPIS). Earlier, in 1971, the main lobby and stairway of the Main Theater was used for the performance of Maceda’s Cassettes 100, participated in by 100 cassette-bearing ambulant participants sounding pretaped music and freely mingling with the audience. In 1991, the loading dock at the side of the main theater stage was the venue of Ramon P. Santos’s Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden), 1991, a multimedia work combining music (two pianos, bamboo instruments, percussion), voice (soprano), poetry (recited by a reader), and dance (a male and female who perform on ropes attached to a ladder-like pyramid frame). Since 1987, the CCP Liwasang Darangen (behind the marquee) has been the site of the special CCP shows in December and in February.

Adjacent to the CCP is the Aliw Theater owned and managed by Star Parks Corporation, developers of the country’s all-weather theme park, Star City. It presents international and local concerts, ballet performances, and corporate events. The GSIS Theater near the Manila Film Center presents musical performances and theater productions. The GSIS Museum presents intimate recitals. Attached to the CCP is the Tanghalang Mariang Makiling of the National Arts Center in Mount Makiling, which presents in Los Baños the recitals of the Philippine High School for the Arts scholars who major in dance, music, and theater. Another landmark at the CCP Complex is the Philippine International Convention Center, a venue for political summits and concerts of local and international artists. Also designed by Locsin, it has five building modules: the Delegation Building, Secretariat Building, Plenary Hall, Reception Hall, and The Forum. All of these may be transformed into a number of settings for exhibitions, conventions, or special events.

The Philamlife Auditorium along United Nations Ave, inaugurated in 1961, was known for its excellent acoustics and art deco interiors. It was a venue for classical concerts of foreign and local musical artists, with the performance of Ukrainian pianist Sofya Gulyak with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) in Mar 2013 being its last. The building was sold to developer Shoe Mart Development Corporation (SMDC) in 2012. Responding to an online petition to preserve the theater, SMDC announced on 4 Apr 2013 that it would “save and preserve the culturally historic Philam Life theater.”

In Makati City, the Francisco Santiago Hall, now owned by Banco de Oro (BDO), has featured classical concerts since 1985. The Carlos P. Romulo Auditorium of the RCBC (Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation) Plaza accommodates Broadway-style musicals, ballet, opera, drama, and dance. Concerts are also held at the Ayala Museum’s ground floor lobby. In Quezon City, venues for music performances include the AFP Theater (Armed Forces of the Philippines Theater) in Camp Aguinaldo and the Dolphy Theater at the ABS-CBN Compound, home of ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra. In Pasig City, the Meralco Theater is a venue for classical concerts. In Muntinglupa City, the Insular Life Theater built mainly for corporate events has been used since 2008 for classical season concerts produced by Filfest (Friends of the Insular Life Festival) Foundation.

The Newport Performing Arts Center in Resorts World Manila in Pasay City is one of the newest performing arts venues in the country. Formally inaugurated in 2010, it presents concerts of international rock bands and solo vocal artists, plays, and musicals. The Center boasts of the widest stage among existing Philippine theaters and the biggest LED screen in Asia, providing dynamic video backdrops for productions. It is also equipped with two Euro-LED screens with 3-D effects, a complex fly system, and a revolving stage.

Lobbies and ballrooms of hotels also serve as performance venues. In Metro Manila these hotels include the Shangri-la and Mandarin Oriental Manila, the Manila Hotel, and the Sofitel Philippine Plaza. The Manila Peninsula holds its annual Concert at the Pen featuring the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and choral ensembles in a Christmas concert. The Grand Ballroom of Solaire Resorts and Casino, inaugurated in 2013, features international popular performing groups. These artists are likewise presented in the Grand Ballrooms of hotel chains in other parts of the country such as the Marco Polo and the Waterfront Hotels in Cebu.

Even shopping centers today are venues for performances, particularly for popular music. In Metro Manila, these include the Music Museum and the Teatrino at the Greenhills Shopping Center in San Juan, as well as open spaces at the Shangri-la Plaza and the Megaworld Lifestyle Malls. The Ayala, Robinson’s, and SM Malls in Metro Manila and the regions have their respective large spaces for music performances. Concerts of foreign and local popular singing icons also take place at the SM Malls’ SMX Convention Centers in different parts of the country, the Mall of Asia Arena in Pasay City, and the Araneta Coliseum in Quezon City.

At the foothills of Mount Malasimbo in Puerto Galera, Oriental Mindoro, the Malasimbo Music and Arts Festival takes place in a prominent grass-terraced amphitheater. Produced by a group of individuals passionate about music, arts, culture, and heritage, this unique international Festival has, since its debut in 2011, attracted thousands of tourists. It is now recognized as a notable eco-cultural program.

With the continuous advancement of technology, music making has nowhere to go but forward. Soon, more performances of different music genres will take place with the construction of more state-of-the-art theaters and auditoriums in the country. These halls serve as the venue for formal concerts featuring serious as well as popular music, which are usually held in the evenings and last for about two to three hours. Audiences in these venues usually pay for tickets to watch musicians perform on a proscenium stage. Performances may be held by professional or nonprofessional musicians all-year round or on special occasions. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Melissa Corazon V. Mantaring

article.value: Sections

Indigenous Tradition
Hispanic Tradition
American and Contemporary Traditions
Philippine music has been performed in different spaces, to different audiences, at different times and occasions, and for various purposes.
Indigenous Tradition

Among indigenous cultural communities where music is an adjunct to everyday living, the venues for performances are as diverse as the occasions for which they are played. Within the confines of the home, the Ibaloy mother sings a tami to lull her child to sleep just as the Ata mother sings an a-di-ya-di for the same purpose. For relaxation, Tagakaolo maidens play the sluray (bamboo zither) while seated on the floor of the house, while the Bontok youth plays his kalleleng (nose flute) to serenade a loved one at her doorstep or merely to pass the time away in his abode.

article.value: On more solemn occasions, the home is the venue for a curing ritual such as the gasumbi of the Kalinga where the mandadawak (priest or priestess) dances and chants around the sick person to drive away the evil spirit. Preparations for the ritual, which include the butchering of a pig and the making of a tongatong (bamboo stamping tubes), take place in the yard beside the house.

An elaborate ceremony among the Subanon called pegayep is performed in the home of the balyan (shaman) to invoke the good spirits. Numerous paraphernalia consisting of a binalay (altar), a bahangsu (a seven-step ladder) containing food offerings, a miniature boat which the seven diwata (spirit deities) are supposed to ride to and from the ritual, a large gadyong (swing) hanging from the rafters on which the balyan dances, a low platform for the musicians who play on the gagung pon and gandingan (bossed gongs), and strike porcelain bowls are prepared. The balyan alternately chants and dances, and shakes dried rattan leaves on whose handle a pair of dumala (bells) is attached. The small hall is dimly lit by kerosene lamps which are extinguished when the balyan goes into a trance. The audience then, consisting of the village folk, sits on the floor, against the walls of the hut, and requests for cure or medicine from the spirits through the balyan. Questions are also answered. During the three-hour ceremony, incense is burned intermittently from a bowl containing dagtu (extracts from a tree), daga (chicken blood), pulinan (charcoal), balasi (shells), sulu (an orange-colored stone), and dlemuga (tree bark).

Rituals performed among other groups of people take place in open fields, beside a holy tree, or even by the riverbank. In the fields, music accompanies planting and harvesting activities. The Bontok sing the ayoweng while working in the field, and the Kalinga sing the sungiyaw to help reapers forget the heat of the sun. The Yakan of Basilan prepare the holes for seeds with a tabbak (pointed bamboo stick) whose other end is connected to a daluppal (split bamboo pole). When the pole strikes the ground, it creates varying rhythmic and melodic structures. Once the seeds are planted, the kwintangan kayu, which is made up of graduated wooden beams, is hung from a tree facing the field. It is played continuously as a means of giving life and strength to the palay seeds. Only after the seedlings have sprouted is the kwintangan kayu silenced.

Among the Palawan, the village meeting house is used as the venue for the tambilaw, a harvest thanksgiving. Great quantities of food are cooked. The community and relatives from neighboring villages gather together for the sharing of food, merrymaking, and wine drinking, accompanied by the music of basal (gongs).

Music is also part of ceremonies performed for the dead. The Ifugao play the bangibang (percussion yoke bar) during a himong ritual, a rite for deaths due to foul play. Many men participate as they dance in a long line, striking the bangibang and producing a rhythmic continuum of alternating light and heavy sounds. This is done in an open space. During wakes, the Alangan sing the ambuwaday. The Bontok extol the dead person with a fulayao, which relates the life and good deeds of the departed. The didiyaw is a special song sung for a dead child. It is both an expression grief and a prayer for a good life after death. The Kalinga sing the dassar before the burial of a murdered person asking for vengeance. Among the Mandaya, the family of the departed requests for the wake song called diaga. On a death anniversary, the Subanon sing the bahay-bahay.

Epic singing takes place during festivals or funerals or at events where more than the usual number of people are around. Some accounts speak of epic singing during voyages at sea where the cadence of the singing coincides with the motions of the rowing.
Hispanic Tradition

With the coming of the Spaniards, new venues for music making were added, notably the church, the church courtyard, the town plaza, the streets, and the big halls or the sala of the large homes of ilustrados (educated). Later on, music performances took place in public theaters.

The church was the scene of liturgical music sung and played during the mass and other church services. The friars took pains in teaching canto llano (Gregorian chant) and canto d’organo (polyphony). They also taught the playing of instruments—organ, violin, flute. Historical chronicles speak of organ playing during the mass and the proficiency of church singing comparable to that in Spain.

Eventually, nonliturgical songs were performed on the various feasts of the church calendar. Many of these are still done today. In May, songs are sung during the flores de Mayo as young girls offer flowers to the Virgin Mary in church. In southern Luzon, the “Alay kay Maria” (Hymn to Mary) begins with a procession of young men and women around town which ends in the church. Inside the church, hymns are sung in between prayers by the youths who offer flowers to the image of the Virgin Mary. Also in May are the processions along the town streets like the santacruzan, which celebrates the finding of the Holy Cross by Queen Helena, and the kristiyanong turog, pamukaw, and aurora.

During the Christmas season, carolers walk through the streets and stop to serenade households with Spanish villancicos and vernacular songs. These carols are called pastores in Bicol, daigon in the Visayas, or galikon in Pangasinan. The reenactment through song of the search for a lodging by Mary and Joseph in Bethlehem called panunuluyan, pananapatan, pananawagan, kagharong, or solomon takes place in the streets on Christmas eve. The singers playing the Virgin and Saint Joseph stop at designated houses, seeking shelter, but are rejected a few times. Eventually, the holy couple ends their search at the church, where the nativity scene is revealed on or near the altar at the “Gloria.”

The Lenten season calls for the singing of the pasyon, the versified story of Jesus Christ and his death on the cross. Done as part of a panata (vow), the pasyon may be sung on Ash Wednesday, on the Sundays of Lent, and on Holy Week, in homes, makeshift sheds built along streets, or barrio chapels. During Holy Week, processions feature the carro (floats) bearing images of saints and scenes from Christ’s passion, followed by brass bands playing slow marchas (marches). During Lent and especially on Holy Week, the passion play called sinakulo or tanggal is staged in town plazas or church patios in the Tagalog, Kapampangan, Bikol, and Ilonggo regions. In the play, actors’ lines are cantada (sung) or ablado (spoken), and characters march to lively paso doble or punebre played by the band. Easter is celebrated with the salubong, the reenactment of the meeting of Christ and his mother on the first Easter Sunday, which is performed in the church courtyard, with a young child dressed as an angel lifting the veil of the grieving Mary, and singing “Regina Coeli, Laetare” to the accompaniment of the brass band.

In November, the eve of All Saints’ Day and All Souls’ Day is the occasion for singing the pangangaluluwa songs from house to house. The revelers pretend to be souls of old unmarried men and women in purgatory.

Feasts of patron saints are preceded by nine-day church novenas that feature songs called gozos. Processions feature the town band as well as those from neighboring towns. Celebrations are a mixture of the religious and the profane. Besides the masses and processions, there are dining and dancing with the hermanas mayores (sponsors) splurging on the affair.

To celebrate town fiestas or family affairs or the visits of important dignitaries, the sala or living room of ilustrados become the scene for elegant balls where music and dancing last until the wee hours of the morning. Writers speak of the presence of pianos or harps in homes. Young ladies were taught to play these instruments, and it was customary for homeowners to ask their daughter to perform for visitors.

Travelogues written in the 19th century attest to the excellence of the military bands that played regularly at gathering places all over the islands. In smaller towns, performances took place in the town plaza. In Manila, the most famous venues for an evening of band music were the Plaza Mayor, the calzada (street), and later, Luneta—all in or around Intramuros. Performances at the Luneta took place nightly from six to eight. This major form of entertainment continues until today.

In the town plazas of the past, music was also heard in the komedya performances during fiestas. Travel writers made much mention of the calzada near the Manila Bay, that part of Luneta where military bands performed two evenings in a week. Formerly known as Bagumbayan, Luneta is known today as Rizal Park where the national hero Jose Rizal was executed. The Rizal Park Amphitheater has been the setting for the Concert at the Park held every Sunday since 1978. This program received the Hall of Fame Award from the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) in 1990 as the longest running performing arts series. Concert at the Park, managed by the National Parks Development Committee, also produces Paco Park Presents held at the Paco Cemetery in Manila, a weekly Friday evening concert program which started in Feb 1980.

Within the walled city of Intramuros, the Puerta Real Gardens was the venue for the Puerta Real Evenings which presented on and off-season productions of local and foreign performing arts groups, dance, music, and theater productions from 1979 until the 1990s. It garnered the CMMA for Best Cultural Program in 1983. This project was under the Intramuros Administration which to date also presents concerts at the Fort Santiago, including a cultural show held on Saturday and Sunday afternoons. The Maestranza Plaza was the setting of the Euro-Pinoy Jazz Concert held in Feb 2014. Other open-air venues include the Dulaang Raha Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Paco Park, and the Hinulugang Taktak Park in Antipolo.

In modern times, churches in different parts of the country have become alternate venues for performances and special celebrations. The San Agustin Church in Intramuros, the country’s oldest church and a UNESCO World Heritage site, mounted the San Agustin Music Festival from 1999 to 2009. The St. Joseph Parish Church in Las Piñas City has hosted the International Bamboo Organ Festival every February since 1976. This followed the inaugural concert on 5 May 1975 celebrating the return of the bamboo organ to the Las Piñas Church from the Johannes Klais Orgelbau factory in Bonn, Germany, where it went through two years of restoration work. The festival is organized by the Bamboo Organ Foundation Inc., through the combined efforts of parishioners, sponsors, and patrons, including the Diplomatic Corps. The Las Piñas Boys Choir, the organist Armando Salarza, and many local and international musical artists and groups have performed for the festival. Outside Manila, other churches have hosted musical events. In 2016, Kabataang Gitarista performed in front of the main altar of the church of Pila, Laguna.

Tertulias (soirees) used to take place in the homes of the gentry, the ilustrados, and Spanish government officials in the 1800s. Today, music performances are also often held in private homes to celebrate important milestones, as well as in residences of the Diplomatic Corps who introduce international visiting artists. In the late 19th century, Malacañan Palace and the Casino Español were also venues for occasional chamber music concerts.

The rise of the bourgeoisie in the middle of the 19th century gave rise to the cultural practice of attending musical events in public. The music concert, which initially was done hand in hand with, but which later supplanted, the literary-musical event called veladas, began to have regular performances only in the last quarter of 19th century and in the early 20th century. From the mid-19th century, the public primarily patronized musical theater, such as the opera and later on the sarsuwela and stage plays with incidental music.

As Western influence became more pronounced, the outdoor makeshift performance venues gradually gave way to a more formal setting. Public theaters were built, with the audience paying entrance fees. Performers now appeared onstage with the audience as spectators. The komedya, sarsuwela, opera, and concerts were presented in these theaters. Writing in 1909, Wenceslao Retana cited the existence of 13 theaters in Manila: Teatro Comico, established in 1790; Teatro Arroceros and Teatro de Tondo, both established in the early 1800s; Teatro de Binondo, also known as the Teatro Castellano, the first formal Spanish theater in Manila, which opened in 1846; and Teatro Lirico de Tondo, Teatro del Principe Alfonso, Teatro Circo de Bilibid, Teatro de Variedades, Coliseo Artistico, Teatro Filipino, Teatro Lirico de Quiapo, Teatro Calderon, and Teatro Zorrilla, all built after 1850. Other theaters built were Pandacan’s Opera Theater, Teatro Infantil de Dalumbayan, Teatro Infantil Tagala, Teatro Infantil Malateña, Teatro Tagalo de Aranque, Teatro Tagalo de Tanduay, Teatro Tagalo de Infantil de Barrio Aguila, and Teatro Infantil de Oroquieta. These theaters had the patronage of the bourgeoisie and ordinary citizens of Manila. During the American colonial period, theaters in the Visayas included the Teatro Oriente in Cebu, Teatro La Carlota in Iloilo, Teatro Talisay north of Bacolod, Teatro Kahirup in Silay, Negros Occidental, and the Bohol Opera House. In Pampanga, Teatro Sabina showcased the drama and sarsuwela of prominent Kapampangan playwrights like Crissot.

While these theaters were built primarily for stage plays, some were used for musical presentations, particularly the Spanish zarzuela. In 1862, a visiting French operetta company performed in Teatro del Principe Alfonso, which likewise showcased a symphonic concert in 1871 under the baton of Ignacio Morales. Circo Teatro de Bilibid featured the Assi-Panades Italian Opera Company in 1874. Concerts by visiting artists Remenyi, 1886, and Freidenthal, 1892, as well as local artists Jose Silos, 1900, and Jose Estella, 1901, were held at Teatro Filipino on Echague Street. Lucia di Lammermoor was staged at Teatro Lirico de Quiapo by the M. Maugard French Opera Company. However, it was at Teatro Zorrilla, established in 1893, where many memorable concerts and sarsuwela were held, including the first Filipino opera, Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), 1902, by composer Ladislao Bonus and librettist Pedro Paterno.
American and Contemporary Traditions

The biggest show house constructed after the Philippine revolution was the Manila Grand Opera House, described as the “National Theater” in 1902. It was the site of many important musical events—Rizal Day programs, grand concerts of foreign and Filipino artists, sarsuwela, and operatic presentations, notably the Philippine premier of Giuseppe Verdi’s Aida in 1933. Eventually, these shows gave way to the vaudeville and musicals which replaced the sarsuwela and concerts in popularity.

The Metropolitan Theater, inaugurated in 1931, presented the best foreign and local artists performing in operas, zarzuela, orchestral, choral and solo concerts, musicals, dance, and theater productions. Its opening was a welcome event, as the Manila Grand Opera House, inaugurated in 1902, and the Teatro Circo de Zorrilla, inaugurated in 1893, were both deteriorating. The Metropolitan Theater was severely damaged during World War II and was restored three decades after, opening with an inaugural concert held on 17 Dec 1978. Its two halls were the main Conchita Sunico Hall and the more intimate side hall, Dalubdulaan. The theater closed down in 1996 due to a dispute between the City of Manila and the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) regarding the ownership of the building. Its last concert on 18 Jun 2011 featured the local rock band Wolfgang in celebration of the 440th year of the City of Manila. In 2015, the National Commission on Culture and the Arts won the bid to restore the theater, though the building still remains unrestored.

Other concert halls and auditoriums in Metro Manila are attached to the institutions where music degrees are offered. In Manila, the St. Cecilia’s Hall, inaugurated in 1932, presents recitalists of the St. Scholastica’s College School of Music, the oldest music school in the country, existing since 1906. The Hall, destroyed during World War II, was rebuilt in the 1950s and renovated in the late 1990s. The Corazon Aquino Hall in the new building inaugurated in 2011 presents smaller recitals.

The Fleur-de-lis Auditorium is the concert venue of the St. Paul University College of Music. The Sister Catalina Ledesma Recital Hall and the Santo Cristo del Tesoro Auditorium present recitals of the Santa Isabel College Conservatory of Music. In Quezon City, the Abelardo Hall Auditorium of the College of Music of the University of the Philippines (UP) celebrated its 50th anniversary through a formal gala concert held on 24 Sep 2013. Adjacent to the College of Music is the University Theater, which houses a main concert hall and a small recital hall at the back named Dalisay Aldaba Hall. In the Visayas, the recital venues include the University of San Agustin Auditorium in Iloilo and the Luce Auditorium of Silliman University in Dumaguete. In Mindanao, the Rodelsa Theater at the Liceo de Cagayan University in Cagayan de Oro is where its College of Music majors hold recitals.

Auditoriums of education institutions in Metro Manila include the Far Eastern University (FEU) Auditorium, the University of the East Theater, the Teresa Yuchengco Auditorium of De La Salle University in Manila, the James B. Reuter Theater of the St. Paul University, and the Marian Auditorium of Miriam College in Quezon City. The performing arts groups of De La Salle Zobel in Alabang, Muntinlupa City, present at the Angelo King Center for the Arts. The Marie Eugenie Theater of the Assumption (META) of the Assumption College in Makati and the Assumpta Theater of Assumption in Antipolo, Rizal, feature their respective students enrolled in their theater and ballet programs.

In the regions, school auditoriums, function halls, gymnasiums, sports complexes, and convention centers serve as concert venues. In Luzon, these include the Ilocos Norte Convention Center, the Laoag City Hall Auditorium, and the Don Mariano Marcos State University Sports Complex Auditorium in Ilocos Norte; the Vigan Culture and Trade Center and the Vigan Convention Center in Ilocos Sur; the Baguio City Convention Center Hall, the Baguio CAP (College Assurance Plan) Building in Camp John Hay, the University of Baguio Gym, St. Louis University Center for Culture and the Arts (SLU-CCA), and the University of Cordilleras Multi-Purpose Function Hall in Baguio; the Dagupan Sports Complex and the Sison Auditorium in Pangasinan; Casa San Miguel, the venue of the Pundaquit Arts Festival, a community arts program since 1996 designed to develop the local fishing community, and of workshops of the Pundaquit Virtuosi, a children’s ensemble, in Zambales; the Angeles University Foundation Theater and the Bren Z. Guiao Convention Center in Pampanga; Diwa ng Tarlak Convention Center, Muñoz Gym, and Central Luzon State University Auditorium in Nueva Ecija; the Malolos Sports and Convention Center, the Barasoain Kalinangan Nicanor Abelardo Theater, and the Hiyas ng Bulakan Convention Center in Bulacan; the Batangas City Convention Center and the Manuela Q. Pastor Auditorium of St. Bridget College (SBC) in Batangas City; Baler Gym in Aurora; Quezon Convention Center and Alcala Sports Complex in Lucena, Quezon; and the Universidad de Santa Isabel Auditorium, the Nueva Caceres Gym, and the Albay Astrodome in Albay.

In the Visayas, the venues include Cebu Coliseum, Cebu Cultural Center, St. Theresa’s College Auditorium, the Rudolf Rahmann Cultural Center of the University of San Carlos, and the CENEWOF (Cebu Newspaper Workers Foundation) Theater of the Marcelo B. Fernan Cebu Press Center in Cebu; the San Agustin College Gymnasium and the University of St. La Salle (USLS) Coliseum in Bacolod; Sentro Kansilayan in Silay; West Visayas State University Cultural Center in Iloilo; People’s Center in Tacloban; and the Capiz Gymnasium in Capiz.

In Mindanao, there are Capitol University Gymnatorium and the Xavier University-Ateneo de Cagayan Little Theater in Cagayan de Oro; the Mindanao State University-Iligan Insitute of Technology (MSU-IIT) College of Arts and Social Sciences Auditorium and St. Michael College Auditorium in Iligan City; Kambayoka and the Mindanao State University Gymnasium in Marawi City; Bukidnon State University Gymnasium, Central Mindanao University Gymnasium, and Kisolon Gym in Bukidnon; CAP Theater and Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Convention Center in Davao City; and the Tagum City Trade and Cultural Center Pavilion in Tagum.

Today, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) is the premier venue for presenting all types of music performances. It was designed by the late National Artist for Architecture Leandro Locsin and inaugurated in 1969. CCP has three theaters: the Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo, formerly known as the Main Theater; Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, formerly Little Theater; and Tanghalang Huseng Batute, its experimental theater, formerly Bulwagang Gantimpala. Occasionally, CCP’s ASEAN Park and the front lawn are used for performances of brass bands, choirs, and instrumental ensembles. During its annual Pasinaya Open House Festival, a one-day multi-arts Festival initiated in 2005 and held usually in February, the Center also opens the Bulwagang Amado Hernandez, its conference room; Bulwagang Francisca Reyes Aquino, its rehearsal hall; the Main Theater ramp and lobby; the eskinita (alley) in between the CCP and the Production Design Center; and Pedro Bukaneg Street, fronting the Little Theater entrance. In celebration of the Pasinaya Festival’s 10th year on 15 Mar 2014, the CCP partnered with several museums in Manila in presenting performances: the Metropolitan Museum and Museo Pambata (Children’s Museum) along Roxas Boulevard, the National Museum located next to Rizal Park, Casa Manila, and Bahay Tsinoy or Museum of Chinese in Philippine Life in Intramuros. The Center also manages the Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas or Folk Arts Theater, and the Manila Film Center, both located at the CCP Complex. Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas, which seats 8,000, used to present large popular concerts. The Manila Film Center, with a large main hall called Tanghalang Gerardo de Leon and two small halls called Tanghalang Severino Reyes and Tanghalang Antonio J. Molina, has been leased, since 2001, to Amazing Philippine Theater Inc, producer of the Amazing Philippine Show, a variety show catering to Korean tourists and featuring transgender performers.

Aside from the formal halls, other areas in the CCP complex have been used for performances. In 1975, the CCP parking lot was the venue of Jose Maceda’s Udlot-Udlot (Fluctuation), a 40-minute piece for bamboo instruments and voices. This was participated in by 850 high school students from the University of the Philippines Integrated School (UPIS). Earlier, in 1971, the main lobby and stairway of the Main Theater was used for the performance of Maceda’s Cassettes 100, participated in by 100 cassette-bearing ambulant participants sounding pretaped music and freely mingling with the audience. In 1991, the loading dock at the side of the main theater stage was the venue of Ramon P. Santos’s Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden), 1991, a multimedia work combining music (two pianos, bamboo instruments, percussion), voice (soprano), poetry (recited by a reader), and dance (a male and female who perform on ropes attached to a ladder-like pyramid frame). Since 1987, the CCP Liwasang Darangen (behind the marquee) has been the site of the special CCP shows in December and in February.

Adjacent to the CCP is the Aliw Theater owned and managed by Star Parks Corporation, developers of the country’s all-weather theme park, Star City. It presents international and local concerts, ballet performances, and corporate events. The GSIS Theater near the Manila Film Center presents musical performances and theater productions. The GSIS Museum presents intimate recitals. Attached to the CCP is the Tanghalang Mariang Makiling of the National Arts Center in Mount Makiling, which presents in Los Baños the recitals of the Philippine High School for the Arts scholars who major in dance, music, and theater. Another landmark at the CCP Complex is the Philippine International Convention Center, a venue for political summits and concerts of local and international artists. Also designed by Locsin, it has five building modules: the Delegation Building, Secretariat Building, Plenary Hall, Reception Hall, and The Forum. All of these may be transformed into a number of settings for exhibitions, conventions, or special events.

The Philamlife Auditorium along United Nations Ave, inaugurated in 1961, was known for its excellent acoustics and art deco interiors. It was a venue for classical concerts of foreign and local musical artists, with the performance of Ukrainian pianist Sofya Gulyak with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) in Mar 2013 being its last. The building was sold to developer Shoe Mart Development Corporation (SMDC) in 2012. Responding to an online petition to preserve the theater, SMDC announced on 4 Apr 2013 that it would “save and preserve the culturally historic Philam Life theater.”

In Makati City, the Francisco Santiago Hall, now owned by Banco de Oro (BDO), has featured classical concerts since 1985. The Carlos P. Romulo Auditorium of the RCBC (Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation) Plaza accommodates Broadway-style musicals, ballet, opera, drama, and dance. Concerts are also held at the Ayala Museum’s ground floor lobby. In Quezon City, venues for music performances include the AFP Theater (Armed Forces of the Philippines Theater) in Camp Aguinaldo and the Dolphy Theater at the ABS-CBN Compound, home of ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra. In Pasig City, the Meralco Theater is a venue for classical concerts. In Muntinglupa City, the Insular Life Theater built mainly for corporate events has been used since 2008 for classical season concerts produced by Filfest (Friends of the Insular Life Festival) Foundation.

The Newport Performing Arts Center in Resorts World Manila in Pasay City is one of the newest performing arts venues in the country. Formally inaugurated in 2010, it presents concerts of international rock bands and solo vocal artists, plays, and musicals. The Center boasts of the widest stage among existing Philippine theaters and the biggest LED screen in Asia, providing dynamic video backdrops for productions. It is also equipped with two Euro-LED screens with 3-D effects, a complex fly system, and a revolving stage.

Lobbies and ballrooms of hotels also serve as performance venues. In Metro Manila these hotels include the Shangri-la and Mandarin Oriental Manila, the Manila Hotel, and the Sofitel Philippine Plaza. The Manila Peninsula holds its annual Concert at the Pen featuring the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and choral ensembles in a Christmas concert. The Grand Ballroom of Solaire Resorts and Casino, inaugurated in 2013, features international popular performing groups. These artists are likewise presented in the Grand Ballrooms of hotel chains in other parts of the country such as the Marco Polo and the Waterfront Hotels in Cebu.

Even shopping centers today are venues for performances, particularly for popular music. In Metro Manila, these include the Music Museum and the Teatrino at the Greenhills Shopping Center in San Juan, as well as open spaces at the Shangri-la Plaza and the Megaworld Lifestyle Malls. The Ayala, Robinson’s, and SM Malls in Metro Manila and the regions have their respective large spaces for music performances. Concerts of foreign and local popular singing icons also take place at the SM Malls’ SMX Convention Centers in different parts of the country, the Mall of Asia Arena in Pasay City, and the Araneta Coliseum in Quezon City.

At the foothills of Mount Malasimbo in Puerto Galera, Oriental Mindoro, the Malasimbo Music and Arts Festival takes place in a prominent grass-terraced amphitheater. Produced by a group of individuals passionate about music, arts, culture, and heritage, this unique international Festival has, since its debut in 2011, attracted thousands of tourists. It is now recognized as a notable eco-cultural program.

With the continuous advancement of technology, music making has nowhere to go but forward. Soon, more performances of different music genres will take place with the construction of more state-of-the-art theaters and auditoriums in the country. These halls serve as the venue for formal concerts featuring serious as well as popular music, which are usually held in the evenings and last for about two to three hours. Audiences in these venues usually pay for tickets to watch musicians perform on a proscenium stage. Performances may be held by professional or nonprofessional musicians all-year round or on special occasions. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Melissa Corazon V. Mantaring
