text:
Awards of different types are given to honor the achievements of musical artists. These may come in the form of trophies, medals, or cash rewards as prizes in competition. Grants are given to artists to help in the creation and/or performance of musical works. These may be given in the form of cash or subsidy to finance a tour or the rental of a venue for the performance. Commissions are financial awards given to composers to create a musical work. A music contest is an event designed to identify, select, and award outstanding musical ensembles, soloists, and works.

 

Both public and private sectors give commissions, grants, and awards for music, and sponsor music contests. The government has created musical bodies or cultural institutions to promote music. Civic organizations, foundations, and individuals have also generously supported the musical arts.

Awards. Among the earliest awards were those conferred by the Manila Music Lovers Society on musicians, music writers, and music critics from the 1940s to the 1950s. Among the many awardees were pianist Ernestina Crisologo, pianist-singer Pilar Blanco-Sala, composer Felipe Padilla de Leon, and critics Rosalinda Orosa and J. Mauricio Pimentel. The Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation, founded in 1957, has to date only honored one musician—violinist Gilopez Kabayao, in 1972.

From 1960 to 1972, the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, created in 1960, was the highest form of recognition bestowed by the government on those who made outstanding contributions in the fields of science, arts, and letters. It was given for works and not for lifetime achievement. It sought to “establish a standard of excellence which would serve both as an incentive and goal for the future generation.” Among the awardees in music were Antonino Buenventura, 1961; Lucio D. San Pedro, 1962; Alfredo S. Buenaventura, 1964 and 1972; Eliseo M. Pajaro, 1964 and 1970; Antonio J. Molina, 1965 and 1972; and Felipe Padilla de Leon, 1971.

Since 1959, the Philippine Jaycees has given the annual Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) awards to individuals who excel in their respective fields, including the arts. The first awardee for music was the late baritone Aurelio Estanislao, who received the award in the same year. He was followed by conductor Oscar Yatco, 1960; violinist Gilopez Kabayao, 1961; pianist Benjamin Tupas, 1962; singer-composer Jose Mari Chan, 1974; composer Ryan Cayabyab, 1978; pianist Raul Sunico, 1986; pianist Cecile Licad, 1987; international performer Lea Salonga and singer-composer Joey Ayala, both in 1991; alternative music performer Grace Nono, 1994; pianist Jovianney Emmanuel Cruz, 1996; composer Josefino “Chino” Toledo, 1997; composer Jeffrey Ching, 1998; liturgical music composer Fr Manoling Francisco, SJ, 1999; violinist Alfonso “Coke” Bolipata, 2000; singer Gary Valenciano, 2001; flutist Antonio Maigue, 2002; singer Rachelle Gerodias, 2010; and conductor Gerard Joseph Salonga and Allan “apl.de.ap” Pineda Jr, both in 2012.

The TOWNS (The Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service) award is given every three years to Filipino women who have shown exceptional talent and devotion to their career. Since its inception in 1974, the award has cited seven women in the music field: pianist Ingrid Sala-Santamaria, 1981; pianist Cecile Licad, 1986; pianist Rowena Arrieta and singer Celeste Legaspi, both in 1989; theater artists Maria Lea Carmen Salonga and Monica Anne Wilson, both in 1998; and soprano Rachelle Gerodias, 2013.

Local governments all over the country confer awards on distinguished “sons” or “daughters” who have excelled in music. One such award is the Parangal sa mga Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan given every year for almost three decades on Manila’s Founding Day, 24 Jun. The local government of Manila has conferred the Diwa ng Lahi Award to Atang de la Rama, 1974; Jovita Fuentes, 1975; Lucrecia R. Kasilag, 1984; Felipe Padilla de Leon, 1992; and Andrea O. Veneracion, 2002. It has also given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award to Isang C. Tapales, 1977; UP Madrigal Singers, 1980; and Mercedes Matias Santiago, 1982; and the Musika Award to Leon Ignacio, 1963; Nicanor S. Abelardo and Lucrecia R. Kasilag, both in 1964; Ladislao Bonus, 1966; Julio Nakpil, 1967; Francisco Santiago, 1968; Marcelo Adonay and Antonio J. Molina, both in 1969; Antonino Buenaventura and Jose Estella, both in 1970; Felipe Padilla de Leon and Juan S. Hernandez, both in 1971; Oscar Yatco, 1972; Regalado Jose, 1973; Eliseo M. Pajaro, 1974; Victor Toledo and Aurelio Estanislao, both in 1975; Laureano G. Cariño and Luis C. Valencia, both in 1976; Corazon Maceda, 1978; Gilopez Kabayao, 1979; Vicente M. Sales, 1981; Francisco F. Feliciano and Levi Celerio, both in 1983; Juan Silos Jr and Lucio D. San Pedro, both in 1984; Alfredo S. Buenaventura, 1985; Sergio Z. Esmilla, 1988; Josefino Cenizal, 1989; Ramon P. Santos, 1991; Basilio C. Manalo, 1992; Cecile Licad, 1993; Raul Sunico, 1998; Ryan Cayabyab, 2001; Herminigildo Ranera, 2006; and The CompanY, 2015.

Since 1977, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) has recognized outstanding artists. Among the awardees in music are the following: baritone Aurelio Estanislao, 1978; conductor-violinist Luis Valencia, 1982; pianist-teacher Rosario A. Picazo, 1983; mezzo-soprano Conchita Gaston Holmes, 1984; and composer Mike Velarde Jr, 1986. Since 1989, when it was instituted as the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, awardees have received medals of recognition designed by National Artist Napoleon V. Abueva, citation scrolls, and 10,000-peso gift cheques. Awardees in music are ethnomusicologist Jose Maceda, 1989; choral master Andrea Veneracion, 1990; kulintang player Amal Lumuntod and lyricist-violinist-composer Levi Celerio, both in 1991; epic chanter Elena Gardoce and composer-conductor Ramon Tapales, both in 1992; soprano Dalisay Aldaba, 1993; international concert pianist Cecile Licad, 1994; pianist Nena del Rosario, 1997, in which year the National Music Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA) was also given the Tanging Parangal (Distinguished Award); composer Ryan Cayabyab, 2004; outreach concert artists Gilopez and Corazon Kabayao, 2008; composer Ramon P. Santos, 2012; and soprano Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, 2015.

The government also occasionally gives artists the Presidential Award of Merit. Eliseo M. Pajaro received it in 1966 for his Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seeds of Freedom), the first modern Filipino opera, as did international pianist Cecile B. Licad and international singer-actress Lea Salonga in 1991 for bringing the innate musical artistry of the Filipino people to the world’s attention. The award was renamed the Presidential Medal of Merit by virtue of Executive Order (EO) No 236, signed on 19 Sep 2003. Oscar Yatco received the award in 2006 for bringing classical music to the masses through the establishment of the weekly Concert at the Park. Other recipients of the award in the field of music in 2006 were members of the American hip-hop group Black Eyed Peas apl.de.ap and will.I.am, who brought international recognition to the country and held charity concerts to raise funds and help victims of calamities in various regions in the Philippines in the same year; and Otoniel Gonzaga in 2007. In 2009, the award was posthumously conferred to rapper Francis Magalona.

The National Artist Award, established under Presidential Proclamation No. 1001 on 27 Apr 1972 to honor Filipinos who have made outstanding contributions to Philippine arts and letters, replaced the Republic Cultural Heritage Award. It was later amended through Presidential Proclamation No. 1144 issued on 15 May 1973, creating a National Artists Award Committee to administer the conferment of the honor. It is now the highest and most prestigious award that the government gives to musicians and other artists. The following have been named National Artists for Music: Antonio J. Molina, 1973, who “pioneered in transmuting native melodies and rhythms into musical compositions of great originality and force”; Jovita Fuentes, 1976, for “her mastery of the noblest musical instrument, the voice, which continues to inspire and invigorate the musical development of the country”; Honorata “Atang” de la Rama, 1987, for “her sincere devotion to original theater and music, her outstanding artistry as singer and as sarsuwela actor-playwright-producer,” and for “her tireless efforts to bring her art to all regions and sectors of Filipino society and to the world”; Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988, for keeping “the nationalist tradition alive in his works by espousing the great possibilities of our indigenous music tradition in creating a distinct Philippine sound”; Lucrecia R. Kasilag, 1990, “[whose] devotion to her art … has added important new dimensions to our musical traditions, earning the respect and admiration of many”; Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991, for “his musical philosophy of ‘creative nationalism’ [which] entails an imaginative and emotional interaction between the artist and his culture”; Felipe Padilla de Leon, 1997, for having “achieved a keen understanding and oneness with the soul of his people such that his music breathes its very essence”; Levi Celerio, 1997, for being a “poet for the man-on-the-street who easily relates to him and his works, a true artist of the people … reaching out to the ordinary Filipino”; Jose Maceda, 1997, for having “dedicated his life towards the promotion of a national cultural identity, initiating and inspiring the scholarly study of the music and culture of the Filipino minority groups”; Ernani Cuenco, 1999, who believed that “music unheard was as good as music not created at all”; Andrea O. Veneracion, 1999, for having “consistently kept the Philippine Madrigal Singers’ hallmark of excellence, and for establishing a tradition of fine choral singing in the Philippines”; Francisco Feliciano, 2014, for having “brought the wealth of indigenous Philippine culture to the musical stages of the world”; Ramon P. Santos, 2014, whose body of works highlight the “people-specific concepts central to the ethnomusicological discipline, the translation of indigenous musical systems into modern musical discourse, and the marriage of Western and non-Western sound”; and Ryan Cayabyab, 2018,

 

In support of National Artists, Presidential Decree No. 208, effected on 7 Jun 1973, granted them further privileges and honors: a 10,000-peso gift cheque; a monthly life pension of 2,000 pesos; medical and hospitalization benefits; lifetime insurance of 50,000 pesos; a place of honor at state functions, national commemoration ceremonies, and all other cultural presentations; and a state funeral. National Artists are recommended by the Board of Trustees of the CCP, and since 1989, also by the Presidential (now National) Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and declared by the President. In 2003, EO No. 236 was signed which established the honors code of the Philippines to create an order of precedence of honors conferred and for other purposes. By virtue of this EO, the National Artist Award became the Orden ng mga Pambansang Alagad ng Sining (Order of National Artists), with revised privileges and honors. The cash award was increased to 100,000 for living awardees and 75,000 for posthumous awardees; so, too, the monthly life pension and medical and hospitalization benefits. Life insurance coverage was given to awardees who were still insurable. Also sustained were arrangements and expenses for a state funeral and burial at the Libingan ng mga Bayani (Cemetery of Heroes); a place of honor, in line with protocol, at national state functions, and acknowledgment at cultural events.

As a counterpart of the Order of National Artist, Republic Act (RA) No. 7355 was passed on 3 Apr 1992, which provided for the recognition of national living treasures, otherwise known as the Manlilikha ng Bayan (Creator of the Nation), and the promotion and development of traditional folk arts. The Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA (National Living Treasure Award) was created through Executive Order No. 236 and is “conferred upon a Filipino citizen or group of Filipino citizens engaged in any traditional art uniquely Filipino, whose distinctive skills have reached such a high level of technical and artistic excellence and have been passed on to and widely practiced by the present generations in his/her community with the same degree of technical and artistic competence.” Since its establishment, five traditional musicians have been conferred the award: Samaon Sulaiman, 1993, master of the kutyapi (two-stringed boat lute), and teacher of kulintang, agong, gandingan, palendag, and tambul (various indigenous instruments); Masino Intaray, 1993, an epic chanter from Palawan; Uwang Ahadas, 2000, a Yakan master of the kwintangan kayu and tuntungan (indigenous wooden instruments); Frederico Caballero, 2000, a Sulod-Bukidnon epic chanter from Kalinog, Iloilo; and Alonzo Saclag, 2000, Kalinga master of dance and performing arts.

Another award that recognizes the contribution of Filipino artists is the Ani ng Dangal, given by the NCCA annually since 2009. Unlike the other awards which focus on individual achievements through many years of artistic productivity, this covers distinctions earned by artists in all art forms on a per year basis in international competitions. Some of the Filipino musicians given the Ani ng Dangal award are Nilo Alcala, 2009; University of the East Chorale, 2009; UP Singing Ambassadors, 2009 and 2013; Novo Concertante Manila, 2009, 2010, 2013, and 2015; Cebu Chamber Singers, 2009 and 2012; Hail Mary the Queen Children’s Choir, 2009 and 2014; Beverly Shangkuan, 2010; Ritchie Asibal, 2010; Teresa Barrozo, 2010; University of the Visayas Chorale, 2010; University of Santo Tomas Singers, 2010 and 2011; AUP Singing Ambassadors, 2012; Imusicapella, 2012 and 2013; Tristan Ignacio, 2012; Edgardo Manguiat, 2013; Joseleo Logdat, 2013; Arwin Tan, 2013; De La Salle University Chorale, 2014; Aleron, 2015; Saint Louis University Glee Club, 2015; and Alvin Paulin, 2015.

Awards have also been given solely in the field of popular music. In 1977, the Popular Music Foundation was organized to promote contemporary compositions and develop Filipino amateur and professional composers and songwriters. In 1982, the Foundation initiated the first music industry awards known as the Cecil Awards. Named after Cecil Lloyd, the “Filipino Mystery Singer,” it was launched the same year to honor the country’s best recording artists, encourage musicians, and raise artistic standards in the music industry. Some of the artists who received the Cecil Award were singers Nonoy Zuñiga, Kuh Ledesma, and Freddie Aguilar, and composers Willy Cruz and George Canseco. Some quarters, however, criticized the awards for favoring the big Manila-based recording companies. In 1986, the Cecil Awards bowed out from the Philippine music scene.

The Awit Awards started in 1969 but ended in 1971. It came out of hiatus when the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI) revived it in 1988, aided by the Samahan sa Musika (SAMAKA). Since then, PARI has been responsible for the said award. It carries the same objectives as the Cecil Awards. The wide and varying range of categories include awards given to solo or group performers, composers, arrangers, record producers, audio engineers, music pioneers, and even a significant record or album. Among the many awardees are Gary Valenciano, Rachel Alejandro, Jose Mari Chan, APO Hiking Society, Smokey Mountain, Ryan Cayabyab, Nonoy Zuñiga, Joey Albert, Pilita Corrales, The CompanY, Side A Band, Freestyle, South Border, Gary Valenciano, Martin Nieverra, Rannie Raymundo, Ogie Alcasid, Rico Blanco, Noel Cabangon, Aiza Seguerra, Dessa, Grace Nono, Jaya, Karylle, Kyla, Sitti, and L.A. Lopez.

The Aliw Awards, started in 1975 by the National Press Club and later run by the Aliw Foundation, is given annually to upgrade the quality of live entertainment. There are two general categories of winners: the musical category, which includes group or individual artists and/or performances of serious or popular music, and the nonmusical category, which includes group or individual artists and/or performances in theater and television. Among the many musical artists who have won the Aliw are singers Pilita Corrales, Rico J. Puno, Celeste Legaspi, Basil Valdez, Kuh Ledesma, Freddie Aguilar, Pops Fernandez, Leo Valdez, Martin Nievera, Bert Nievera, Vernie Varga, Gary Valenciano, Zsa Zsa Padilla, Marco Sison, and Sharon Cuneta; group performers Kundirana, Madrigal Singers, Tux, Family Birth Control Band, Bong Peñera Jazz Band, Emil Mijares Jazz Band, Tribung Pinoy, and the Manila Peninsula Strings; instrumentalists Eddie Katindig and Joselito Pascual; and composers Homer Flores, Ryan Cayabyab, and Louie Ocampo. Ingrid Sala-Santamaria was conferred the Lifetime Achievement Award in 2008. Among its roster of awards, the Entertainer of the Year award is the most sought-after. Most recent recipients are Regine Velasquez in 2009, Sarah Geronimo in 2010, and Charice Pempengco in 2011.

 

Katha Music Awards ranks among the most coveted awards for songwriters and popular music performers as these are given based on exceptional achievement either as composer or performer, and not based on popularity or marketability. The first Katha Awards were given out in 1995. Some of the exceptional artists who have won this award are South Border, Jungee Marcelo, Radha Cuadrado, Jonathan Manalo, Gloc-9, Grace Nono, and Eraserheads.

The NU Rock Awards recognized hard work and artistry specifically among rock artists. These were given yearly from 1994 to 2010. It was sponsored by the now-defunct radio station NU 107. Among the rock artists who were honored by the NU Rock Awards were the bands Afterimage, Eraserheads, Wolfgang, Parokya ni Edgar, Slapshock, Bamboo, Orange and Lemons, Kamikazee, Pupil, Up Dharma Down, Franco, Alamid, and Put3ska.

 

Beginning 2008, the National Book Development Board (NBDB) and the Manila Critics Circle (MCC) have given the National Book Award to recognize the contribution to scholarship of writers and musicologists who have published outstanding researches on Philippine music and culture. This award was established by the MCC in 1982. Among the books which have been awarded are Jose Maceda’s Gongs and Bamboo: A Panorama of Philippine Musical Instruments, 1998; Marjorie Evasco’s biography on Andrea Veneracion, A Life Shaped by Music, 2001; Richie Quirino’s Pinoy Jazz Traditions, 2004; Ramon Santos’s Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music and Manolete Mora’s Myth, Mimesis and Magic in the Music of the T’boli, Philippines, both in 2006; and Raul Navarro’s Kolonyal na Patakaran at ang Nagbabagong Kamalayang Filipino: Musika sa Publikong Paaralan sa Pilipinas 1898-1935, 2008.

 

In 2010, MYX, the music channel owned by ABS-CBN, began to give out awards to local music artists and music videos based on votes garnered from viewers and followers. Among the winners of the 2010 MYX Music Awards are Sarah Geronimo (Favorite Female Artist), Rico Blanco (Favorite Male Artist), Sponge Cola (Favorite Group), “Kasalanan” by 6cyclemind and Gloc-9 (Favorite Music Video), and “Back in Time” by Kyla and Jay-R (Favorite Song). Also for that year, Jose Mari Chan received the MYX Magna Award, a special recognition given to Filipino music stalwarts. Other MYX Magna Awardees are Regine Velasquez, 2011; Ryan Cayabyab, 2012; Lea Salonga, 2013; Parokya ni Edgar, 2014; Rey Valera, 2015; and Ogie Alcasid, 2016.

Grants and Commissions. RA 1370 effected on 18 Jun 1955 created the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP). In 1961, RA 3042 allotted 400,000 pesos annually to MPFP and to cultural groups studying and disseminating Filipino folk arts, music, and dances abroad. The MPFP helped leading composers to produce new works in various forms, including chamber works, operas, sarsuwela, concertos, and symphonic and band works. From 1959 to 1972, the MPFP commissioned a total of 19 compositions. It also gave out 76 student scholarship grants from 1957 to 1965.

The League of Filipino Composers (LFC), also founded in 1955, presented new works at annual festivals with help from MPFP subsidies. Later on, the CCP, inaugurated in 1969, co-sponsored the annual festivals and continues to commission works. The LFC has presented more than 160 commissioned works.

Aside from the awards it annually confers on leading Filipino musical artists, the CCP has also provided tour grants to the following musicians: Ramon P. Santos, Felicidad Prudente, and Kristina Benitez, all in 1989, Jose Maceda in 1990, and the UP Singing Ambassadors and Joey Ayala at Ang Bagong Lumad, both in 1991. Since its restoration in 1978 until its untimely closure in 1990, the Metropolitan Theater has actively commissioned both classical and popular composers to write sarsuwela, musicals, and other works.

Private musical organizations such as the Manila Symphony Orchestra, institutions such as schools, banks, and corporations, and private individuals have engaged many a composer to create symphonic works, marches, hymns, songs, choral works, musicals, and even commercial jingles. NCCA, through its Grants Program, has funded many projects which highlight the contributions of culture to national growth and development. It aids in identifying programs and projects that focus on the positive impacts of culture and arts to the life of men and women, most especially the vulnerable and marginalized sectors in the various regions of the country. Since its inception, NCCA has provided venues for the different regions to articulate their local culture and development concerns. Among its recipients are the Pasinaya Performing Arts Market at the CCP; the International Las Piñas Bamboo Organ Festival; the Pasasalamat Festival of Pagadian; Konsiyerto ng Pangalay, Tula, Salinawit at Musika; Teduray Dance and Gong Playing; School of Living Traditions on Maguindanao Kulintang-Playing of Barangay Lower Campo Islam, Labangan, Zamboanga del Sur; Taal Tunugan: Philippine Musical and Vocal Forms in Vernacular; and Kuwerdas ng Pagkakaisa (Strings of Unity) Rondalla Festival.

Music Contests. The European classical art music idiom, traditionally, has relied heavily on the institution of music competitions to provide a forum for recognizing the most outstanding instrumentalists, vocalists, composers, orchestras, and small ensembles, thereby contributing significantly to the establishment of these artists’ careers. Classical instrumental ensembles such as brass bands, school bands and choirs, and church and community choirs have also long relied on competitions and festivals to promote their groups and showcase high levels of artistry. In recent decades, various competitions have also arisen in the field of popular music.

During the Spanish colonial period, formal music contests in the field of art music were first sponsored by private artistic and musical societies and by religious groups. These groups celebrated the feast of Saint Cecilia, Patroness of Music, with concerts and contests. The Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario held one such contest in 1879, where noted cellist-pianist Antonio Garcia won second prize. During the American period, new schools and societies continued the institution of music competitions. With the establishment of the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1908 came the competition for composing its hymn which Nicanor S. Abelardo, then a student at the UP Conservatory of Music, won in 1917. Escuelas Confederadas de Musica was a private school in Quiapo composed of three departments: the Schola Cantorum under Victorino Carrion, the Escuela de Piano under Vicente Marifosqui, and the Escuela de Violin under Bonifacio Abdon. These departments held their respective contests, with the Schola Cantorum even sponsoring in 1933 an essay-writing contest on music open to its graduates and students. Private individuals also sponsored music contests. The distinguished composer of sacred music, Marcelo Adonay, sponsored a competition for the best wedding march on the occasion of his golden wedding anniversary in 1924. Abelardo won the 100,000-peso grand prize, and his work was played during the event.

The Japanese interregnum, 1941-45, saw a proliferation of music contests custom-made by the Japanese government to promote their own agenda. There was much music-making but the aim was to move away from the supposedly excessive, materialistic, and degenerating influence of American culture. Music contests were thus held with the goal of re-orienting or re-aligning Filipino culture towards becoming a worthy member of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. Some of these contests were the Pilipino Farmers Song Contest, the March and Kundiman Contest, the Philippine Band Contest, and the Music Concourse, Literary and Song-Writing Competition of the Manila Shimbunsha, the umbrella newspaper company during this period. Among the prize-winning compositions were “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Pilipinas” (Song for the Creation of a New Philippines), which temporarily replaced the National Anthem, music by Felipe Padilla de Leon, lyrics by first prize winner Catalino Dionisio; “Awit ng Mga Magsasaka” (Song of the Farmers), music by F. P. de Leon, lyrics by Simplicio Talens; and “President Laurel March,” music by Lucio San Pedro, lyrics by Jacinto de Leon. Other composers who won various awards for their compositions were Leon Ignacio, Hilarion Rubio, Francisco Buencamino, Lucino Sacramento, and Nemesio Regalado. To encourage excellence in band music, awards were given under the auspices of the Philippine Band Association in 1943. The Muling Pagsikat Band under Rafael Batugal won the top prize.

Postwar Philippines saw a new phase in the life of the nation’s music contests as artists grappled with nation building in their music. Foremost among the music competitions was the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA), established in 1973, which sparked nationwide contests that nurtured the country’s young talents in various categories—piano, voice, choral music, solo, family ensemble, traditional music, and commissioned contest pieces. Created by Proclamation No. 1173, NAMCYA designated a National Music Week in November, with the CCP and the Department of Education as its prime collaborating arms.

In 2009, the CCP staged the 1st Philippine International Choral Competition, which took place from 18 to 22 Aug. The festival was part of its 40th anniversary celebration, and it brought choirs from different parts of the Philippines to compete in four categories: Children’s Choir, Mixed Choir, Sacred Music, and Folk Music. Not long after, the Andrea O. Veneracion International Choral Festival 2013 was launched to celebrate the 50th founding anniversary of the Philippine Madrigal Singers, the choir that Veneracion, a National Artist, nurtured to become the world-class ensemble that it is today. It was held from 7-10 Aug, a month after the passing of Veneracion. A total of five foreign choirs from Indonesia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, and Thailand, and 14 Filipino choirs competed in three categories. The second edition of this international choral competition was held from 22-25 Jul 2015.

Many other choral competitions have been held, and among those which have lasted through the years include Voices in Harmony, a competition for high school choirs organized by the Children’s Museum and Library, Inc (CMLI) which began in 1999; the annual Musikahan sa Tagum, sponsored by the city government of Tagum and the City of Tagum Tourism Office since 1999, which includes competitions for choirs, band, singing, and rondalla; the MBC Choral Competition, organized by the Manila Broadcasting Company since 2007; Musica FEUROPA, the only European Union-sponsored choral competition in the Philippines, hosted by the Far Eastern University since 2009; and the annual Government Choral Competition, a Civil Service Commission-sponsored competition for choirs of government agencies which held its first edition in 2011.

Another festival held regularly at the CCP is the International Guitar Festival and Competition. It began in 2010, organized by Guitar Friends, a group of Filipino guitar aficionados, and the CCP. In its 2011 competition, Filipino guitarist Ramoncito Carpio won the first prize.

Aside from the CCP-initiated festivals, there is the Kundiman Fiesta sponsored by Hotel Nikko Manila Garden in Makati which began in 1991. The goal of the festival was to revive the singing of the Filipino kundiman and propagate this singing tradition among the youth. The first five years were financed by the hotel management and produced the following top kundiman singers: Francisco Batomalaque, 1991; Alexis Sumicat, 1992; Nolito Gregorio, 1993; Joel Saavedra, 1994; and Cherry Batalla, 1995. When the ownership of Hotel Nikko changed in 1996, the annual Kundiman Fiesta faced an uncertain fate. The NCCA eventually took over, and the 1996 edition was held on 4 Dec at the Folk Arts Theater, with Marya Deeda Barreto as the winner. The Makati Coliseum and Cultural Affairs Office started another kundiman singing competition in 1995 to celebrate “Buwan ng Wika” (Language Month) in Makati City. The competition was aptly called “Kampeon ng Kundiman” and was later on renamed “Kundiman sa Makati.” It has been held annually ever since.

A contest of semiclassical tradition was the Yamaha Electone Festival (YEF) held from 1972 to the late 1990s, which showcased the capability of the electronic organ to replicate the sound of an entire orchestra, traditional instrumental ensemble, or popular bands. Aside from original compositions for the Electone, the festival required the participants to display their arrangements and improvisational skills during the competition. The festival’s national champion represented the country in the Southeast Asian regional competition, and those who won in the regional contest advanced to the International Electone Concours, which was always held in Japan. Many YEF winners have become prominent contributors to the country’s music industry such as Francisco “Toti” Fuentes, Maritess Salientes, Carolyn Kleiner-Cheng, Louie Ocampo, Rowena Arietta, Maria Corazon “Maricor” Perez, Norman Agatep, Jesse Lucas, Marvin Queirdo, Pipo Cifra, Rica Arambulo, Noel Arce, Charisse Baldoria, Khavn de la Cruz, Arwin Tan, Dennis Sugarol, and Jude Roldan.

Contests in the field of popular music have been led by the Metro Manila Popular Music Festival (Metropop) established in 1978 under the auspices of the Popular Music Foundation and led by Imee Marcos and Teodoro Valencia. The most prestigious pop music contest of its time, it came at a period when national pride in music was ardently felt, thus inspiring the growth of Original Pilipino Music (OPM). Winners included Ryan Cayabyab for “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful Is Our Music), Freddie Aguilar for “Anak” (Child) and “Bulag, Pipi at Bingi” (Blind, Mute, and Deaf), Louie Ocampo and Rowena Arrieta for “Ewan” (I Don’t Know), Odette Quesada for “Give Me a Chance” and “Till I Met You,” Nonong Pedero for “Narito Ako” (Here I Am) and “Isang Mundo, Isang Awit” (One World, One Song), George Canseco for “Ako ang Nagwagi, Ako ang Nasawi” (I Won, I Lost), Ananias Montano for “Babae Ka” (You’re a Girl), Gines Tan for “Magsimula Ka” (Make a Start), and Gary Granada for “Salamat, Salamat Musika” (Thanks, Music). Although it launched the careers of many aspiring songwriters and produced an avalanche of OPM, the Metropop lasted only until 1985 as the end of the Marcos regime neared. It was revived in 1996 as the Metropop Song Fest, which lasted until 2003.

Launched on 15 Feb 2012 was the Philippine Pop Music Festival (PhilPop) Songwriting Competition which aimed to encourage Filipinos to create music that could become classic hits. The competition is organized and sponsored by a group of companies owned by business tycoon Manuel V. Pangilinan. The first grand prize winner was Karl Villuga with his song “Bawat Hakbang” (Every Step), interpreted in the 2012 festival by Mark Bautista and the Akafellas. In its 2013 edition, the top winners were Thyro Alfaro and Yumi Lacsamana with their song “Dati” (Before), interpreted by Tippy Dos Santos and Sam Concepcion. In 2014, the grand prizewinner was veteran Jungee Marcelo with his song “Salbabida” (Lifesaver), interpreted by Kyla.

Recent music competitions include the Kapisanan ng Mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP) Pop Music Festival in 2010 which uniquely took place over the airwaves and aimed to generate new Filipino songs; the Philippine Popular Music Festival in 2012 which aired over TV5, and whose entries won by number of text votes; and the Manila Broadcasting Company’s choral contests, held under the auspices of the largest radio network in Asia, which draws school ensembles from all over the country. A music contest with the goal of giving thanks and praise to God is the ASOP (A Song of Praise Music Festival), which receives song entries from the Philippines and overseas, is streamed live on www.untvweb.com, and is covered internationally by UNTV 37.

ABS-CBN Corporation and its music subsidiary, Star Music, have their own songwriting and music video competition known as Himig Handog. The contest initially ran from 2000 to 2003 and had varying themes in each year. It was discontinued after 2003 but was revived in 2013 as Himig Handog Pinoy Pop Love Songs, with romantic love as the primary theme of all song-entries. The grand winner of the 2013 competition was Jovinor Tan and his song “Anong Nangyari Sa Ating Dalawa?” as interpreted by Aiza Seguerra. Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Ma. Patricia B. Silvestre and Arwin Q. Tan

article.value: Awards of different types are given to honor the achievements of musical artists. These may come in the form of trophies, medals, or cash rewards as prizes in competition. Grants are given to artists to help in the creation and/or performance of musical works. These may be given in the form of cash or subsidy to finance a tour or the rental of a venue for the performance. Commissions are financial awards given to composers to create a musical work. A music contest is an event designed to identify, select, and award outstanding musical ensembles, soloists, and works.

article.value: Both public and private sectors give commissions, grants, and awards for music, and sponsor music contests. The government has created musical bodies or cultural institutions to promote music. Civic organizations, foundations, and individuals have also generously supported the musical arts.

Awards. Among the earliest awards were those conferred by the Manila Music Lovers Society on musicians, music writers, and music critics from the 1940s to the 1950s. Among the many awardees were pianist Ernestina Crisologo, pianist-singer Pilar Blanco-Sala, composer Felipe Padilla de Leon, and critics Rosalinda Orosa and J. Mauricio Pimentel. The Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation, founded in 1957, has to date only honored one musician—violinist Gilopez Kabayao, in 1972.

From 1960 to 1972, the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, created in 1960, was the highest form of recognition bestowed by the government on those who made outstanding contributions in the fields of science, arts, and letters. It was given for works and not for lifetime achievement. It sought to “establish a standard of excellence which would serve both as an incentive and goal for the future generation.” Among the awardees in music were Antonino Buenventura, 1961; Lucio D. San Pedro, 1962; Alfredo S. Buenaventura, 1964 and 1972; Eliseo M. Pajaro, 1964 and 1970; Antonio J. Molina, 1965 and 1972; and Felipe Padilla de Leon, 1971.

Since 1959, the Philippine Jaycees has given the annual Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) awards to individuals who excel in their respective fields, including the arts. The first awardee for music was the late baritone Aurelio Estanislao, who received the award in the same year. He was followed by conductor Oscar Yatco, 1960; violinist Gilopez Kabayao, 1961; pianist Benjamin Tupas, 1962; singer-composer Jose Mari Chan, 1974; composer Ryan Cayabyab, 1978; pianist Raul Sunico, 1986; pianist Cecile Licad, 1987; international performer Lea Salonga and singer-composer Joey Ayala, both in 1991; alternative music performer Grace Nono, 1994; pianist Jovianney Emmanuel Cruz, 1996; composer Josefino “Chino” Toledo, 1997; composer Jeffrey Ching, 1998; liturgical music composer Fr Manoling Francisco, SJ, 1999; violinist Alfonso “Coke” Bolipata, 2000; singer Gary Valenciano, 2001; flutist Antonio Maigue, 2002; singer Rachelle Gerodias, 2010; and conductor Gerard Joseph Salonga and Allan “apl.de.ap” Pineda Jr, both in 2012.

article.value: Local governments all over the country confer awards on distinguished “sons” or “daughters” who have excelled in music. One such award is the Parangal sa mga Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan given every year for almost three decades on Manila’s Founding Day, 24 Jun. The local government of Manila has conferred the Diwa ng Lahi Award to Atang de la Rama, 1974; Jovita Fuentes, 1975; Lucrecia R. Kasilag, 1984; Felipe Padilla de Leon, 1992; and Andrea O. Veneracion, 2002. It has also given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award to Isang C. Tapales, 1977; UP Madrigal Singers, 1980; and Mercedes Matias Santiago, 1982; and the Musika Award to Leon Ignacio, 1963; Nicanor S. Abelardo and Lucrecia R. Kasilag, both in 1964; Ladislao Bonus, 1966; Julio Nakpil, 1967; Francisco Santiago, 1968; Marcelo Adonay and Antonio J. Molina, both in 1969; Antonino Buenaventura and Jose Estella, both in 1970; Felipe Padilla de Leon and Juan S. Hernandez, both in 1971; Oscar Yatco, 1972; Regalado Jose, 1973; Eliseo M. Pajaro, 1974; Victor Toledo and Aurelio Estanislao, both in 1975; Laureano G. Cariño and Luis C. Valencia, both in 1976; Corazon Maceda, 1978; Gilopez Kabayao, 1979; Vicente M. Sales, 1981; Francisco F. Feliciano and Levi Celerio, both in 1983; Juan Silos Jr and Lucio D. San Pedro, both in 1984; Alfredo S. Buenaventura, 1985; Sergio Z. Esmilla, 1988; Josefino Cenizal, 1989; Ramon P. Santos, 1991; Basilio C. Manalo, 1992; Cecile Licad, 1993; Raul Sunico, 1998; Ryan Cayabyab, 2001; Herminigildo Ranera, 2006; and The CompanY, 2015.

Since 1977, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) has recognized outstanding artists. Among the awardees in music are the following: baritone Aurelio Estanislao, 1978; conductor-violinist Luis Valencia, 1982; pianist-teacher Rosario A. Picazo, 1983; mezzo-soprano Conchita Gaston Holmes, 1984; and composer Mike Velarde Jr, 1986. Since 1989, when it was instituted as the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, awardees have received medals of recognition designed by National Artist Napoleon V. Abueva, citation scrolls, and 10,000-peso gift cheques. Awardees in music are ethnomusicologist Jose Maceda, 1989; choral master Andrea Veneracion, 1990; kulintang player Amal Lumuntod and lyricist-violinist-composer Levi Celerio, both in 1991; epic chanter Elena Gardoce and composer-conductor Ramon Tapales, both in 1992; soprano Dalisay Aldaba, 1993; international concert pianist Cecile Licad, 1994; pianist Nena del Rosario, 1997, in which year the National Music Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA) was also given the Tanging Parangal (Distinguished Award); composer Ryan Cayabyab, 2004; outreach concert artists Gilopez and Corazon Kabayao, 2008; composer Ramon P. Santos, 2012; and soprano Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, 2015.

article.value: The National Artist Award, established under Presidential Proclamation No. 1001 on 27 Apr 1972 to honor Filipinos who have made outstanding contributions to Philippine arts and letters, replaced the Republic Cultural Heritage Award. It was later amended through Presidential Proclamation No. 1144 issued on 15 May 1973, creating a National Artists Award Committee to administer the conferment of the honor. It is now the highest and most prestigious award that the government gives to musicians and other artists. The following have been named National Artists for Music: Antonio J. Molina, 1973, who “pioneered in transmuting native melodies and rhythms into musical compositions of great originality and force”; Jovita Fuentes, 1976, for “her mastery of the noblest musical instrument, the voice, which continues to inspire and invigorate the musical development of the country”; Honorata “Atang” de la Rama, 1987, for “her sincere devotion to original theater and music, her outstanding artistry as singer and as sarsuwela actor-playwright-producer,” and for “her tireless efforts to bring her art to all regions and sectors of Filipino society and to the world”; Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988, for keeping “the nationalist tradition alive in his works by espousing the great possibilities of our indigenous music tradition in creating a distinct Philippine sound”; Lucrecia R. Kasilag, 1990, “[whose] devotion to her art … has added important new dimensions to our musical traditions, earning the respect and admiration of many”; Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991, for “his musical philosophy of ‘creative nationalism’ [which] entails an imaginative and emotional interaction between the artist and his culture”; Felipe Padilla de Leon, 1997, for having “achieved a keen understanding and oneness with the soul of his people such that his music breathes its very essence”; Levi Celerio, 1997, for being a “poet for the man-on-the-street who easily relates to him and his works, a true artist of the people … reaching out to the ordinary Filipino”; Jose Maceda, 1997, for having “dedicated his life towards the promotion of a national cultural identity, initiating and inspiring the scholarly study of the music and culture of the Filipino minority groups”; Ernani Cuenco, 1999, who believed that “music unheard was as good as music not created at all”; Andrea O. Veneracion, 1999, for having “consistently kept the Philippine Madrigal Singers’ hallmark of excellence, and for establishing a tradition of fine choral singing in the Philippines”; Francisco Feliciano, 2014, for having “brought the wealth of indigenous Philippine culture to the musical stages of the world”; Ramon P. Santos, 2014, whose body of works highlight the “people-specific concepts central to the ethnomusicological discipline, the translation of indigenous musical systems into modern musical discourse, and the marriage of Western and non-Western sound”; and Ryan Cayabyab, 2018,

In support of National Artists, Presidential Decree No. 208, effected on 7 Jun 1973, granted them further privileges and honors: a 10,000-peso gift cheque; a monthly life pension of 2,000 pesos; medical and hospitalization benefits; lifetime insurance of 50,000 pesos; a place of honor at state functions, national commemoration ceremonies, and all other cultural presentations; and a state funeral. National Artists are recommended by the Board of Trustees of the CCP, and since 1989, also by the Presidential (now National) Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and declared by the President. In 2003, EO No. 236 was signed which established the honors code of the Philippines to create an order of precedence of honors conferred and for other purposes. By virtue of this EO, the National Artist Award became the Orden ng mga Pambansang Alagad ng Sining (Order of National Artists), with revised privileges and honors. The cash award was increased to 100,000 for living awardees and 75,000 for posthumous awardees; so, too, the monthly life pension and medical and hospitalization benefits. Life insurance coverage was given to awardees who were still insurable. Also sustained were arrangements and expenses for a state funeral and burial at the Libingan ng mga Bayani (Cemetery of Heroes); a place of honor, in line with protocol, at national state functions, and acknowledgment at cultural events.

article.value: Another award that recognizes the contribution of Filipino artists is the Ani ng Dangal, given by the NCCA annually since 2009. Unlike the other awards which focus on individual achievements through many years of artistic productivity, this covers distinctions earned by artists in all art forms on a per year basis in international competitions. Some of the Filipino musicians given the Ani ng Dangal award are Nilo Alcala, 2009; University of the East Chorale, 2009; UP Singing Ambassadors, 2009 and 2013; Novo Concertante Manila, 2009, 2010, 2013, and 2015; Cebu Chamber Singers, 2009 and 2012; Hail Mary the Queen Children’s Choir, 2009 and 2014; Beverly Shangkuan, 2010; Ritchie Asibal, 2010; Teresa Barrozo, 2010; University of the Visayas Chorale, 2010; University of Santo Tomas Singers, 2010 and 2011; AUP Singing Ambassadors, 2012; Imusicapella, 2012 and 2013; Tristan Ignacio, 2012; Edgardo Manguiat, 2013; Joseleo Logdat, 2013; Arwin Tan, 2013; De La Salle University Chorale, 2014; Aleron, 2015; Saint Louis University Glee Club, 2015; and Alvin Paulin, 2015.

Awards have also been given solely in the field of popular music. In 1977, the Popular Music Foundation was organized to promote contemporary compositions and develop Filipino amateur and professional composers and songwriters. In 1982, the Foundation initiated the first music industry awards known as the Cecil Awards. Named after Cecil Lloyd, the “Filipino Mystery Singer,” it was launched the same year to honor the country’s best recording artists, encourage musicians, and raise artistic standards in the music industry. Some of the artists who received the Cecil Award were singers Nonoy Zuñiga, Kuh Ledesma, and Freddie Aguilar, and composers Willy Cruz and George Canseco. Some quarters, however, criticized the awards for favoring the big Manila-based recording companies. In 1986, the Cecil Awards bowed out from the Philippine music scene.

The Awit Awards started in 1969 but ended in 1971. It came out of hiatus when the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI) revived it in 1988, aided by the Samahan sa Musika (SAMAKA). Since then, PARI has been responsible for the said award. It carries the same objectives as the Cecil Awards. The wide and varying range of categories include awards given to solo or group performers, composers, arrangers, record producers, audio engineers, music pioneers, and even a significant record or album. Among the many awardees are Gary Valenciano, Rachel Alejandro, Jose Mari Chan, APO Hiking Society, Smokey Mountain, Ryan Cayabyab, Nonoy Zuñiga, Joey Albert, Pilita Corrales, The CompanY, Side A Band, Freestyle, South Border, Gary Valenciano, Martin Nieverra, Rannie Raymundo, Ogie Alcasid, Rico Blanco, Noel Cabangon, Aiza Seguerra, Dessa, Grace Nono, Jaya, Karylle, Kyla, Sitti, and L.A. Lopez.

The Aliw Awards, started in 1975 by the National Press Club and later run by the Aliw Foundation, is given annually to upgrade the quality of live entertainment. There are two general categories of winners: the musical category, which includes group or individual artists and/or performances of serious or popular music, and the nonmusical category, which includes group or individual artists and/or performances in theater and television. Among the many musical artists who have won the Aliw are singers Pilita Corrales, Rico J. Puno, Celeste Legaspi, Basil Valdez, Kuh Ledesma, Freddie Aguilar, Pops Fernandez, Leo Valdez, Martin Nievera, Bert Nievera, Vernie Varga, Gary Valenciano, Zsa Zsa Padilla, Marco Sison, and Sharon Cuneta; group performers Kundirana, Madrigal Singers, Tux, Family Birth Control Band, Bong Peñera Jazz Band, Emil Mijares Jazz Band, Tribung Pinoy, and the Manila Peninsula Strings; instrumentalists Eddie Katindig and Joselito Pascual; and composers Homer Flores, Ryan Cayabyab, and Louie Ocampo. Ingrid Sala-Santamaria was conferred the Lifetime Achievement Award in 2008. Among its roster of awards, the Entertainer of the Year award is the most sought-after. Most recent recipients are Regine Velasquez in 2009, Sarah Geronimo in 2010, and Charice Pempengco in 2011.

Katha Music Awards ranks among the most coveted awards for songwriters and popular music performers as these are given based on exceptional achievement either as composer or performer, and not based on popularity or marketability. The first Katha Awards were given out in 1995. Some of the exceptional artists who have won this award are South Border, Jungee Marcelo, Radha Cuadrado, Jonathan Manalo, Gloc-9, Grace Nono, and Eraserheads.

The NU Rock Awards recognized hard work and artistry specifically among rock artists. These were given yearly from 1994 to 2010. It was sponsored by the now-defunct radio station NU 107. Among the rock artists who were honored by the NU Rock Awards were the bands Afterimage, Eraserheads, Wolfgang, Parokya ni Edgar, Slapshock, Bamboo, Orange and Lemons, Kamikazee, Pupil, Up Dharma Down, Franco, Alamid, and Put3ska.

Beginning 2008, the National Book Development Board (NBDB) and the Manila Critics Circle (MCC) have given the National Book Award to recognize the contribution to scholarship of writers and musicologists who have published outstanding researches on Philippine music and culture. This award was established by the MCC in 1982. Among the books which have been awarded are Jose Maceda’s Gongs and Bamboo: A Panorama of Philippine Musical Instruments, 1998; Marjorie Evasco’s biography on Andrea Veneracion, A Life Shaped by Music, 2001; Richie Quirino’s Pinoy Jazz Traditions, 2004; Ramon Santos’s Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music and Manolete Mora’s Myth, Mimesis and Magic in the Music of the T’boli, Philippines, both in 2006; and Raul Navarro’s Kolonyal na Patakaran at ang Nagbabagong Kamalayang Filipino: Musika sa Publikong Paaralan sa Pilipinas 1898-1935, 2008.

In 2010, MYX, the music channel owned by ABS-CBN, began to give out awards to local music artists and music videos based on votes garnered from viewers and followers. Among the winners of the 2010 MYX Music Awards are Sarah Geronimo (Favorite Female Artist), Rico Blanco (Favorite Male Artist), Sponge Cola (Favorite Group), “Kasalanan” by 6cyclemind and Gloc-9 (Favorite Music Video), and “Back in Time” by Kyla and Jay-R (Favorite Song). Also for that year, Jose Mari Chan received the MYX Magna Award, a special recognition given to Filipino music stalwarts. Other MYX Magna Awardees are Regine Velasquez, 2011; Ryan Cayabyab, 2012; Lea Salonga, 2013; Parokya ni Edgar, 2014; Rey Valera, 2015; and Ogie Alcasid, 2016.

Grants and Commissions. RA 1370 effected on 18 Jun 1955 created the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP). In 1961, RA 3042 allotted 400,000 pesos annually to MPFP and to cultural groups studying and disseminating Filipino folk arts, music, and dances abroad. The MPFP helped leading composers to produce new works in various forms, including chamber works, operas, sarsuwela, concertos, and symphonic and band works. From 1959 to 1972, the MPFP commissioned a total of 19 compositions. It also gave out 76 student scholarship grants from 1957 to 1965.

The League of Filipino Composers (LFC), also founded in 1955, presented new works at annual festivals with help from MPFP subsidies. Later on, the CCP, inaugurated in 1969, co-sponsored the annual festivals and continues to commission works. The LFC has presented more than 160 commissioned works.

Aside from the awards it annually confers on leading Filipino musical artists, the CCP has also provided tour grants to the following musicians: Ramon P. Santos, Felicidad Prudente, and Kristina Benitez, all in 1989, Jose Maceda in 1990, and the UP Singing Ambassadors and Joey Ayala at Ang Bagong Lumad, both in 1991. Since its restoration in 1978 until its untimely closure in 1990, the Metropolitan Theater has actively commissioned both classical and popular composers to write sarsuwela, musicals, and other works.

Private musical organizations such as the Manila Symphony Orchestra, institutions such as schools, banks, and corporations, and private individuals have engaged many a composer to create symphonic works, marches, hymns, songs, choral works, musicals, and even commercial jingles. NCCA, through its Grants Program, has funded many projects which highlight the contributions of culture to national growth and development. It aids in identifying programs and projects that focus on the positive impacts of culture and arts to the life of men and women, most especially the vulnerable and marginalized sectors in the various regions of the country. Since its inception, NCCA has provided venues for the different regions to articulate their local culture and development concerns. Among its recipients are the Pasinaya Performing Arts Market at the CCP; the International Las Piñas Bamboo Organ Festival; the Pasasalamat Festival of Pagadian; Konsiyerto ng Pangalay, Tula, Salinawit at Musika; Teduray Dance and Gong Playing; School of Living Traditions on Maguindanao Kulintang-Playing of Barangay Lower Campo Islam, Labangan, Zamboanga del Sur; Taal Tunugan: Philippine Musical and Vocal Forms in Vernacular; and Kuwerdas ng Pagkakaisa (Strings of Unity) Rondalla Festival.

Music Contests. The European classical art music idiom, traditionally, has relied heavily on the institution of music competitions to provide a forum for recognizing the most outstanding instrumentalists, vocalists, composers, orchestras, and small ensembles, thereby contributing significantly to the establishment of these artists’ careers. Classical instrumental ensembles such as brass bands, school bands and choirs, and church and community choirs have also long relied on competitions and festivals to promote their groups and showcase high levels of artistry. In recent decades, various competitions have also arisen in the field of popular music.

During the Spanish colonial period, formal music contests in the field of art music were first sponsored by private artistic and musical societies and by religious groups. These groups celebrated the feast of Saint Cecilia, Patroness of Music, with concerts and contests. The Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario held one such contest in 1879, where noted cellist-pianist Antonio Garcia won second prize. During the American period, new schools and societies continued the institution of music competitions. With the establishment of the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1908 came the competition for composing its hymn which Nicanor S. Abelardo, then a student at the UP Conservatory of Music, won in 1917. Escuelas Confederadas de Musica was a private school in Quiapo composed of three departments: the Schola Cantorum under Victorino Carrion, the Escuela de Piano under Vicente Marifosqui, and the Escuela de Violin under Bonifacio Abdon. These departments held their respective contests, with the Schola Cantorum even sponsoring in 1933 an essay-writing contest on music open to its graduates and students. Private individuals also sponsored music contests. The distinguished composer of sacred music, Marcelo Adonay, sponsored a competition for the best wedding march on the occasion of his golden wedding anniversary in 1924. Abelardo won the 100,000-peso grand prize, and his work was played during the event.

The Japanese interregnum, 1941-45, saw a proliferation of music contests custom-made by the Japanese government to promote their own agenda. There was much music-making but the aim was to move away from the supposedly excessive, materialistic, and degenerating influence of American culture. Music contests were thus held with the goal of re-orienting or re-aligning Filipino culture towards becoming a worthy member of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. Some of these contests were the Pilipino Farmers Song Contest, the March and Kundiman Contest, the Philippine Band Contest, and the Music Concourse, Literary and Song-Writing Competition of the Manila Shimbunsha, the umbrella newspaper company during this period. Among the prize-winning compositions were “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Pilipinas” (Song for the Creation of a New Philippines), which temporarily replaced the National Anthem, music by Felipe Padilla de Leon, lyrics by first prize winner Catalino Dionisio; “Awit ng Mga Magsasaka” (Song of the Farmers), music by F. P. de Leon, lyrics by Simplicio Talens; and “President Laurel March,” music by Lucio San Pedro, lyrics by Jacinto de Leon. Other composers who won various awards for their compositions were Leon Ignacio, Hilarion Rubio, Francisco Buencamino, Lucino Sacramento, and Nemesio Regalado. To encourage excellence in band music, awards were given under the auspices of the Philippine Band Association in 1943. The Muling Pagsikat Band under Rafael Batugal won the top prize.

Postwar Philippines saw a new phase in the life of the nation’s music contests as artists grappled with nation building in their music. Foremost among the music competitions was the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA), established in 1973, which sparked nationwide contests that nurtured the country’s young talents in various categories—piano, voice, choral music, solo, family ensemble, traditional music, and commissioned contest pieces. Created by Proclamation No. 1173, NAMCYA designated a National Music Week in November, with the CCP and the Department of Education as its prime collaborating arms.

In 2009, the CCP staged the 1st Philippine International Choral Competition, which took place from 18 to 22 Aug. The festival was part of its 40th anniversary celebration, and it brought choirs from different parts of the Philippines to compete in four categories: Children’s Choir, Mixed Choir, Sacred Music, and Folk Music. Not long after, the Andrea O. Veneracion International Choral Festival 2013 was launched to celebrate the 50th founding anniversary of the Philippine Madrigal Singers, the choir that Veneracion, a National Artist, nurtured to become the world-class ensemble that it is today. It was held from 7-10 Aug, a month after the passing of Veneracion. A total of five foreign choirs from Indonesia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, and Thailand, and 14 Filipino choirs competed in three categories. The second edition of this international choral competition was held from 22-25 Jul 2015.

Many other choral competitions have been held, and among those which have lasted through the years include Voices in Harmony, a competition for high school choirs organized by the Children’s Museum and Library, Inc (CMLI) which began in 1999; the annual Musikahan sa Tagum, sponsored by the city government of Tagum and the City of Tagum Tourism Office since 1999, which includes competitions for choirs, band, singing, and rondalla; the MBC Choral Competition, organized by the Manila Broadcasting Company since 2007; Musica FEUROPA, the only European Union-sponsored choral competition in the Philippines, hosted by the Far Eastern University since 2009; and the annual Government Choral Competition, a Civil Service Commission-sponsored competition for choirs of government agencies which held its first edition in 2011.

Another festival held regularly at the CCP is the International Guitar Festival and Competition. It began in 2010, organized by Guitar Friends, a group of Filipino guitar aficionados, and the CCP. In its 2011 competition, Filipino guitarist Ramoncito Carpio won the first prize.

Aside from the CCP-initiated festivals, there is the Kundiman Fiesta sponsored by Hotel Nikko Manila Garden in Makati which began in 1991. The goal of the festival was to revive the singing of the Filipino kundiman and propagate this singing tradition among the youth. The first five years were financed by the hotel management and produced the following top kundiman singers: Francisco Batomalaque, 1991; Alexis Sumicat, 1992; Nolito Gregorio, 1993; Joel Saavedra, 1994; and Cherry Batalla, 1995. When the ownership of Hotel Nikko changed in 1996, the annual Kundiman Fiesta faced an uncertain fate. The NCCA eventually took over, and the 1996 edition was held on 4 Dec at the Folk Arts Theater, with Marya Deeda Barreto as the winner. The Makati Coliseum and Cultural Affairs Office started another kundiman singing competition in 1995 to celebrate “Buwan ng Wika” (Language Month) in Makati City. The competition was aptly called “Kampeon ng Kundiman” and was later on renamed “Kundiman sa Makati.” It has been held annually ever since.

A contest of semiclassical tradition was the Yamaha Electone Festival (YEF) held from 1972 to the late 1990s, which showcased the capability of the electronic organ to replicate the sound of an entire orchestra, traditional instrumental ensemble, or popular bands. Aside from original compositions for the Electone, the festival required the participants to display their arrangements and improvisational skills during the competition. The festival’s national champion represented the country in the Southeast Asian regional competition, and those who won in the regional contest advanced to the International Electone Concours, which was always held in Japan. Many YEF winners have become prominent contributors to the country’s music industry such as Francisco “Toti” Fuentes, Maritess Salientes, Carolyn Kleiner-Cheng, Louie Ocampo, Rowena Arietta, Maria Corazon “Maricor” Perez, Norman Agatep, Jesse Lucas, Marvin Queirdo, Pipo Cifra, Rica Arambulo, Noel Arce, Charisse Baldoria, Khavn de la Cruz, Arwin Tan, Dennis Sugarol, and Jude Roldan.

Contests in the field of popular music have been led by the Metro Manila Popular Music Festival (Metropop) established in 1978 under the auspices of the Popular Music Foundation and led by Imee Marcos and Teodoro Valencia. The most prestigious pop music contest of its time, it came at a period when national pride in music was ardently felt, thus inspiring the growth of Original Pilipino Music (OPM). Winners included Ryan Cayabyab for “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful Is Our Music), Freddie Aguilar for “Anak” (Child) and “Bulag, Pipi at Bingi” (Blind, Mute, and Deaf), Louie Ocampo and Rowena Arrieta for “Ewan” (I Don’t Know), Odette Quesada for “Give Me a Chance” and “Till I Met You,” Nonong Pedero for “Narito Ako” (Here I Am) and “Isang Mundo, Isang Awit” (One World, One Song), George Canseco for “Ako ang Nagwagi, Ako ang Nasawi” (I Won, I Lost), Ananias Montano for “Babae Ka” (You’re a Girl), Gines Tan for “Magsimula Ka” (Make a Start), and Gary Granada for “Salamat, Salamat Musika” (Thanks, Music). Although it launched the careers of many aspiring songwriters and produced an avalanche of OPM, the Metropop lasted only until 1985 as the end of the Marcos regime neared. It was revived in 1996 as the Metropop Song Fest, which lasted until 2003.

Launched on 15 Feb 2012 was the Philippine Pop Music Festival (PhilPop) Songwriting Competition which aimed to encourage Filipinos to create music that could become classic hits. The competition is organized and sponsored by a group of companies owned by business tycoon Manuel V. Pangilinan. The first grand prize winner was Karl Villuga with his song “Bawat Hakbang” (Every Step), interpreted in the 2012 festival by Mark Bautista and the Akafellas. In its 2013 edition, the top winners were Thyro Alfaro and Yumi Lacsamana with their song “Dati” (Before), interpreted by Tippy Dos Santos and Sam Concepcion. In 2014, the grand prizewinner was veteran Jungee Marcelo with his song “Salbabida” (Lifesaver), interpreted by Kyla.

Recent music competitions include the Kapisanan ng Mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP) Pop Music Festival in 2010 which uniquely took place over the airwaves and aimed to generate new Filipino songs; the Philippine Popular Music Festival in 2012 which aired over TV5, and whose entries won by number of text votes; and the Manila Broadcasting Company’s choral contests, held under the auspices of the largest radio network in Asia, which draws school ensembles from all over the country. A music contest with the goal of giving thanks and praise to God is the ASOP (A Song of Praise Music Festival), which receives song entries from the Philippines and overseas, is streamed live on www.untvweb.com, and is covered internationally by UNTV 37.

ABS-CBN Corporation and its music subsidiary, Star Music, have their own songwriting and music video competition known as Himig Handog. The contest initially ran from 2000 to 2003 and had varying themes in each year. It was discontinued after 2003 but was revived in 2013 as Himig Handog Pinoy Pop Love Songs, with romantic love as the primary theme of all song-entries. The grand winner of the 2013 competition was Jovinor Tan and his song “Anong Nangyari Sa Ating Dalawa?” as interpreted by Aiza Seguerra. Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Ma. Patricia B. Silvestre and Arwin Q. Tan
