text:
Composition, from the Latin componere meaning “to collect, put, place together,” refers to both the creative process of producing music and the musical product. Composition more specifically signifies the creative activity and the created work or opus in the context of art music in the European tradition, with reference to the notated score and its realization and interpretation by performers. Arnold Schoenberg, a leading Austrian composer of the 20th century, cites the different stages involved in the process of composing: the basic idea or grundgestalt, which comes from an extramusical source such as an emotion, a story, an image; the translation of the grundgestalt into a basic musical material or grundreihe, involving the appropriate scale and mode; the creation of the motif or theme; and the development of the theme into a musical form. In general, this limited concept of composition precludes the idea of improvisation and implies the total authority and absolute control of the composer through the written score.

 

A wider view of composition, however, considers the almost unlimited variety of ways of composing, not only in the modern tradition dominant in 20th-century Western art music but also in the countless musical traditions outside the Western hemisphere. In orally transmitted cultures where the term “music” or the idea of composer as author and writer does not exist, the compositional process may be manifested in the following ways: the innovation on the musical elements of an actual performance; the extemporized creation of the text on a preexisting tune; the invention of additional episodes or development of plots in epics and other narrative forms; the musical utterances and physical movements in ritualistic trance; the learning, as among the Blackfoot Indians, of a new song through dream; and the transcription and stylization of traditional melodies.

In some Asian classical traditions, such as the raga and tala of the Hindustani and Carnatic music of India, and the Persian radif and the Arabic maqam, composition occurs as improvisation of existing modal melodies and rhythmic patterns during the performance of the music. In Javanese classical music, basic melodies or themes called balungan are composed according to the six modes of the two-scale systems of pelog and slendro, and using any of the 19 compositional formats or ghending. These melodies are then realized in the semi-improvised playing technique of the gamelan or gong-chime orchestra. In Thai music, melodies are composed, incorporating both traditional themes as well as structural elements from foreign music (e.g., Khmer, Lao, Chinese). These are then realized by means of variant techniques by standard performing ensembles such as piphad, mohori, and khruang sai. In modern China, composition also means the transcription and scoring of collected tunes from tribal music repertoires for various types of instrumental ensembles.

The traditional differs greatly from the modern concept of composition. In the traditional, the element of improvisation and extemporization is a major part of the creative process; there is little distinction between composer and performer; innovations and inventions are based on preexisting materials and rules of style; moreover, the spirit world may also be directly involved in the compositional act.

In unwritten vocal genres, composition is the creation of the text on preexisting melodic formulae which, together with the stylistic elements in their musical rendition usually determine the genres, as in the oggayam or the welcome song of the Kalinga. Other genres are specific to social activities such as the Tagalog huluna (lullaby), and the Bontok sowe-ey (agricultural song). There are also musical forms that are related to important events such as weddings, peace pacts, and rituals. Epics and ballads are rendered only by elders who are regarded to have greater artistic character and philosophical depth than ordinary members of the community.

A piece may sometimes be “titled” or identified either by its composer or by its thematic content, as in the case of the Ibaloy ba-diw, a poetic musical form sung on various occasions, from small gatherings to big celebrations. E.L. Pungayan classifies ba-diw into five categories: batbat or pinchitan ba-diw, for big feasts; kapi ba-diw, for thanksgiving rites and good fortune; pinatjan ba-diw, for death wakes; ngilin ba-diw, for weddings; and adadkos ba-diw for entertainment and storytelling. The ba-diw is sung in leader-chorus style. The man-badiw (elderly male), is the leader-composer-poet, and the asbayat (a chorus of women) echoes each line that is half-recited by the man-badiw. A ba-diw composer must be skilled not only in reciting extempore seven-syllable-line poetry on a specific theme but also in developing his own imagery, metaphorical language, and different ways of incorporating Ibaloy values related to the spirit world, material wealth, cultural identity, creativity, and sense of humor. These skills are acquired by listening to and memorizing individual phrases or entire pieces as sung by experts. Selected ba-diw are remembered either through the authors, such as “Ba-diw ni Dasolas” (Ba-diw of Dasolas) and “Ba-diw ni Bab’an Berong” (Ba-diw of Bab’an Berong), with cross-reference to the occasions when they were heard; or through specific categories, as in “Ba-diw ni Abiteg” (The Poor Man’s Bad-iw), with cross-reference, too, to the authors and/or occasions.

The process of creating other vocal forms, such as the Maranao bayok, involves not only composing a text extemporaneously but also putting together various vocal style formulae such as ringkaran or vocal ornaments, to support the text. The bayok is a hyperbolic panegyric composition. A good pabubayok (bayok singer) must be able to manipulate the different formulae skillfully, and to sing about any topic employing proverbs, adages, and puns, among others.

Vocal genres from other cultural groups in the Philippines also possess extemporized text on melodic and stylistic formulae. The genres include the Palawan kulilal, the Subanon sinaleg and palagi, the Ilocano dal-lot, the Tagalog pandangguhan, the Cebuano balitaw, the Tiruray siyasid and seringan, the Aeta awa-idi, and the Bikol composo.

In the indigenous instrumental repertoires, the integration of artistic creation and performance is also the fundamental process of music composition, consisting mainly of improvising preexisting structural elements (melodic and rhythmic modes) and musical forms. Since many of the instrumental forms are as open-ended as the occasions and social events that they enhance or the specific activities of which they are an integral part, the limits of the creative act can be indefinite in duration and substance. The improvisation may take the form of ornamentation, repetition, variations, and permutations of the thematic, rhythmic, and tonal (timbre) elements.

The musical forms suggest the possible manners of improvisation. The Yakan kuriri, for example, is a continuous series of three- to four-note motifs representing different shades of emotions and feelings. Changes and permutations are made in the rhythmic patterns and note sequences without deviating from a basic pulse, especially in solo instrumental music.

In Maguindanaon kulintangan music, the formal element may be based on a series of phrases as well as rhythmic formulae, like the duyug, sinulug, tidtu, binalig, and/or on existing songs like “Mamayug” and “Layas sa Ulan.” The phrases are repeated and modified any number of times at the discretion of the kulintang player who cues the other members of the ensemble especially in the opening and closing sequences. In other ensemble music such as the Kalinga gangsa palook and Tiruray agung, only one or two members improvise, while the others play constant patterns which provide the drone element. In pre-Christian ensemble music, one gong is usually the drone such as the babandir in the Maguindanaon and Maranao kulintangan, the patawaganan in the tagunggo of the Kalagan, and the bandilan of the Manobo hanging kulintang.

Pre-Western concepts of composition were gradually replaced by changes in the melodies themselves to accommodate novel elements from Western music such as harmony, counterpoint, chordal accompaniment, and dance rhythms. These musical changes are evident in the various vocal music of rural Christian cultures such as the Tagalog awit, kumintang, and pandanggo, and the Visayan composo and balitaw. The next stage of folk song evolution is represented by the actual composition of new melodies for individual texts as seen in “Kundiman de 1800” (Kundiman of 1800) or the highly stylized reconstruction of traditional musical forms according to Western harmonic idioms. Many of Philippine Westernized folk songs are in either major or minor modes and cast in three-beat patterns as influenced by the valse, pandanggo, and jota rhythms, or in the two-beat patterns of the danza or the habanera.

The variable-text concept of composition appears to be the norm not only in folk songs and folk epics but also in literary-musical genres such as the metrical romances called awit and korido, and the komedya in which the composed music for standard parts (dances and battle scenes) can be interchanged between different works. It is quite evident that in these forms, the music is incidental to the literary content. The same is true for other dramatic forms. There is a greater collaboration between the dramatist-playwright and the music composer in producing songs which in some instances can stand on their own artistic merit outside the drama itself. It is not uncommon to insert in a particular sarsuwela production songs originally composed for other sarsuwela, especially if these songs were written by the same composer.

Although popular music writing usually follows the Western compositional concept involving the composer, the written score, and the performer, some works, especially those that belong to the folk ballad category, are composed and performed by the same person, such as the songs of Florante, Freddie Aguilar, and Heber Bartolome. The folk ballad type is usually set in simple tunes in strophic form. Because of its semi-narrative, semi-declarative character, its literary-poetic content, more often than not, carries greater artistic value than the music itself. Thus, this type of folk music is widely used as a medium of protest and serious political statements. Some folk ballad composers such as Joey Ayala, Grace Nono, and Edru Abraham integrate indigenous music in their works. In many of the comic-didactic folk ballads of Yoyoy Villame, the music is less significant in that it is hardly original, as it is usually lifted from the popular dance music repertoire of the American colonial period.

A number of Filipino popular music composers who lack background in music notation employ arrangers. The use of tape recorders and other electronic devices for sound storage and preprogrammed music or minus one have also been put to good use by nonliterate pop music composers.

In recent years, the use of Philippine languages in popular music and the production of Filipino-composed tunes have given rise to OPM or original Pilipino music. Composition in Philippine art music, on the other hand, adopts the principles of the European art music tradition. The flowering of the Filipino composer produced classical art music works: masses, operas, symphonies, sonatas, concertos, chamber music, concert overtures and tone poems, song cycles, kundiman, art songs, preludes, and character pieces. Western compositional skills consist of a working knowledge of functional harmony, counterpoint, orchestration, other forms of choral and instrumental writing techniques, as well as stylistic devices relative to vocal and individual instrumental idioms. The principal composers identified with the art music literature which flourished in the late 19th and early 20th centuries are Ladislao Bonus, Marcelo Adonay, Nicanor S. Abelardo, Francisco Santiago, Antonio J. Molina, Juan S. Hernandez, Francisco Buencamino, Hilarion F. Rubio, Antonino Buenaventura, Lucio D. San Pedro, Eliseo M. Pajaro, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucino T. Sacramento, Alfredo S. Buenaventura, and Rosendo Santos. These composers utilize the forms mainly as a medium for expressing programmatic ideas based on Filipino themes and nationalist ideology as exemplified by the Taga-ilog Symphony, the Mayon Concerto, the symphonic poem Lahing Kayumanggi (Brown Race), the Daklahi Symphony, and the opera Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not). Structural motifs taken from folk songs are common source elements in these works. Purely abstract compositions without allusion to or quotation of Filipino materials are rare in Philippine classical music.

New compositional concepts and techniques which evolved in 20th-century Western art music were also selectively adopted and modified by Filipino composers. The proliferation of different stylistic idioms, such as impressionism, expressionism, neoclassicism, and the various streams of thought in the avant-garde movement from the 1950s to the 1970s further enriched the compositional base of Filipino creative artists.

The ambiguous tonal language of expressionist music was absorbed by Nicanor S. Abelardo in the latter part of his creative career, as can be heard in Sinfonietta and the Cinderella Overture, while the textural devices of the impressionists were adopted by Antonino Buenaventura and Antonio J. Molina. The neoclassicist idea of putting together old and new materials of music was espoused by Eliseo M. Pajaro, Rosendo Santos, Manuel P. Maramba, OSB, Angel M. Peña, and Lucrecia R. Kasilag. Kasilag expanded the neoclassic idiom by fusing non-Western music elements, specifically Asian tones and scales, with standard western melodic and harmonic structures. Other Filipino composers such as Alfredo S. Buenaventura and Jerry A. Dadap are more eclectic in their compositional perspective, relating the different musical idioms to different feelings and emotions. Thus, the application of particular styles of composition is based on programmatic and descriptive, rather than linguistic considerations.

The techniques of composition that developed out of the avant-garde movement also found a place in the works of Filipino composers. Composing with mass sound structures as those initiated by the French musique concrete movement serves as the basic formula for Jose Maceda’s sound murals, as in his Ugnayan (Coordination) and Udlot-Udlot (Fluctuation). Here, microstructural materials are taken from the sound repertoire of Philippine indigenous instruments such as gongs, mouth harp, bamboo zithers, scrapers, as well as vocal techniques like vocal slides and glottal stops. A similar approach to composition has been adopted by Jonas Baes whose works, like Basbasan (Blessing) and Yayeyunan (Melody), are inspired by both Maceda’s music and his own researches in Philippine indigenous music.

Improvisation, open forms, and graphic notation are elements of composition employed by Ramon P. Santos in his early works like Time Improvisation, Five Pieces for Two Pianos, Radyasyon (Radiation), and Nabasag ang Banga (The Jar Was Broken); Chino Toledo in his Samut-sari (Variety), Terminal Lamentation, and Baryasyon (Variation); and Kasilag in her Five Portraits and Ekologie I: On A Day Off.

Compositions based on non-Western structural elements such as hocket technique, rhythmic patterns, drones, and heterophony are seen in Ruben R. Federizon’s Ritmos Tabulare (Tabular Rhythm) and Tinig ng Lupa (Voice of the Earth); Verne dela Peña’s Nyuma and Panaghoy (Lamentation); Ramon P. Santos’s Abot-tanaw (Horizons) I, II, and III; Chino Toledo’s Trenodya ke Lean at sa Iba Pang Pinapaslang, Pinaslang at Papaslangin Dahil sa Dahilang Walang Kadahilanan (Threnody for Lean and Those Who Have Been Slain, Are Being Slain, and Will Be Slain for Reasons That Have No Reason) and Taghoy ng Kalikasan (Nature’s Lamentation); Francisco F. Feliciano’s Siya-Kuno (As If, also a play on the word “chaconne”); Arlene Chongson’s Lunduyan (Center); and Kristina Benitez’s works. Sound layers and a rich variety of sound textures that are generated from small nuclear cells are characteristic of the works of Francisco F. Feliciano in his Isostasie III, Die Verkläerung Christi, Fragments, Yerma, and the opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf); and Conrado del Rosario in his Chants. Moreover, Robin Estrada’s choral pieces such as Awit sa Panginoon (Song for God) resound chant elements and ritual-based structures.

The integration of various artistic elements (poetry, music, dance, visual design) has been realized in a number of multimedia works which have been composed in the spirit of artistic holism in traditional art forms. This repertoire continues to grow today, as seen in such works as Ramon P. Santos’s Siklo (Cycle), Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden) and Awit ni Pulau (Song of Pulau); Chino Toledo’s Dasalan at Toksohan (Praying and Teasing); and Verne dela Peña’s Urduja and Agueda. Interlocking rhythms usually found in the ensemble music of northern Philippines’ indigenous groups were employed in the urban soundscape piece of Maria Christine Muyco’s Ikotoki for Jeepney Orchestra, a multimedia piece involving instruments made from parts of the jeepney (the Philippine’s public vehicle), speech choir, dance, and actual jeepneys and their drivers participating in music making. On the other hand, Mary Katherine Trangco’s Elira comprises the use of choir, shadow dance, and gong instruments. In this piece, she shows her multitasking ability as performer, that is, conducting while chanting part of her piece.

There are participative and interactive pieces written that invoke deep sociopolitical consciousness among performers and audience such as Jonas Baes’s compositions. His InAyta involves issues on loss of ancestral land, and Lisan essays the Iraya Mangyan’s exodus as a result of land displacement, armed conflict, and other encroachments.

Collaborations of artists across countries result to fruitful endeavors such as Lily Anne Perez’s In Search of Kwan and Ocho Ocho (Barrionics), which she accomplished with artists from the Philippines and the United States. These pieces involve installations, theatre, dance, video, and computer music. In the same light, Dennis Reyes employs electronic technology in his compositions such as the Dance of the Monkey King and Bolgia, performed in series of Asian Composers League international festivals. Other works of Filipino composers using electro-acoustic and computer technology are uploaded in SoundCloud and other online websites for listening access. Electronic music compositions have been around not only in the academe but among experimental groups as well. Tad Ermitaño’s Deus Ex Machina and Tengal Drilon’s 30 Sounds in a Filing Cabinet are some of the pieces that involve interactive technology and media art. Ermitano has also worked with members of The Children of Cathode Ray, an experimental media group. This group has been performing his works, which in context, become his partners in recreating structures and ideas. Written by Ramon P. Santos, updated by Maria Christine Muyco

In many of the comic-didactic folk ballads of Yoyoy Villame, the music is less significant in that it is hardly original, as it is usually lifted from the popular dance music repertoire of the American colonial period.

A number of Filipino popular music composers who lack background in music notation employ arrangers. The use of tape recorders and other electronic devices for sound storage and preprogrammed music or minus one have also been put to good use by nonliterate pop music composers.

In recent years, the use of Philippine languages in popular music and the production of Filipino-composed tunes have given rise to OPM or original Pilipino music. Composition in Philippine art music, on the other hand, adopts the principles of the European art music tradition. The flowering of the Filipino composer produced classical art music works: masses, operas, symphonies, sonatas, concertos, chamber music, concert overtures and tone poems, song cycles, kundiman, art songs, preludes, and character pieces. Western compositional skills consist of a working knowledge of functional harmony, counterpoint, orchestration, other forms of choral and instrumental writing techniques, as well as stylistic devices relative to vocal and individual instrumental idioms. The principal composers identified with the art music literature which flourished in the late 19th and early 20th centuries are Ladislao Bonus, Marcelo Adonay, Nicanor S. Abelardo, Francisco Santiago, Antonio J. Molina, Juan S. Hernandez, Francisco Buencamino, Hilarion F. Rubio, Antonino Buenaventura, Lucio D. San Pedro, Eliseo M. Pajaro, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucino T. Sacramento, Alfredo S. Buenaventura, and Rosendo Santos. These composers utilize the forms mainly as a medium for expressing programmatic ideas based on Filipino themes and nationalist ideology as exemplified by the Taga-ilog Symphony, the Mayon Concerto, the symphonic poem Lahing Kayumanggi (Brown Race), the Daklahi Symphony, and the opera Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not). Structural motifs taken from folk songs are common source elements in these works. Purely abstract compositions without allusion to or quotation of Filipino materials are rare in Philippine classical music.

New compositional concepts and techniques which evolved in 20th-century Western art music were also selectively adopted and modified by Filipino composers. The proliferation of different stylistic idioms, such as impressionism, expressionism, neoclassicism, and the various streams of thought in the avant-garde movement from the 1950s to the 1970s further enriched the compositional base of Filipino creative artists.

The ambiguous tonal language of expressionist music was absorbed by Nicanor S. Abelardo in the latter part of his creative career, as can be heard in Sinfonietta and the Cinderella Overture, while the textural devices of the impressionists were adopted by Antonino Buenaventura and Antonio J. Molina. The neoclassicist idea of putting together old and new materials of music was espoused by Eliseo M. Pajaro, Rosendo Santos, Manuel P. Maramba, OSB, Angel M. Peña, and Lucrecia R. Kasilag. Kasilag expanded the neoclassic idiom by fusing non-Western music elements, specifically Asian tones and scales, with standard western melodic and harmonic structures. Other Filipino composers such as Alfredo S. Buenaventura and Jerry A. Dadap are more eclectic in their compositional perspective, relating the different musical idioms to different feelings and emotions. Thus, the application of particular styles of composition is based on programmatic and descriptive, rather than linguistic considerations.

The techniques of composition that developed out of the avant-garde movement also found a place in the works of Filipino composers. Composing with mass sound structures as those initiated by the French musique concrete movement serves as the basic formula for Jose Maceda’s sound murals, as in his Ugnayan (Coordination) and Udlot-Udlot (Fluctuation). Here, microstructural materials are taken from the sound repertoire of Philippine indigenous instruments such as gongs, mouth harp, bamboo zithers, scrapers, as well as vocal techniques like vocal slides and glottal stops. A similar approach to composition has been adopted by Jonas Baes whose works, like Basbasan (Blessing) and Yayeyunan (Melody), are inspired by both Maceda’s music and his own researches in Philippine indigenous music.

Improvisation, open forms, and graphic notation are elements of composition employed by Ramon P. Santos in his early works like Time Improvisation, Five Pieces for Two Pianos, Radyasyon (Radiation), and Nabasag ang Banga (The Jar Was Broken); Chino Toledo in his Samut-sari (Variety), Terminal Lamentation, and Baryasyon (Variation); and Kasilag in her Five Portraits and Ekologie I: On A Day Off.

Compositions based on non-Western structural elements such as hocket technique, rhythmic patterns, drones, and heterophony are seen in Ruben R. Federizon’s Ritmos Tabulare (Tabular Rhythm) and Tinig ng Lupa (Voice of the Earth); Verne dela Peña’s Nyuma and Panaghoy (Lamentation); Ramon P. Santos’s Abot-tanaw (Horizons) I, II, and III; Chino Toledo’s Trenodya ke Lean at sa Iba Pang Pinapaslang, Pinaslang at Papaslangin Dahil sa Dahilang Walang Kadahilanan (Threnody for Lean and Those Who Have Been Slain, Are Being Slain, and Will Be Slain for Reasons That Have No Reason) and Taghoy ng Kalikasan (Nature’s Lamentation); Francisco F. Feliciano’s Siya-Kuno (As If, also a play on the word “chaconne”); Arlene Chongson’s Lunduyan (Center); and Kristina Benitez’s works. Sound layers and a rich variety of sound textures that are generated from small nuclear cells are characteristic of the works of Francisco F. Feliciano in his Isostasie III, Die Verkläerung Christi, Fragments, Yerma, and the opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf); and Conrado del Rosario in his Chants. Moreover, Robin Estrada’s choral pieces such as Awit sa Panginoon (Song for God) resound chant elements and ritual-based structures.

The integration of various artistic elements (poetry, music, dance, visual design) has been realized in a number of multimedia works which have been composed in the spirit of artistic holism in traditional art forms. This repertoire continues to grow today, as seen in such works as Ramon P. Santos’s Siklo (Cycle), Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden) and Awit ni Pulau (Song of Pulau); Chino Toledo’s Dasalan at Toksohan (Praying and Teasing); and Verne dela Peña’s Urduja and Agueda. Interlocking rhythms usually found in the ensemble music of northern Philippines’ indigenous groups were employed in the urban soundscape piece of Maria Christine Muyco’s Ikotoki for Jeepney Orchestra, a multimedia piece involving instruments made from parts of the jeepney (the Philippine’s public vehicle), speech choir, dance, and actual jeepneys and their drivers participating in music making. On the other hand, Mary Katherine Trangco’s Elira comprises the use of choir, shadow dance, and gong instruments. In this piece, she shows her multitasking ability as performer, that is, conducting while chanting part of her piece.

There are participative and interactive pieces written that invoke deep sociopolitical consciousness among performers and audience such as Jonas Baes’s compositions. His InAyta involves issues on loss of ancestral land, and Lisan essays the Iraya Mangyan’s exodus as a result of land displacement, armed conflict, and other encroachments.

Collaborations of artists across countries result to fruitful endeavors such as Lily Anne Perez’s In Search of Kwan and Ocho Ocho (Barrionics), which she accomplished with artists from the Philippines and the United States. These pieces involve installations, theatre, dance, video, and computer music. In the same light, Dennis Reyes employs electronic technology in his compositions such as the Dance of the Monkey King and Bolgia, performed in series of Asian Composers League international festivals. Other works of Filipino composers using electro-acoustic and computer technology are uploaded in SoundCloud and other online websites for listening access. Electronic music compositions have been around not only in the academe but among experimental groups as well. Tad Ermitaño’s Deus Ex Machina and Tengal Drilon’s 30 Sounds in a Filing Cabinet are some of the pieces that involve interactive technology and media art. Ermitano has also worked with members of The Children of Cathode Ray, an experimental media group. This group has been performing his works, which in context, become his partners in recreating structures and ideas. Written by Ramon P. Santos, updated by Maria Christine Muyco

text:
Music criticism is the subjective evaluation of a musical work or performance based on the experience of the writer. This interpretation may emerge from a music analysis, which deals with music’s formal properties, or from historical and cultural facts, which would provide contextual meanings. Music criticism fundamentally differs from all other types of musicological writings because it emphasizes how a piece of music is perceived, heard, or felt by a listener who then shares his or her musical experience in writing to a reader.

 

Music criticism may be classified into two kinds, both of which are practiced in the Philippines: (a) the academic or specialized music criticism, found in scholarly journals, periodicals, or books, and (b) the general or what can be called performance review, which is published in newspapers or popular magazines. Normally, criticism of both kinds should position a new work or its performance in relation to existing genre conventions, emphasizing its status with respect to the repertoire of which such work or performance is a part of, and in reference to the composer’s other works as well as to other related compositions. It requires attention to musical details such as elements and forms, and utilizes a specialized technical vocabulary.

 

Criticism of the first kind is an elucidation of a work or performance, written by the few musicologists and academics in the country. Published in refereed journals and books, it is characterized by an examination of a work or a performance, usually discussing its formalistic content and employing a theoretical framework to validate the scholarly approach of the critic’s analysis. It is intended to be read by people who are interested in the uniqueness and artistry of such work or performance as this was or is primarily experienced. Such criticism may bring in as well the work’s relation to the historical, sociopolitical, and cultural circumstances that would further enrich the appreciation of the evaluated piece or performance. It requires the critic to have a comprehensive technical training, particularly in music theory and history; a systematic usage of musical vocabulary; a comprehensive and deep knowledge of repertories; a firm grasp of theoretical frameworks; a high regard for scholarship; and an unquestionable esteem for the art of music.

The second type of criticism is the performance review which is written for the general audience, and therefore, disseminated by the mass media. Normally, it reports the critic’s experience of the musical event, usually containing information about the composition and its historical and cultural contexts, with the goal of offering an understanding of the musical performance to the public. The principal task of a critic of this kind is to interpret in lay terms an artist’s performance of a work, commenting on its manner of interpretation and impact, especially its relationship to style and repertoire. Ideally, the critic for this type possesses the same qualifications as those writing scholarly reviews, and in addition, the ability to popularize his or her ideas. In the Philippines, some music critics or reviewers for periodicals are trained formally or informally in music; others, sadly, only have a nodding acquaintance with music. Writers with training generally expound with equal ease on all kinds of performed music, from chamber to symphonic to band, from solo instrumental pieces to music theater.

Academic criticism appears in refereed journals such as Musika Jornal, Humanities Diliman, Asian Studies, Bulawan, Budhi, Kritika Kultura, Perspectives in the Arts and Humanities, and Philippine Studies. Two examples of academic criticism using different approaches on a range of musical subjects are Jose Buenconsejo’s article, “Dances and Hostility and Friendship: Embodied Histories of Group Relations in the Agusan-Manobo Spirit Possession” in Humanities Diliman, 2001, which explores indigenous songs in the context of Manobo rituals as a way to establish face-to-face relationships between people; and Jonas Baes’s article, “That’s Ethnomusicology-or-Could my Study of Songs Help Indigenous Philippine Peoples in Disputes over Ancestral Domain?” in Perfect Beat: The Pacific Journal of Research into Contemporary Music and Popular Culture, 2002, which is on the music of the Iraya Mangyan of Mindoro and details the role of music in empowerment, specifically in relation to disputes over their ancestral domain.

A fine example of scholarly criticism is Ramon Santos’s Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music. This contains the essay “Nicanor S. Abelardo: Filipino Classicism in the Art of Music,” 2005, which scrutinizes Abelardo’s kundiman such as “Mutya ng Pasig” (Maiden of Pasig), “Kundiman ng Luha” (Kundiman of Tears), and “Nasaan Ka Irog” (Where Are You, Beloved), as well as Abelardo’s instrumental works such as “Romanza” for violoncello, and Concerto in B-flat Minor. The essay provides a detailed assessment of Abelardo’s harmonic explorations in his attempt to create instrumental compositions that extended classical forms, and songs that are meaningful fusion of poetry and music in his songs.

The second kind of criticism first appeared in the earliest periodicals devoted to music like the short-lived La Lira Filipina, which ran from 2 May 1877 to 27 Feb 1878. This was followed by the publication of the journal Revista del Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario de Manila, which printed its first musical review on 10 Aug 1879. The first Filipino music critics at the turn of the 20th century were Epifanio de los Santos, Fernando Canon, Alfredo Roa, Antonio Molina, Ignacio Manlapaz, and Arturo B. Rotor of the Philippines Herald and Francisco B. Icasiano of the Tribune who wrote in the1920s and 1930s. In the 1930s, composer Felipe Padilla de Leon wrote a column, “Musical Corner,” for the Tribune. After World War II, he wrote “Music and You” for Manila Times. Other composers who wrote about music performances were Antonio Giodina and Hilarion F. Rubio. There were other critics of the pre-World War II era such as columnist J. Mauricio Pimentel of La Vanguardia and the American writer Abraham Van Heyningen Hartendorp of The Manila Times who was also the publisher of Philippine Magazine.

After World War II, J. Mauricio Pimentel, who wrote for Evening News, commented that music critics sprouted “like mushrooms, appearing everywhere.” In the 1950s, the better-known critics were Rodrigo D. Perez III, Rosita Sandejas de la Concepcion, Morli Dharam or Anthony Morli, and Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, all for The Manila Times; Adelaida Reyes Katigbak, Evening News; and Rosalinda Orosa, The Manila Chronicle, Philippine Daily Express, and The Philippines Star. In the 1960s, other writers emerged such as Exequiel Molina of Business Day, which later became Business World; and Vilma Santiago-Felipe and Esther Samonte-Madrid, both of Daily Mirror. In 1972, martial law closed down some dailies and saw the flourishing of new ones. In the 1970s and 1980s, Santiago-Felipe continued to write, but now for Manila Bulletin, while Orosa-Goquingco wrote for the Philippine Times Journal, Philippine Star, Manila Bulletin, Philippine Daily Express, Manila Times Journal, Short Show Magazine, and Evening Post. Other writers who have published music reviews from the 1980s to the present are Jaime Daroy for Philippine Daily Inquirer; Celeste Icban Dadap for Manila Bulletin; Antonio Hila for Manila Chronicle when it was still circulating, and at present, for Philippine Daily Inquirer; and Pablo Tariman, who wrote a regular column on culture for Manila Chronicle and an occasional one for Philippine Daily Globe, and now contributes to Philippine Daily Inquirer.

Examples of performance reviews are Felipe de Leon Jr’s reflections on Filipino musical identity in his article “What is Philippine Music?” in Malaya, 3 May 1990; an appraisal of Lorenzo Medel’s piano concert in “Young Pianist Electrifies Audience,” in Philippine Daily Inquirer, 26 Jul 2010; and Pocholo Concepcion’s assessment of the 2011 Red Horse Beer Muziklaban Rock Challenge in “Tribal Fun Prevails in ‘Muziklaban’,” in the same newspaper, 1 Feb 2011.

On 18 Mar 1983, the Samahan ng Manunuri at Manunulat sa Musika ng Pilipinas (SAMMPI) or Music Critics Guild was founded by a small group of music critics and writers composed of Exequiel Molina, Felipe de Leon Jr, Vilma Santiago-Felipe, Antonio C. Hila, Fe B. Mangahas, Felicidad Z. Reyes, and Pablo Tariman. Except for Molina who wrote regularly for Business Day, all were freelance writers and contributors to the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ publication Arts Monthly, then edited by Tariman.

At present, music criticism of the second kind in the Philippines is faced with an unfavorable predicament brought about by factors that directly limit the serious growth of the profession. Criticisms that come out often fall short of professional standards because of the following reasons. First, there is a dearth of space in existing periodicals for responsible and serious criticism because of competition with the more sensational nature of writing in the tabloids. The tabloids prefer a more trivialized type of reporting in order to capture and maintain the general readers’ attention. Second, there is dearth of professional critics because newspaper companies do not hire them. They consider it too costly to have a specialized music critic in their roster of employees, and they think that it is not important enough. Third, critics of the other arts double up as music critics. Necessarily, they are not knowledgeable enough about music. Fourth, the practice of showering critics with all kinds of perks (i.e., free transportation, tickets, and meals) has become the norm among performers who are hoping that their performances are reviewed in a positive light. As a consequence of all these, reviews generally appear more as simply reports of musical events and typically contain descriptions of the audiences’ response. They are commonly impressionistic and promotional in nature, serving as a public relations tool for both the artists and the writers. But a ray of hope can be glimpsed in social media bloggers who write candid, often fair evaluations of musical productions including publications, recordings, and performances. These music aficionados attend and leave musical events discreetly and in no time publish their criticism online. Written by Antonio C. Hila updated by Arwin Q. Tan a dditional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

Mauricio Pimentel of La Vanguardia and the American writer Abraham Van Heyningen Hartendorp of The Manila Times who was also the publisher of Philippine Magazine.

After World War II, J. Mauricio Pimentel, who wrote for Evening News, commented that music critics sprouted “like mushrooms, appearing everywhere.” In the 1950s, the better-known critics were Rodrigo D. Perez III, Rosita Sandejas de la Concepcion, Morli Dharam or Anthony Morli, and Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, all for The Manila Times; Adelaida Reyes Katigbak, Evening News; and Rosalinda Orosa, The Manila Chronicle, Philippine Daily Express, and The Philippines Star. In the 1960s, other writers emerged such as Exequiel Molina of Business Day, which later became Business World; and Vilma Santiago-Felipe and Esther Samonte-Madrid, both of Daily Mirror. In 1972, martial law closed down some dailies and saw the flourishing of new ones. In the 1970s and 1980s, Santiago-Felipe continued to write, but now for Manila Bulletin, while Orosa-Goquingco wrote for the Philippine Times Journal, Philippine Star, Manila Bulletin, Philippine Daily Express, Manila Times Journal, Short Show Magazine, and Evening Post. Other writers who have published music reviews from the 1980s to the present are Jaime Daroy for Philippine Daily Inquirer; Celeste Icban Dadap for Manila Bulletin; Antonio Hila for Manila Chronicle when it was still circulating, and at present, for Philippine Daily Inquirer; and Pablo Tariman, who wrote a regular column on culture for Manila Chronicle and an occasional one for Philippine Daily Globe, and now contributes to Philippine Daily Inquirer.

Examples of performance reviews are Felipe de Leon Jr’s reflections on Filipino musical identity in his article “What is Philippine Music?” in Malaya, 3 May 1990; an appraisal of Lorenzo Medel’s piano concert in “Young Pianist Electrifies Audience,” in Philippine Daily Inquirer, 26 Jul 2010; and Pocholo Concepcion’s assessment of the 2011 Red Horse Beer Muziklaban Rock Challenge in “Tribal Fun Prevails in ‘Muziklaban’,” in the same newspaper, 1 Feb 2011.

On 18 Mar 1983, the Samahan ng Manunuri at Manunulat sa Musika ng Pilipinas (SAMMPI) or Music Critics Guild was founded by a small group of music critics and writers composed of Exequiel Molina, Felipe de Leon Jr, Vilma Santiago-Felipe, Antonio C. Hila, Fe B. Mangahas, Felicidad Z. Reyes, and Pablo Tariman. Except for Molina who wrote regularly for Business Day, all were freelance writers and contributors to the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ publication Arts Monthly, then edited by Tariman.

At present, music criticism of the second kind in the Philippines is faced with an unfavorable predicament brought about by factors that directly limit the serious growth of the profession. Criticisms that come out often fall short of professional standards because of the following reasons. First, there is a dearth of space in existing periodicals for responsible and serious criticism because of competition with the more sensational nature of writing in the tabloids. The tabloids prefer a more trivialized type of reporting in order to capture and maintain the general readers’ attention. Second, there is dearth of professional critics because newspaper companies do not hire them. They consider it too costly to have a specialized music critic in their roster of employees, and they think that it is not important enough. Third, critics of the other arts double up as music critics. Necessarily, they are not knowledgeable enough about music. Fourth, the practice of showering critics with all kinds of perks (i.e., free transportation, tickets, and meals) has become the norm among performers who are hoping that their performances are reviewed in a positive light. As a consequence of all these, reviews generally appear more as simply reports of musical events and typically contain descriptions of the audiences’ response. They are commonly impressionistic and promotional in nature, serving as a public relations tool for both the artists and the writers. But a ray of hope can be glimpsed in social media bloggers who write candid, often fair evaluations of musical productions including publications, recordings, and performances. These music aficionados attend and leave musical events discreetly and in no time publish their criticism online. Written by Antonio C. Hila updated by Arwin Q. Tan a dditional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

Sections

Indigenous Tradition of Informal Music Education
Historical Notes on Formal Music Education

Music education, which is the transmission of musical skills, knowledge, and values, is shaped by its purposes and context. This transference may take place in the formalized setting of a classroom or under more natural or informal conditions, but either way serving as an avenue for the transmission of culture.

 

Indigenous Tradition of Informal Music Education

 

Among indigenous cultural groups, music is adjunct to everyday living, connected with life cycle events as seen through the ceremonies or rituals that celebrate birth, courtship, and marriage, and that give emphasis to healing, curing, and grieving for the dead. It is used to lull babies to sleep, to relax, or to lighten the burden of household chores. It is as a means of driving away evil spirits or thanking the gods. Planting, harvesting, fishing, and hunting are likewise accompanied by musical activity. In the chanted epics, heroes are extolled, genealogies are traced, and moral lessons are imparted. By and large, such music is learned by imitation and immersion. Young children who are surrounded by this music in their daily activities subconsciously absorb the repertoire. This unstructured transmission process takes place continuously in the community, from generation to generation.

 

The Manobo epic singers learn their songs before or during their early teens. Inuk of Tambuyung, the immortal Manobo bard who chanted the Tuwaang epic, descended from a long line of epic singers. His grandfather had two sons, Inagla and Lumunay, both epic singers. Lumunay was Inuk’s father. Inuk’s son Kagyo is also an accomplished singer. Since formal teaching is not part of the Manobo culture, the children of epic singers are more likely to become epic singers themselves through constant exposure. However, other interested youngsters with the “proper voice” may learn from a master in a very informal manner. Banlak and Mahunlayon, two Manobo epic singers, learned their songs by staying and listening to Inuk in his house for several nights. They would return home and practice the song away from their teacher. This type of transmission also occurred in the case of Oyana, a Mansaka singer, who learned the Manggob the same way.

Among the Sulod, Panay Bukidnon, a binukot (kept maiden) is chosen by the elders of the community. The binukot enjoys great prestige, for it is she who chants the Hinilawod epic and records in memory all beliefs and rituals of the community. Elena Gardoce or Lola Elena, Sulod chanter of the Hinilawod was anointed binukot when she was 13 years old. Her grandmother, also a binukot, trained her for four hours a day. She was chosen because of her high-pitched voice and her good memory.

Gong music, like epic singing, is also learned by imitation. Gongs are highly valued, sometimes considered sacred, and children are normally not allowed to play with these instruments. On the other hand, bamboo is abundant and inexpensive. Thus, children learn the intricate gong patterns they hear by playing these patterns on bamboo instruments.

In the Cordillera highlands, young Kalinga boys imitate the gangsa (flat gong) rhythms on the patatag (bamboo xylophone blades). The two styles of gong playing, namely, gangsa pattong or striking the gongs with a stick, and gangsa toppaya or striking the gongs with the palms, are simulated. One stick is used to strike the patatag for the pattong style while two sticks, following the palm strokes of two hands, are used for the toppaya style.

Another example of bamboo as gong substitutes is found among the Maguindanaon. Quill-shaped tubes of hard bamboo are used in lieu of the big agung (wide rimmed hanging bossed gong). Young boys practice the difficult agung patterns on the agung tamlang (bamboo tube “slit drum”).

Among Muslim cultures, a more formalized process of transmission of musical traditions takes place. The Tausug have a highly organized system for imparting their vocal music tradition which entails learning a repertoire of melodies set to prescribed texts. Young girls learn the lugu maulud, a song cycle in Arabic which tells of the birth and life of Mohammed in poetry and prose, from the community lugu teacher, who also works on vocal quality, competitive performance techniques, and stage presence. The usual length of study for the lugu maulud is six months, after which other lugu traditions like the sail (ritual song), langanbatabata (royal lullaby), and tarasul (homiletic songs) may be learned.

A similar transmission system is followed for the paggabang (voice with gabbang xylophone), tata gabbang (solo gabbang), and tata biyula (solo biyula) traditions. The teacher, most often male, is a professional musician. He teaches instrumental technique and repertoire. The vocal part is taught aurally, while instrumental instruction is essentially visual and kinetic. A disciple-guru relationship exists between male students and the teacher. The teacher provides room and board to them in exchange for household service. Female students, however, have lessons at prearranged times.

The third type of transmission in Tausug culture involves learning the tata suling and tata saunay traditions. Only the males learn the biyula (violin), suling (flute), and saunay (reed pipe), usually from a relative or a neighbor. This is done sporadically and informally. Among the Maranao, instruction in vocal music is likewise based on the disciple-guru system. The guru is a high-caliber professional singer. He may have as many as three or four apprentices living with him at a time, although two is usually the norm. Text is initially memorized. The various styles of singing these texts are then learned by rote, with the guru singing first, followed by the student. This traditional apprenticeship is termed kasombak. The apprentice, who may be anywhere from 12 to 20 years old, is the morit.

 

Historical Notes on Formal Music Education

 

With the coming of the Spanish colonizers in 1521, efforts at Christianization brought about the introduction of canto llano (Gregorian chant) and canto d’organo (polyphonic music). The arrival of the Augustinians in 1569, the Franciscans in 1577, the Jesuits in 1581, the Dominicans in 1587, and the Recollects in 1606, resulted in the establishment of schools in convents and churches all over the islands, where young boys were taught the liturgy and its accompanying music. Thus, in 1606, the Franciscan Fr Juan de Santa Marta founded a seminary in Lumban, Laguna where 400 boys from different towns were trained in singing and playing musical instruments. Earlier accounts describe how young children were taught canto llano and canto d’organo as well as how to play musical instruments, together with Christian doctrine, reading, and writing. The Franciscan Francisco de San Antonio noted in his Chronicas that each town had decent instrumental music and a church choir, and everyone knew how to read notes. This observation was echoed again and again in subsequent reports, journals, and travelogues in the decades that followed. Favorite instruments were the flute, violin, piano, harp, and guitar. By the mid-1800s, much mention was made of the excellent bands which performed not only in Manila but in town plazas all over the islands.

A long list of friar musicians who taught in the convent and church schools includes Fr San Pedro Bautista, who was the first to teach Western music to the Tagalog; Fr Geronimo Aguilar, who taught Gregorian chant, polyphony, and instruments in Camarines; Fr Juan de Santa Marta, who taught in Lumban, Laguna in 1606; Fr Antonio de Moqueda, who taught in Majayjay, Laguna; Fr Marcelo de San Agustin, who taught in Manila in 1565; Fr Juan Bolivar, who taught in Manila and Panay in 1739; Fr Lorenzo Castelo, who taught in Manila, Ilocos, and Panay in 1718; Fr Ignacio de Jesus, who taught in Guadalupe Church in 1737; Fr Jose de la Virgen, who taught in Bicol, from 1717 to 1767; and Fr Diego Cera, who taught in Las Piñas in 1795.

The Colegio de Niños Tiples de la Santa Iglesia Catedral was established at the behest of the Archbishop of Manila, Juan Angel Rodriguez, who, shortly before his death in 1742, ordered that a boys’ choir be formed. It became the prototype for the other schools in the islands. The Colegio had a director, vice-director, three music professors, and an academic teacher of primary instruction. Music classes for solfeggio, vocalization, composition, organ, and string instruments were given to the young boys. Many noted Filipino musicians such as Antonio Garcia, Salvador Piñon, Fulgencio Tolentino, and Manuel Lopez were graduates of the school. The college was in existence until the outbreak of World War II.

A great many chronicles of the 19th century also speak of the presence of pianos in the homes of the landed and educated gentry in most towns and cities. Young ladies were taught to play the piano by hired teachers who came to their homes to give individual instruction. Both male and female students learned how to play the piano in the colegios of the Spanish period. This system of piano teaching continued in private schools to the American period. In some cases, students would go to their teachers’ homes for their lessons. Today, however, with the existence of many professional music schools, this type of instruction has declined.

The American colonial government established the public school system all over the islands. As early as August 1898, seven schools were established in Manila and many more followed, so that at the turn of the century, over 100,000 Filipino children were enrolled in public schools. American soldiers served as the first public school teachers and were later replaced by the Thomasites, American teachers who came aboard the USS Thomas. In the first decade of the 20th century, young talented Filipinos were sent to the United States as pensionados or scholars. Upon their return, they also assumed teaching and administrative positions.

At the elementary school level, music instruction was limited mostly to the development of singing skills based on material contained in the four-volume Progressive Music Series, 1924, by Horatio Parker et al., and a Philippine edition of the same series by Charles E. Griffith and Norberto Romualdez. These books were graded anthologies containing folk songs from different countries, some classical works, and contributions by American and Filipino composers. Similar anthologies were subsequently introduced: Singing and Growing for Primary Grades, edited by Ramon Tapales, 1952, and Sing and Be Happy, edited by Antonino Buenaventura and Jose Villa Panganiban, 1966.

In 1982, the Ministry of Education and Culture (MEC) prescribed a New Elementary School Curriculum (MEC-ORDER No. 6) which included among its objectives the “development of basic understanding about Philippine culture and the acquisition of fundamental knowledge, habits and skills … in culture, history, and arts.” The new guidelines provided that for the Grade 1 and 2 levels, music would be part of an integrated teaching strategy, serving as a supplementary medium of instruction rather than as a learning goal itself. From grades 3 to 6, music would be taught as a separate learning area, sharing a daily allocation of 40 minutes with Visual Arts and Physical Education. Later, the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports (DECS) issued further guidelines on the minimum learning requirement for music: identification of notation symbols and execution of simple forms and simple tonic-dominant-subdominant harmonies.

At the high school level, the teaching of music received new impetus with the 1986 Philippine Constitution provision which guaranteed free high school education. As a result, the DECS upgraded and revised the secondary school curriculum. Thus, with the creation of the Secondary Education Development Program (SEDP), the teaching of music in the high school system was institutionalized. Music was made part of a composite subject called PHEM, together with Health and Physical Education. PHEM received a daily 40-minute allocation throughout the four-year high school course. The fundamental learning framework was based on theoretical skills drawn from Western music. On their third year, students were taught Philippine and Asian music. The content of the Philippine music component included the indigenous music of northern Luzon, Islamic music of Mindanao, rural Christian folk music from the Tagalog and Visayan regions, and Philippine art songs and old theater forms.

In both elementary and high school programs, singing constituted the main classroom activity. Some schools offered elective participation in choruses, rondalla groups, or bands.

Legislations for Music Education Basic Education. The first legislation which touched on music education was Republic Act (RA) 4723 signed in 1966. It was known as the Music Law, which mandated the teaching of music and art as a separate subject in the elementary level and the teaching of music once a week in the secondary level.

The Governance of Basic Education Act or RA No. 9155 signed in 2001 led to the Basic Education Curriculum for Formal Education of 2002 which aimed, among other things, to develop in the Filipino learner a love of country and pride in his or her rich cultural heritage through holistic teaching and learning. The four components directed toward this aim were Musika, Sining, Edukasyong Pangkatawan, and Edukasyong Pangkalusugan (MSEPP). The experiential approach in listening, singing, playing, reading, and creating music became the preferred strategy for teaching music.

The Enhanced Basic Education Act or RA 10533 signed in 2013 is also known as the K-12 Program. It aims to prepare the Filipino learner for college or vocational-technical career opportunities to achieve global competitiveness within 12 years (six years in elementary, four years in junior high school, and two years in senior high school). This learner-oriented reform advocates the Mother-Tongue-Based Lingual Education for grades 1-3 and a specialized senior high school curriculum created with the cooperation of the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) and the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA). The implementation of the K-12 program began in 2016. Under it, music is to be taught as a separate subject, with content and processes appropriate for each grade level.

Presidential Decree No. 1287, signed in 1978, created the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) in Makiling. It was instituted to search for and develop highly talented children exceptionally gifted in the arts, with the end goal of providing a continuing source of artists of excellence and leaders in the preservation and promotion of the Filipino’s artistic heritage. Currently, the school has five specializations: creative writing, dance (folk and ballet), music, theater arts, and visual arts. The PHSA curriculum is currently undergoing synchronization with the K-12 program to further support the development of artistry and creative expression in the specialized fields. The Special Program for the Arts (SPA) in the approved DepEd public high schools was conceived as a regional counterpart of PHSA but only in selected applicable fields. More initiatives from the regions would disseminate the SPA.

Higher Education. The University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music was opened in 1916 by a Philippine Legislature Act. Since then, it has had 14 directors/deans. Originally modeled after European conservatories, it has since been elevated to a college in 1966, complementing its music offering with a substantive component of general education courses in the sciences, humanities, languages, and social sciences. Two faculty members (one from the Voice Department and one from Composition Department), and seven alumni (six from the Composition Department and one from the Voice Department) have been declared National Artists for Music.

Today, the UP College of Music offers undergraduate and graduate programs which reflect a fusion of European conservatory and American college practices. It has eight departments: Composition, Conducting and Choral Ensemble, Music Education, Musicology, Keyboard, and Chamber Music, Voice and Music Theater, and Winds and Percussion. In the ladderized undergraduate curriculum, a five-year bachelor of music program (BM) offers majors in instruments, conducting (band, choral, orchestral), piano, voice, dance, composition, music education, and musicology. The four-year diploma in the creative and performing musical arts (DCPMA) has majors in instrument, piano, band conducting, choral conducting, voice, dance, Asian music, composition, and music education. A short three-year music certificate program was created primarily for the performing arts, focusing on instruments and voice. At the graduate level, the college confers master of music degrees with majors in instruments, voice, musicology, conducting, and composition, which have been designed to deepen the respective BM areas of specializations. The 2011 Doctor of Philosophy in music aims to address the current demand for broader, more holistic, and more integrative activities in the dimensions of music scholarship, creation, and pedagogy in the country and in Southeast Asia.

The University of Santo Tomas (UST) was founded in 1611 as a joint enterprise of Archbishop Miguel de Benavides and the Dominican order. The Conservatory of Music was founded much later in 1946, with Manuel de Cuerva as its first director and Rev Gregorio Garcia OP as regent. The current bachelor of music curriculum at UST is a four-year course with majors in keyboard, music education, voice, strings, guitar, woodwinds, brasswinds, percussion, music literature music theory, composition, conducting, musical theatre, and music technology. A three-year course with majors in keyboard, voice, strings, winds, percussion, and theory leads to a music teacher’s certificate. In the field of performance, two types of courses are offered: a four-year performance certificate designed for students with a pronounced performance ability and a five-year artist diploma course designed for student with exceptional performance ability. Specialized courses in sacred music are also offered.

Saint Scholastica’s College (SSC) was founded by the Benedictine nuns in 1906. Music instruction was given by Sr Winfrieda Muller and in 1907 by Sr Baptista Battig, an accomplished pianist. The school became noted for excellence in piano performance. It produced its first piano graduate, Patrocinio Garcia, in 1917, and in that same decade, 11 others finished a piano course. The SSC Music Department continues to be one of the leading music schools in the Metro Manila area. Its current undergraduate curriculum consists of bachelor of music degrees in music composition (BMC); in performance (BMP) (voice, instruments, and violin pedagogy); music education (BMME); and a bachelor of arts in music production and technology (BAMPT). The college also offers diplomas in composition (DMC), performance (DMP), music production and technology (DMPT), and a certificate in music performance (CMP). The master of music has concentrations in music education, piano pedagogy, and string pedagogy.

The School of Music of the Philippine Women’s University offers a bachelor of music curriculum specializing in music performance, music education, Philippine music, and popular music, while for its master’s degree, the specializations are music performance, music education, piano pedagogy, and ethnomusicology. The master of arts degree has three major areas of concentration: music education with emphasis on choral conducting, music education with emphasis on the Kodaly Approach, and ethnomusicology. The Doctor of Philosophy focuses on music performance and ethnomusicology.

The College of Music and the Performing Arts of Saint Paul University offers a bachelor’s degree in music program in piano, voice, instruments, music theory, composition, marimba, piano accompanying and chamber music, and music therapy for children and youth with disabilities. The master’s degree in music programs is in the areas of performance, piano pedagogy, theory pedagogy, vocal pedagogy, choral conducting, music education, collaborative performance, and musicology. A master of arts in music concentrates on music therapy.

Silliman University in Dumaguete City was founded by Protestant missionaries in 1901. Its School of Music, which was granted college status in 2001, is officially known today as the College of Performing and Visual Arts. It confers bachelor of music degrees in choral conducting, composition and arranging, music education, piano, and voice as well as master of music degrees in choral conducting, instrument conducting, ethnomusicology, and music education. It initiated a research program on southern Philippine music and maintains an archive of taped music collections.

The University of San Agustin, originally Colegio de San Agustin, established in 1904 by missionaries belonging to the order of Saint Augustine, was granted university status in 1953. Its Conservatory of Music was subsequently established in 1967. The bachelor of music curriculum specifies the following areas of concentration: piano, voice, music science, and music education. An associate in music program and a music specialization course for elementary and secondary teachers are also offered.

In the 1930s, two private music schools were established in Manila: the Academy of Music, founded in 1930, under the directorship of Alexander Lippay; and the Manila Conservatory of Music, founded in 1934, under the directorship of Rodolfo S. Cornejo. Both schools, however, only operated for a few years.

The Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music (AILM) is patterned after the German schools that specialize in church music. At AILM, the emphasis is on the use and development of traditional music in Asia for contemporary Christian liturgy and worship.Students follow a curriculum which includes theory, solfeggio, history, field methods, field work, transcription, chorus, composition, and instrumental and vocal performance and pedagogy. Enrollees hail from all over the Philippines as well as from different Asian countries.

Outside the academe, there are today some tutors who give private lessons on vocal technique and interpretation. Others have established private institutions to answer the demand for training among musical performers and composers, especially in the different mass media. One such school is the Ryan Cayabyab Music Studio, founded in 1986 by composer-performer Ryan Cayabyab and his wife Emelina Punzalan. It offers courses on music theory, music composition, music arrangement, music and movement, jazz improvisation, piano, guitar, and voice, the latter for both pop and classical vocal artists. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Mauricia D. Borromeo
