Inuk of Tambuyung, the immortal Manobo bard who chanted the Tuwaang epic, descended from a long line of epic singers. His grandfather had two sons, Inagla and Lumunay, both epic singers. Lumunay was Inuk’s father. Inuk’s son Kagyo is also an accomplished singer. Since formal teaching is not part of the Manobo culture, the children of epic singers are more likely to become epic singers themselves through constant exposure. However, other interested youngsters with the “proper voice” may learn from a master in a very informal manner. Banlak and Mahunlayon, two Manobo epic singers, learned their songs by staying and listening to Inuk in his house for several nights. They would return home and practice the song away from their teacher. This type of transmission also occurred in the case of Oyana, a Mansaka singer, who learned the Manggob the same way.

Among the Sulod, Panay Bukidnon, a binukot (kept maiden) is chosen by the elders of the community. The binukot enjoys great prestige, for it is she who chants the Hinilawod epic and records in memory all beliefs and rituals of the community. Elena Gardoce or Lola Elena, Sulod chanter of the Hinilawod was anointed binukot when she was 13 years old. Her grandmother, also a binukot, trained her for four hours a day. She was chosen because of her high-pitched voice and her good memory.

Gong music, like epic singing, is also learned by imitation. Gongs are highly valued, sometimes considered sacred, and children are normally not allowed to play with these instruments. On the other hand, bamboo is abundant and inexpensive. Thus, children learn the intricate gong patterns they hear by playing these patterns on bamboo instruments.

In the Cordillera highlands, young Kalinga boys imitate the gangsa (flat gong) rhythms on the patatag (bamboo xylophone blades). The two styles of gong playing, namely, gangsa pattong or striking the gongs with a stick, and gangsa toppaya or striking the gongs with the palms, are simulated. One stick is used to strike the patatag for the pattong style while two sticks, following the palm strokes of two hands, are used for the toppaya style.

Another example of bamboo as gong substitutes is found among the Maguindanaon. Quill-shaped tubes of hard bamboo are used in lieu of the big agung (wide rimmed hanging bossed gong). Young boys practice the difficult agung patterns on the agung tamlang (bamboo tube “slit drum”).

Among Muslim cultures, a more formalized process of transmission of musical traditions takes place. The Tausug have a highly organized system for imparting their vocal music tradition which entails learning a repertoire of melodies set to prescribed texts. Young girls learn the lugu maulud, a song cycle in Arabic which tells of the birth and life of Mohammed in poetry and prose, from the community lugu teacher, who also works on vocal quality, competitive performance techniques, and stage presence. The usual length of study for the lugu maulud is six months, after which other lugu traditions like the sail (ritual song), langanbatabata (royal lullaby), and tarasul (homiletic songs) may be learned.

A similar transmission system is followed for the paggabang (voice with gabbang xylophone), tata gabbang (solo gabbang), and tata biyula (solo biyula) traditions. The teacher, most often male, is a professional musician. He teaches instrumental technique and repertoire. The vocal part is taught aurally, while instrumental instruction is essentially visual and kinetic. A disciple-guru relationship exists between male students and the teacher. The teacher provides room and board to them in exchange for household service. Female students, however, have lessons at prearranged times.

The third type of transmission in Tausug culture involves learning the tata suling and tata saunay traditions. Only the males learn the biyula (violin), suling (flute), and saunay (reed pipe), usually from a relative or a neighbor. This is done sporadically and informally. Among the Maranao, instruction in vocal music is likewise based on the disciple-guru system. The guru is a high-caliber professional singer. He may have as many as three or four apprentices living with him at a time, although two is usually the norm. Text is initially memorized. The various styles of singing these texts are then learned by rote, with the guru singing first, followed by the student. This traditional apprenticeship is termed kasombak. The apprentice, who may be anywhere from 12 to 20 years old, is the morit.
Historical Notes on Formal Music Education

With the coming of the Spanish colonizers in 1521, efforts at Christianization brought about the introduction of canto llano (Gregorian chant) and canto d’organo (polyphonic music). The arrival of the Augustinians in 1569, the Franciscans in 1577, the Jesuits in 1581, the Dominicans in 1587, and the Recollects in 1606, resulted in the establishment of schools in convents and churches all over the islands, where young boys were taught the liturgy and its accompanying music. Thus, in 1606, the Franciscan Fr Juan de Santa Marta founded a seminary in Lumban, Laguna where 400 boys from different towns were trained in singing and playing musical instruments. Earlier accounts describe how young children were taught canto llano and canto d’organo as well as how to play musical instruments, together with Christian doctrine, reading, and writing. The Franciscan Francisco de San Antonio noted in his Chronicas that each town had decent instrumental music and a church choir, and everyone knew how to read notes. This observation was echoed again and again in subsequent reports, journals, and travelogues in the decades that followed. Favorite instruments were the flute, violin, piano, harp, and guitar. By the mid-1800s, much mention was made of the excellent bands which performed not only in Manila but in town plazas all over the islands.

A long list of friar musicians who taught in the convent and church schools includes Fr San Pedro Bautista, who was the first to teach Western music to the Tagalog; Fr Geronimo Aguilar, who taught Gregorian chant, polyphony, and instruments in Camarines; Fr Juan de Santa Marta, who taught in Lumban, Laguna in 1606; Fr Antonio de Moqueda, who taught in Majayjay, Laguna; Fr Marcelo de San Agustin, who taught in Manila in 1565; Fr Juan Bolivar, who taught in Manila and Panay in 1739; Fr Lorenzo Castelo, who taught in Manila, Ilocos, and Panay in 1718; Fr Ignacio de Jesus, who taught in Guadalupe Church in 1737; Fr Jose de la Virgen, who taught in Bicol, from 1717 to 1767; and Fr Diego Cera, who taught in Las Piñas in 1795.

The Colegio de Niños Tiples de la Santa Iglesia Catedral was established at the behest of the Archbishop of Manila, Juan Angel Rodriguez, who, shortly before his death in 1742, ordered that a boys’ choir be formed. It became the prototype for the other schools in the islands. The Colegio had a director, vice-director, three music professors, and an academic teacher of primary instruction. Music classes for solfeggio, vocalization, composition, organ, and string instruments were given to the young boys. Many noted Filipino musicians such as Antonio Garcia, Salvador Piñon, Fulgencio Tolentino, and Manuel Lopez were graduates of the school. The college was in existence until the outbreak of World War II.

A great many chronicles of the 19th century also speak of the presence of pianos in the homes of the landed and educated gentry in most towns and cities. Young ladies were taught to play the piano by hired teachers who came to their homes to give individual instruction. Both male and female students learned how to play the piano in the colegios of the Spanish period. This system of piano teaching continued in private schools to the American period. In some cases, students would go to their teachers’ homes for their lessons. Today, however, with the existence of many professional music schools, this type of instruction has declined.

The American colonial government established the public school system all over the islands. As early as August 1898, seven schools were established in Manila and many more followed, so that at the turn of the century, over 100,000 Filipino children were enrolled in public schools. American soldiers served as the first public school teachers and were later replaced by the Thomasites, American teachers who came aboard the USS Thomas. In the first decade of the 20th century, young talented Filipinos were sent to the United States as pensionados or scholars. Upon their return, they also assumed teaching and administrative positions.

At the elementary school level, music instruction was limited mostly to the development of singing skills based on material contained in the four-volume Progressive Music Series, 1924, by Horatio Parker et al., and a Philippine edition of the same series by Charles E. Griffith and Norberto Romualdez. These books were graded anthologies containing folk songs from different countries, some classical works, and contributions by American and Filipino composers. Similar anthologies were subsequently introduced: Singing and Growing for Primary Grades, edited by Ramon Tapales, 1952, and Sing and Be Happy, edited by Antonino Buenaventura and Jose Villa Panganiban, 1966.

In 1982, the Ministry of Education and Culture (MEC) prescribed a New Elementary School Curriculum (MEC-ORDER No. 6) which included among its objectives the “development of basic understanding about Philippine culture and the acquisition of fundamental knowledge, habits and skills … in culture, history, and arts.” The new guidelines provided that for the Grade 1 and 2 levels, music would be part of an integrated teaching strategy, serving as a supplementary medium of instruction rather than as a learning goal itself. From grades 3 to 6, music would be taught as a separate learning area, sharing a daily allocation of 40 minutes with Visual Arts and Physical Education. Later, the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports (DECS) issued further guidelines on the minimum learning requirement for music: identification of notation symbols and execution of simple forms and simple tonic-dominant-subdominant harmonies.

At the high school level, the teaching of music received new impetus with the 1986 Philippine Constitution provision which guaranteed free high school education. As a result, the DECS upgraded and revised the secondary school curriculum. Thus, with the creation of the Secondary Education Development Program (SEDP), the teaching of music in the high school system was institutionalized. Music was made part of a composite subject called PHEM, together with Health and Physical Education. PHEM received a daily 40-minute allocation throughout the four-year high school course. The fundamental learning framework was based on theoretical skills drawn from Western music. On their third year, students were taught Philippine and Asian music. The content of the Philippine music component included the indigenous music of northern Luzon, Islamic music of Mindanao, rural Christian folk music from the Tagalog and Visayan regions, and Philippine art songs and old theater forms.
In both elementary and high school programs, singing constituted the main classroom activity. Some schools offered elective participation in choruses, rondalla groups, or bands.

Legislations for Music Education Basic Education. The first legislation which touched on music education was Republic Act (RA) 4723 signed in 1966. It was known as the Music Law, which mandated the teaching of music and art as a separate subject in the elementary level and the teaching of music once a week in the secondary level.

The Governance of Basic Education Act or RA No. 9155 signed in 2001 led to the Basic Education Curriculum for Formal Education of 2002 which aimed, among other things, to develop in the Filipino learner a love of country and pride in his or her rich cultural heritage through holistic teaching and learning. The four components directed toward this aim were Musika, Sining, Edukasyong Pangkatawan, and Edukasyong Pangkalusugan (MSEPP). The experiential approach in listening, singing, playing, reading, and creating music became the preferred strategy for teaching music.

The Enhanced Basic Education Act or RA 10533 signed in 2013 is also known as the K-12 Program. It aims to prepare the Filipino learner for college or vocational-technical career opportunities to achieve global competitiveness within 12 years (six years in elementary, four years in junior high school, and two years in senior high school). This learner-oriented reform advocates the Mother-Tongue-Based Lingual Education for grades 1-3 and a specialized senior high school curriculum created with the cooperation of the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) and the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA). The implementation of the K-12 program began in 2016. Under it, music is to be taught as a separate subject, with content and processes appropriate for each grade level.

Presidential Decree No. 1287, signed in 1978, created the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) in Makiling. It was instituted to search for and develop highly talented children exceptionally gifted in the arts, with the end goal of providing a continuing source of artists of excellence and leaders in the preservation and promotion of the Filipino’s artistic heritage. Currently, the school has five specializations: creative writing, dance (folk and ballet), music, theater arts, and visual arts. The PHSA curriculum is currently undergoing synchronization with the K-12 program to further support the development of artistry and creative expression in the specialized fields. The Special Program for the Arts (SPA) in the approved DepEd public high schools was conceived as a regional counterpart of PHSA but only in selected applicable fields. More initiatives from the regions would disseminate the SPA.

Higher Education. The University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music was opened in 1916 by a Philippine Legislature Act. Since then, it has had 14 directors/deans. Originally modeled after European conservatories, it has since been elevated to a college in 1966, complementing its music offering with a substantive component of general education courses in the sciences, humanities, languages, and social sciences. Two faculty members (one from the Voice Department and one from Composition Department), and seven alumni (six from the Composition Department and one from the Voice Department) have been declared National Artists for Music.

Today, the UP College of Music offers undergraduate and graduate programs which reflect a fusion of European conservatory and American college practices. It has eight departments: Composition, Conducting and Choral Ensemble, Music Education, Musicology, Keyboard, and Chamber Music, Voice and Music Theater, and Winds and Percussion. In the ladderized undergraduate curriculum, a five-year bachelor of music program (BM) offers majors in instruments, conducting (band, choral, orchestral), piano, voice, dance, composition, music education, and musicology. The four-year diploma in the creative and performing musical arts (DCPMA) has majors in instrument, piano, band conducting, choral conducting, voice, dance, Asian music, composition, and music education. A short three-year music certificate program was created primarily for the performing arts, focusing on instruments and voice. At the graduate level, the college confers master of music degrees with majors in instruments, voice, musicology, conducting, and composition, which have been designed to deepen the respective BM areas of specializations. The 2011 Doctor of Philosophy in music aims to address the current demand for broader, more holistic, and more integrative activities in the dimensions of music scholarship, creation, and pedagogy in the country and in Southeast Asia.

The University of Santo Tomas (UST) was founded in 1611 as a joint enterprise of Archbishop Miguel de Benavides and the Dominican order. The Conservatory of Music was founded much later in 1946, with Manuel de Cuerva as its first director and Rev Gregorio Garcia OP as regent. The current bachelor of music curriculum at UST is a four-year course with majors in keyboard, music education, voice, strings, guitar, woodwinds, brasswinds, percussion, music literature music theory, composition, conducting, musical theatre, and music technology. A three-year course with majors in keyboard, voice, strings, winds, percussion, and theory leads to a music teacher’s certificate. In the field of performance, two types of courses are offered: a four-year performance certificate designed for students with a pronounced performance ability and a five-year artist diploma course designed for student with exceptional performance ability. Specialized courses in sacred music are also offered.

Saint Scholastica’s College (SSC) was founded by the Benedictine nuns in 1906. Music instruction was given by Sr Winfrieda Muller and in 1907 by Sr Baptista Battig, an accomplished pianist. The school became noted for excellence in piano performance. It produced its first piano graduate, Patrocinio Garcia, in 1917, and in that same decade, 11 others finished a piano course. The SSC Music Department continues to be one of the leading music schools in the Metro Manila area. Its current undergraduate curriculum consists of bachelor of music degrees in music composition (BMC); in performance (BMP) (voice, instruments, and violin pedagogy); music education (BMME); and a bachelor of arts in music production and technology (BAMPT). The college also offers diplomas in composition (DMC), performance (DMP), music production and technology (DMPT), and a certificate in music performance (CMP). The master of music has concentrations in music education, piano pedagogy, and string pedagogy.

The School of Music of the Philippine Women’s University offers a bachelor of music curriculum specializing in music performance, music education, Philippine music, and popular music, while for its master’s degree, the specializations are music performance, music education, piano pedagogy, and ethnomusicology. The master of arts degree has three major areas of concentration: music education with emphasis on choral conducting, music education with emphasis on the Kodaly Approach, and ethnomusicology. The Doctor of Philosophy focuses on music performance and ethnomusicology.

The College of Music and the Performing Arts of Saint Paul University offers a bachelor’s degree in music program in piano, voice, instruments, music theory, composition, marimba, piano accompanying and chamber music, and music therapy for children and youth with disabilities. The master’s degree in music programs is in the areas of performance, piano pedagogy, theory pedagogy, vocal pedagogy, choral conducting, music education, collaborative performance, and musicology. A master of arts in music concentrates on music therapy.

Silliman University in Dumaguete City was founded by Protestant missionaries in 1901. Its School of Music, which was granted college status in 2001, is officially known today as the College of Performing and Visual Arts. It confers bachelor of music degrees in choral conducting, composition and arranging, music education, piano, and voice as well as master of music degrees in choral conducting, instrument conducting, ethnomusicology, and music education. It initiated a research program on southern Philippine music and maintains an archive of taped music collections.

The University of San Agustin, originally Colegio de San Agustin, established in 1904 by missionaries belonging to the order of Saint Augustine, was granted university status in 1953. Its Conservatory of Music was subsequently established in 1967. The bachelor of music curriculum specifies the following areas of concentration: piano, voice, music science, and music education. An associate in music program and a music specialization course for elementary and secondary teachers are also offered.

In the 1930s, two private music schools were established in Manila: the Academy of Music, founded in 1930, under the directorship of Alexander Lippay; and the Manila Conservatory of Music, founded in 1934, under the directorship of Rodolfo S. Cornejo. Both schools, however, only operated for a few years.

The Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music (AILM) is patterned after the German schools that specialize in church music. At AILM, the emphasis is on the use and development of traditional music in Asia for contemporary Christian liturgy and worship.Students follow a curriculum which includes theory, solfeggio, history, field methods, field work, transcription, chorus, composition, and instrumental and vocal performance and pedagogy. Enrollees hail from all over the Philippines as well as from different Asian countries.

Outside the academe, there are today some tutors who give private lessons on vocal technique and interpretation. Others have established private institutions to answer the demand for training among musical performers and composers, especially in the different mass media. One such school is the Ryan Cayabyab Music Studio, founded in 1986 by composer-performer Ryan Cayabyab and his wife Emelina Punzalan. It offers courses on music theory, music composition, music arrangement, music and movement, jazz improvisation, piano, guitar, and voice, the latter for both pop and classical vocal artists. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Mauricia D. Borromeo

text:
Music recordings refer to mechanically reproduced copies of musical performances, instrumental and/or vocal music. Such copies were originally known as records.

 

Records, technically called phonorecords, began with the invention of the phonograph cylinder in 1877 and the gramophone disc in 1881. The earliest records were sold in 1901 in the United States by Victor Company. By 1925, the speed of the record was standardized at 78 RPM (revolutions per minute). In 1948, Columbia introduced the 33 1⁄3 RPM vinyl LP (long-playing) record, and in 1949, the 45 RPM single was introduced by RCA-Victor. These analog discs were supplanted by digital compact discs (CDs) in 1981, co-developed by Phillips and Sony. All musical recordings contained in phonorecords, including those synchronized with film and games, are collectively called phonograms.

According to Danny Yson, an American businessman named Isaac Beck opened a store in 1913 in Manila’s Isaac Peral Street (later renamed United Nations Avenue), which sold 78 RPM discs from Victor Company and their disc player called the Victrola. In the same year, a retired US Army major named William Anderson took the initiative to record Filipino talents. Anderson, who was appointed representative of the Victor Talking Machine Company, created a makeshift studio on the second floor of the Manila Hotel where he began recording songs from the Philippine sarsuwela, the native adaptation of the Spanish zarzuela or lyric theater. Actress Maria Carpena became the first Philippine recording artist. Accompanied by the Molina Orchestra, her song “Ang Maya” (The Sparrow), composed by Jose Estella with lyrics by Severino Reyes, was released by Victor Records in 1913.

In 1925, Isaac Beck became a distributor of Columbia Phonograph Company and became William Anderson’s competitor. Beck put up his own radio station, KZIB, after the release by Columbia Records of two Filipino songs, “Ang Dalagang Pilipina” (Filipina Maiden) and “Paalam sa Pagkadalaga” (Farewell to Maidenhood), which were recorded by the mezzo-soprano Nati de Arellano in the United States. Ironically, by 1929, Arellano transferred to Victor Records and recorded extensively with them. Most notable of these recordings was “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig) by Nicanor S. Abelardo.

In the 1920s, the popularity of bodabil (the Filipino vaudeville) brought to the fore the eclectic talents of Katy de la Cruz, billed equally as “Queen of Vaudeville” and “Queen of Jazz.” She was the highest paid entertainer in the country during her prime and had popularized her trademark art of scat singing. By the 1930s, she would be most identified with the song “Balut” (Duck Egg), a tune written by Jerry Brandy which was a bawdy take on the notorious Filipino culinary delicacy. However, her recorded legacy is the bilingual song “Magtanim ay Di Biro” (Planting Rice Is Never Easy), recorded initially for Filipinos in the United States with the English title “Planting Rice,” which was released by RCA-Victor.

Between the years 1927 and 1929, a young Filipino-Basque composer-pianist and conductor named Federico Elizalde, aka Fred Elizalde, did a series of jazz recordings in England for the prestigious Brunswick and Decca record labels. His recordings are considered milestones in the world of jazz, and are still available today under the name Fred Elizalde and his Anglo American Band. Elizalde was closely associated with modernist composers such as Maurice Ravel, Darius Milhaud, and Manuel De Falla. He returned to the Philippines in later years to conduct the Manila Symphony Orchestra and attend to his family’s media business.

In the 1930s, the most popular singer was Lilian Velez, who became a celebrated movie actress for LVN Pictures. She is best known for her on-screen rendition of “Sa Kabukiran” (By the Countryside), a theme song composed by her father Manuel P. Velez for a film of the same title. The elder Velez wrote other timeless Philippine songs such as “Lawiswis sa Kawayan” (Swishing Bamboo), “Ako’y Kampupot” (I’m a Jasmine), and “La Cariñosa” (The Affectionate Lady), which was recorded by the Victor Orchestra and released by Victor Records in 1930. The song “Sa Kabukiran” attained a wide Philippine cinematic following and was reinterpreted by Elsa Oria in Sampaguita Pictures’ movie Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star) and by Nora Hermosa in Vista Films’ movie Ang Siloy (The Songbird).

 

Songs from the Philippine sarsuwela found a new medium in movies and disc. “Bituing Marikit,” composed by Nicanor S. Abelardo in 1926, became a movie theme and title in 1937 for Sampaguita Pictures. Nicanor S. Abelardo supposedly recorded 16 of his songs for Victor Company, interpreted by various singers such as Nati de Arellano, Pacita de Tavera, and Florentino Ballecer. The most significant of these recordings was “Amorosa” (The Amorous Lady), released by Victor in New York in 1922.

Sylvia La Torre, known as the “Queen of Kundiman,” rose to prominence after World War II when she joined the roster of artists of the Manila Grand Opera House. In 1950, she became a recording artist for the fledgling independent label Bataan Records, with the song “Si Petite Mon Amour” (My Little Love). Later, she transferred to the larger independent Villar Records, where she recorded her hit song “Waray-Waray” (a person from Samar or Leyte), a blues progression with Tagalog lyrics. Villar Records was launched in 1950 by the late Manuel P. Villar, known as the “Father of Philippine Recording,” who had released the first commercial record of the Philippine National Anthem. In the 1960s, Villar Records’ previous success with “Waray-Waray” paved the way for another Tagalog vernacular song with a rock and roll progression, “Hahabol-habol” (Chasing After) by Bobby Gonzales, a singer who became a star on the live musical stage of Manila’s Clover Theater.

In the early 1960s, Pilita Corrales, a Cebuana Spanish mestiza, made a hit record in Melbourne titled “Come Closer to Me” and recorded three LPs for Australia’s Astor Records. Her weekly television show from 1965-72 featured her international hit song “A Million Thanks to You,” composed by Alice Doria-Gamilla and released by Villar Records. She was dubbed “Asia’s Queen of Song” and sang to open the Beatles’ 1966 concert at the Rizal Memorial Stadium. Later on, she transferred to Vicor Music Corporation, a company founded by record industry entrepreneurs Vic del Rosario and Orly Ilacad. Here, she interpreted George Canseco’s early compositions such as “Kapantay ay Langit” (As High as the Sky) issued in the album Philippine Love Songs Vol. 1.

In 1970, a Filipino-American singer-drummer named Joey “Pepe” Smith was discovered during his stint in Tokyo and was invited to join a band named Speed, Glue & Shinki that subsequently released two albums: Eve, 1971, and their eponymous second album, 1972, under Atlantic Records. Prior to his Japanese experience, Smith, with his previous band the Downbeats, was also part of the opening act of the Beatles’ 1966 concert at the Rizal Memorial Stadium. Returning to Manila upon completing his obligations with Atlantic Records, he reinvented himself as Pepe Smith and, consequently, with his colleagues in the Juan de la Cruz Band, invented Pinoy rock. Released by Vicor Music, their comprehensive discography consisted of “Up in Arms,” “Maskara” (Mask), “Super Session,” and “Kahit Anong Mangyari” (Whatever Happens). Pepe Smith’s composition, “Ang Himig Natin” (Our Hymn), defined the character of Pinoy rock for an entire generation.

The avalanche of possibilities in Pinoy rock was multifaceted. In 1977, a rock vocalist named Tessie Alfonso, with stage name Sampaguita, collaborated with an Olongapo-based guitarist, Gary Perez, to write songs for a self-titled LP released by Vicor that combined rock and roll with Tagalog street jargon, as in her single, “Bonggahan” (Revelry). After a long sabbatical, she repeated this formula on her own in 1991 with her single “Nosi Ba Lasi” (Tagalog word play for “Sino Ba Sila?”/Who Are They?), released on cassette tape by RJ Records. Ramon Jacinto, a rock and roll guitarist, singer, and businessman who owned RJ Records and the Rajah Broadcasting Network (DZRJ), had also released his own chart-topping song titled “Muli” (Once More) in the 1980s. A DZRJ favorite, Florante, recorded an album in 1978 titled Mga Tula at Awitin ni Florante (Poems and Songs of Florante) for an independent record label called Jem Recording Company that was received favorably by critics and folk-rock enthusiasts.

In 1976, Jem Recording Company, or simply Jem Records (not to be confused with an American label of the same name), introduced itself to the record-buying public with two prestigious LP album projects—namely, Pinoy Jazz by Eddie Munji III and Pinoy Jazz II: Roots to Routes by Ryan Cayabyab. Both featured modern arrangements of Philippine folk songs. Amid a flurry of mixed reviews, the tracks from the two albums were continually rotated on AM and FM radio.

The new Pinoy jazz genre was quickly supported by Vicor Records and its new subsidiary, Blackgold Records. Two groundbreaking albums by the Filipino bossa nova advocate and composer-pianist Bong Peñera found their place in the pop charts: A Samba Song, 1976, and Batucada sa Calesa (Batucada by the Horse-drawn Cart), 1977. It was also in 1977 that the LP The Jazz Friends was released. It featured Filipino big band performances with saxophonists Lito Molina and Doming Valdez, drummer Tony Velarde, and Manila’s finest jazz musicians, accompanied by music created by the “Godfather of Pinoy Jazz,” Angel Peña.

In an unexpected move, Jem Records issued Buhay Musikero (Musician’s Life), 1976, the first of three Pinoy Rock LPs that propelled Mike Hanopol, the erstwhile singer-composer-bassist of the Juan de la Cruz Band, to the top of the local charts. Hanopol’s themes of hardship, delinquency, greed, and desperation, combined with a refined rock aesthetic, were warmly received. This album was followed by two other LPs released by Blackgold Records—Awiting Pilipino (Filipino Songs), 1977, and Buksan (Open), 1978. Completing the cycle of classic Pinoy rock recordings, the abortive 1973 sessions of a Juan de la Cruz splinter group, Anak Bayan, were eventually released in 1977 in a self-titled LP by A&W Records, a subsidiary of Villar Records. The singles “Jeepney Rock” and “Probinsiyana” (Country Girl) resonated with elements of rock and jazz undertones. Almost as an afterthought, an album by an Olongapo-based band named Maria Cafra, led by guitarist Resty Fabunan, was released in 1978 by Jem Records. The subgenre of music, described as kundiman rock, was both tentative and creative.

In the early to mid-1970s, Vicor Music Corporation and Villar Records were in competition to capture a burgeoning Filipino pop market. Vicor was first in line to heed the demand as Filipino language adaptations of Western songs were crafted. A song by Barbra Streisand, “The Way We Were,” was sung by Rico J. Puno in an adaptation titled “Alaala sa Luneta” (Memories at Luneta), 1973. A song by the Bee Gees, “Charade,” was adapted by Willy Cruz into “Tag-Araw” (Summer), 1974, sung by Hajji Alejandro. The standard song “There Will Never Be Another You” was translated into “Ikaw Pa Rin” (Still You), 1975, by Tito Mina. Villar Records followed suit in 1974 with the release of the LP Unang Kagat (First Bite) and the single, “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You are the Miss Universe of My Life), recorded by the pop-rock band Hotdog. The popularity of the Miss Universe ditty spawned the movie Hotdog: Unang Kagat in 1975, starring the band, with some of the biggest names in local cinema—Fernando Poe Jr, Joseph Estrada, Nora Aunor, Vilma Santos, and Boots Anson Roa—in cameo roles.

Initially described as Manila Sound, the genre later called Original Pilipino Music (OPM) underwent a gradual process of reinvention. Sunshine Records, a sub-label of Vicor Music, assembled a studio band named Cinderella featuring Yolly Samson that released three significant albums. The first LP, Ang Boyfriend Kong Baduy (My Gaudy Boyfriend), 1974, was a collection of novelty songs and a soft style marketed as the Marshmallow Sound. The song spawned a movie of the same title, directed by Jose Gosiengfiao. Their second LP, Cinderella 2, 1975, featured a song composed by Ernani Cuenco titled “Bato sa Buhangin” (Pebble in the Sand) that became an enduring Filipino ballad and which also led to a movie of the same title, directed by Pablo Santiago. A third LP, T.L. Ako sa Yo (I’m Truly in Love with You), 1975, featuring a new singer, Cecile Colayco, returned the group to their novelty roots before it disbanded.

With the coming of the 1980s, the architects of OPM were gradually outgrowing the adaptive and novelty genres of the Manila Sound. Most notably, a popular cover group named Circus Band had ceased performing in Manila’s nightspots, starting an exodus of its members into the recording industry. The first to go was Basil Valdez who recorded for Blackgold Records, a subsidiary of Vicor Music, the single “Ngayon at Kailanman” (Now and Forever), 1977, a song by George Canseco loosely based on the Diana Ross song “All of My Life.” The Circus Band keyboardist, Boy Katindig, also released a well-received instrumental jazz album titled Midnight Lady for A&W Records International, a subsidiary of Villar Records.

By then, the media czar of the Marcos regime, Teodoro Valencia, had authored a memorandum instructing all radio stations to air three Filipino recordings each hour. He also co-organized the Metropolitan Popular Music Festival in 1978 to stimulate originality in the songwriting field. Winning the grand prize for the premier event was Ryan Cayabyab’s “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful is Our Music), interpreted by Hajji Alejandro of the Circus Band. Interestingly, one finalist of that contest who did not win was Freddie Aguilar, whose composition “Anak” (Child), became the most famous Filipino song in the world. In the following year, another Circus Band alumnus, Ray-An Fuentes, won first place with the song “Umagang Kay Ganda” (Beautiful Morning).

The Golden Age of OPM had begun, ushering in a fresh crop of artists who would define the character of the genre. Leading the throng were the APO (Apolinario Mabini) Hiking Society, which began with a comedic spin in their first two LPs, In Concert #$% *!?, 1974, and Collector’s Item, 1975, but later came up with a more mature repertoire of classic pop singles released by Jem Records, including “Mahirap Magmahal ng Syota ng Iba” (It’s Difficult to Love Someone Else’s Girlfriend), 1976, “Pumapatak ang Ulan” (Rain Is Falling), 1978, and “Lumang Tugtugin” (Old Tune), 1978. In 1985, when the group was already simply known as APO Hiking Society, Danny Javier, one of its members, wrote a song titled “Di na Natuto” (You Never Learn) for Blackgold Records for a gifted young singer named Gary Valenciano. Valenciano’s creativity as a composer and instrumentalist led to a series of LPs and singles for Universal Records, which culminated in the technically innovative album Moving Thoughts, 1988, that featured his original songs like “Sana Maulit Muli” (I Hope It Happens Again) and “Di Bale na Lang” (Never Mind). “Sana Maulit Muli” inspired a movie of the same title, directed by Mike Relon Makiling.

The convergence of musical recordings and film was best exemplified by the singer and actress Sharon Cuneta, dubbed “The Megastar,” whose 40 albums, 53 movies, and 10 television shows were unprecedented. Encouraged by her executive producer Vic del Rosario and aided by songwriters like George Canseco, Willy Cruz, and Rey Valera, Sharon Cuneta movies like Dear Heart, 1981, P.S. I Love You, 1981, Bukas Luluhod Ang Mga Tala (Tomorrow, the Stars Will Fall on their Knees), 1984, Bituing Walang Ningning (Star Without Sparkle), 1985, Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (May It Never End), 1986, and Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 1991, became indistinguishable from her soundtrack hits. Other musical artists took to the fashion, with stars like Kuh Ledesma, Martin Nievera, and Zsa Zsa Padilla being given their own television shows and movies. Songs like “Dito Ba” (Is It Here?), 1980, by Kuh Ledesma, composed by George Canseco; “Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin” (You Are Everything To Me), 1985, by Martin Nievera, composed by Cecile Azarcon-Picazo; and “Ikaw Lamang” (Only You), by Zsa Zsa Padilla, composed by Dodjie Simon, became household hits.

In 1982, the greatest Filipino jazz pianist of his time, Bobby Enriquez, emerged in the American limelight. He performed and recorded with some of the most established masters of the idiom, including the legendary trumpetist Dizzy Gillespie who fondly called him the “wild man from Mindanao.” The monicker stuck because it captured Bobby Enriquez’s unpredictable yet engrossing piano style. Crescendo Records, his record label in the United States, was distributed in the Philippines by Villar Records, and through the latter, his LPs The Wild Man and The Wild Man Meets The Madman became very popular jazz records in Manila.

In 1986, a new wave band called The Dawn released their first eponymous album and single, “Enveloped Ideas,” under OctoArts International, which created much enthusiasm in the Pinoy rock community. Many felt that the group could fill the void left by the Juan de la Cruz band. The Dawn’s second album in 1988, I Stand With You, with the single, “Love Will Set Us Free,” propelled the band to the top of the charts. Unfortunately, the untimely demise that year of its guitarist, Teddy Diaz, momentarily brought its rise to a standstill. After that, the band continued to release albums and remains active until today.

Executive Order No. 255 issued by Pres Corazon Aquino in 1987 stipulated that all local radio stations must air four or more OPM songs per hour. The karaoke sing-along device was also in vogue during this time, and helped propagate the OPM repertoire of songs far and wide. But the Golden Age of OPM reached a plateau towards the 1990s. The Philippine recording industry was in need of new blood. It was then that Francis Magalona, an actor and break-dancer in the 1980s ventured into the flourishing American genre called rap. Incorporating technique and social relevance, he emerged with records titled Yo!, 1990, which became the first commercially released Filipino rap album, and Rap is Francis M, 1992, both under PolyEast Records. His efforts at bringing nationalistic Filipino sensibilities to his field of artistic endeavor earned him a posthumous Presidential Medal of Merit.

In a parallel development, Eraserheads, a band formed in 1991 by students from the University of the Philippines (UP), was rejected at every turn until BMG Records Pilipinas signed the group up for a three-year contract. Their debut record in 1993 called Ultraelectromagneticpop had sold 300,000 copies by the end of the year. The second album in 1994, Circus, sold 200,000 copies, and the third album in 1995, Cutterpillow, was certified Gold prior to release and went on to sell 400,000 copies. All seven albums and four compilation albums of Eraserheads sold out. The group’s success is credited today for having opened the floodgates for alternative music in the Philippines. The character and flavor of alternative music encouraged independent recordings to prosper. The record companies, eager to emulate the success of the Eraserheads, signed dozens of nonmainstream acts like Rivermaya, Parokya ni Edgar, Urbandub, Razorback, and Sponge Cola. Independent commercial and institutional record labels also brought unexpected additions to a growing OPM tradition. Some of these independent labels such as Terno Recordings have created a large niche of their own in the music industry, featuring bands such as Up Dharma Down that released an album called Fragmented in 2006 that merited a a full-page mention in Time Magazine.

Joey Ayala, a native of Davao City, with his group Ang Bagong Lumad, independently released Panganay ng Umaga (Eldest of the Morning) in 1981, a folk album utilizing native Filipino instruments such as the hegalong (two-stringed lute), kubing (mouth harp) and kulintang (gongs of graduated sizes), released commercially by WEA Records in 1991. Ayala, with his sister, singer-songwriter Cynthia Alexander, independently recorded and released an album for the Asian puppet theater Sita at Rama (Sita and Rama), written by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio. In New York, two albums of original works by Jose Maceda were released by the Tzadik record label: Gongs and Bamboos, 2001, and Drone and Melody, 2007. In 2012, Humanfolk, a collaboration between jazz guitarist-composer Johnny Alegre and the New York-based kulintang advocate and percussionist Susie Ibarra, augmented by the talents of Cynthia Alexander and the electronica exponent Malek Lopez, was recorded. Their album, which combined gongs, bamboo, and conventional instrumentation with computer programming, was released by MCA Music Philippines in 2011. Similarly, two albums that have received critical acclaim among peers are the experimental albums Translating the Gongs, 2006, and Out of Tradition, 2014, which were independently recorded and released by guitarist-composer Bob Aves through his own record label, Tao Music.

The UP College of Music produced the records Ang Musika ng mga Kalinga (Kalinga Music), Ang Mga Kulintang sa Mindanao at Sulu (The Kulintang of Mindanao and Sulu), and Kulintang and Kudyapiq. The Asian Institute of Liturgy and Music came out with Buksan Mo ang Aming Labi (Open Our Lips), O, Señor Tagbalay (Oh, Lord of the House), and Mula sa Labi ng Mga Musmos (From the Mouths of Children). The CCP produced Pagdiriwang (Celebration), Messiah, Spectacular, and Blending, and the sarsuwela production kits of Walang Sugat (No Wounds), Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), and Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden). Written by Juan Bautista H. Alegre, with notes from Elmer L. Gatchalian, Milagros P. Carunungan, and Danny Yson

article.value: Records, technically called phonorecords, began with the invention of the phonograph cylinder in 1877 and the gramophone disc in 1881. The earliest records were sold in 1901 in the United States by Victor Company. By 1925, the speed of the record was standardized at 78 RPM (revolutions per minute). In 1948, Columbia introduced the 33 1⁄3 RPM vinyl LP (long-playing) record, and in 1949, the 45 RPM single was introduced by RCA-Victor. These analog discs were supplanted by digital compact discs (CDs) in 1981, co-developed by Phillips and Sony. All musical recordings contained in phonorecords, including those synchronized with film and games, are collectively called phonograms.

According to Danny Yson, an American businessman named Isaac Beck opened a store in 1913 in Manila’s Isaac Peral Street (later renamed United Nations Avenue), which sold 78 RPM discs from Victor Company and their disc player called the Victrola. In the same year, a retired US Army major named William Anderson took the initiative to record Filipino talents. Anderson, who was appointed representative of the Victor Talking Machine Company, created a makeshift studio on the second floor of the Manila Hotel where he began recording songs from the Philippine sarsuwela, the native adaptation of the Spanish zarzuela or lyric theater. Actress Maria Carpena became the first Philippine recording artist. Accompanied by the Molina Orchestra, her song “Ang Maya” (The Sparrow), composed by Jose Estella with lyrics by Severino Reyes, was released by Victor Records in 1913.

In 1925, Isaac Beck became a distributor of Columbia Phonograph Company and became William Anderson’s competitor. Beck put up his own radio station, KZIB, after the release by Columbia Records of two Filipino songs, “Ang Dalagang Pilipina” (Filipina Maiden) and “Paalam sa Pagkadalaga” (Farewell to Maidenhood), which were recorded by the mezzo-soprano Nati de Arellano in the United States. Ironically, by 1929, Arellano transferred to Victor Records and recorded extensively with them. Most notable of these recordings was “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig) by Nicanor S. Abelardo.

In the 1920s, the popularity of bodabil (the Filipino vaudeville) brought to the fore the eclectic talents of Katy de la Cruz, billed equally as “Queen of Vaudeville” and “Queen of Jazz.” She was the highest paid entertainer in the country during her prime and had popularized her trademark art of scat singing. By the 1930s, she would be most identified with the song “Balut” (Duck Egg), a tune written by Jerry Brandy which was a bawdy take on the notorious Filipino culinary delicacy. However, her recorded legacy is the bilingual song “Magtanim ay Di Biro” (Planting Rice Is Never Easy), recorded initially for Filipinos in the United States with the English title “Planting Rice,” which was released by RCA-Victor.

article.value: In the 1930s, the most popular singer was Lilian Velez, who became a celebrated movie actress for LVN Pictures. She is best known for her on-screen rendition of “Sa Kabukiran” (By the Countryside), a theme song composed by her father Manuel P. Velez for a film of the same title. The elder Velez wrote other timeless Philippine songs such as “Lawiswis sa Kawayan” (Swishing Bamboo), “Ako’y Kampupot” (I’m a Jasmine), and “La Cariñosa” (The Affectionate Lady), which was recorded by the Victor Orchestra and released by Victor Records in 1930. The song “Sa Kabukiran” attained a wide Philippine cinematic following and was reinterpreted by Elsa Oria in Sampaguita Pictures’ movie Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star) and by Nora Hermosa in Vista Films’ movie Ang Siloy (The Songbird).

article.value: Songs from the Philippine sarsuwela found a new medium in movies and disc. “Bituing Marikit,” composed by Nicanor S. Abelardo in 1926, became a movie theme and title in 1937 for Sampaguita Pictures. Nicanor S. Abelardo supposedly recorded 16 of his songs for Victor Company, interpreted by various singers such as Nati de Arellano, Pacita de Tavera, and Florentino Ballecer. The most significant of these recordings was “Amorosa” (The Amorous Lady), released by Victor in New York in 1922.

Sylvia La Torre, known as the “Queen of Kundiman,” rose to prominence after World War II when she joined the roster of artists of the Manila Grand Opera House. In 1950, she became a recording artist for the fledgling independent label Bataan Records, with the song “Si Petite Mon Amour” (My Little Love). Later, she transferred to the larger independent Villar Records, where she recorded her hit song “Waray-Waray” (a person from Samar or Leyte), a blues progression with Tagalog lyrics. Villar Records was launched in 1950 by the late Manuel P. Villar, known as the “Father of Philippine Recording,” who had released the first commercial record of the Philippine National Anthem. In the 1960s, Villar Records’ previous success with “Waray-Waray” paved the way for another Tagalog vernacular song with a rock and roll progression, “Hahabol-habol” (Chasing After) by Bobby Gonzales, a singer who became a star on the live musical stage of Manila’s Clover Theater.

Her weekly television show from 1965-72 featured her international hit song “A Million Thanks to You,” composed by Alice Doria-Gamilla and released by Villar Records. She was dubbed “Asia’s Queen of Song” and sang to open the Beatles’ 1966 concert at the Rizal Memorial Stadium. Later on, she transferred to Vicor Music Corporation, a company founded by record industry entrepreneurs Vic del Rosario and Orly Ilacad. Here, she interpreted George Canseco’s early compositions such as “Kapantay ay Langit” (As High as the Sky) issued in the album Philippine Love Songs Vol. 1.

In 1970, a Filipino-American singer-drummer named Joey “Pepe” Smith was discovered during his stint in Tokyo and was invited to join a band named Speed, Glue & Shinki that subsequently released two albums: Eve, 1971, and their eponymous second album, 1972, under Atlantic Records. Prior to his Japanese experience, Smith, with his previous band the Downbeats, was also part of the opening act of the Beatles’ 1966 concert at the Rizal Memorial Stadium. Returning to Manila upon completing his obligations with Atlantic Records, he reinvented himself as Pepe Smith and, consequently, with his colleagues in the Juan de la Cruz Band, invented Pinoy rock. Released by Vicor Music, their comprehensive discography consisted of “Up in Arms,” “Maskara” (Mask), “Super Session,” and “Kahit Anong Mangyari” (Whatever Happens). Pepe Smith’s composition, “Ang Himig Natin” (Our Hymn), defined the character of Pinoy rock for an entire generation.

The avalanche of possibilities in Pinoy rock was multifaceted. In 1977, a rock vocalist named Tessie Alfonso, with stage name Sampaguita, collaborated with an Olongapo-based guitarist, Gary Perez, to write songs for a self-titled LP released by Vicor that combined rock and roll with Tagalog street jargon, as in her single, “Bonggahan” (Revelry). After a long sabbatical, she repeated this formula on her own in 1991 with her single “Nosi Ba Lasi” (Tagalog word play for “Sino Ba Sila?”/Who Are They?), released on cassette tape by RJ Records. Ramon Jacinto, a rock and roll guitarist, singer, and businessman who owned RJ Records and the Rajah Broadcasting Network (DZRJ), had also released his own chart-topping song titled “Muli” (Once More) in the 1980s. A DZRJ favorite, Florante, recorded an album in 1978 titled Mga Tula at Awitin ni Florante (Poems and Songs of Florante) for an independent record label called Jem Recording Company that was received favorably by critics and folk-rock enthusiasts.

In 1976, Jem Recording Company, or simply Jem Records (not to be confused with an American label of the same name), introduced itself to the record-buying public with two prestigious LP album projects—namely, Pinoy Jazz by Eddie Munji III and Pinoy Jazz II: Roots to Routes by Ryan Cayabyab. Both featured modern arrangements of Philippine folk songs. Amid a flurry of mixed reviews, the tracks from the two albums were continually rotated on AM and FM radio.

The new Pinoy jazz genre was quickly supported by Vicor Records and its new subsidiary, Blackgold Records. Two groundbreaking albums by the Filipino bossa nova advocate and composer-pianist Bong Peñera found their place in the pop charts: A Samba Song, 1976, and Batucada sa Calesa (Batucada by the Horse-drawn Cart), 1977. It was also in 1977 that the LP The Jazz Friends was released. It featured Filipino big band performances with saxophonists Lito Molina and Doming Valdez, drummer Tony Velarde, and Manila’s finest jazz musicians, accompanied by music created by the “Godfather of Pinoy Jazz,” Angel Peña.

In an unexpected move, Jem Records issued Buhay Musikero (Musician’s Life), 1976, the first of three Pinoy Rock LPs that propelled Mike Hanopol, the erstwhile singer-composer-bassist of the Juan de la Cruz Band, to the top of the local charts. Hanopol’s themes of hardship, delinquency, greed, and desperation, combined with a refined rock aesthetic, were warmly received. This album was followed by two other LPs released by Blackgold Records—Awiting Pilipino (Filipino Songs), 1977, and Buksan (Open), 1978. Completing the cycle of classic Pinoy rock recordings, the abortive 1973 sessions of a Juan de la Cruz splinter group, Anak Bayan, were eventually released in 1977 in a self-titled LP by A&W Records, a subsidiary of Villar Records. The singles “Jeepney Rock” and “Probinsiyana” (Country Girl) resonated with elements of rock and jazz undertones. Almost as an afterthought, an album by an Olongapo-based band named Maria Cafra, led by guitarist Resty Fabunan, was released in 1978 by Jem Records. The subgenre of music, described as kundiman rock, was both tentative and creative.

In the early to mid-1970s, Vicor Music Corporation and Villar Records were in competition to capture a burgeoning Filipino pop market. Vicor was first in line to heed the demand as Filipino language adaptations of Western songs were crafted. A song by Barbra Streisand, “The Way We Were,” was sung by Rico J. Puno in an adaptation titled “Alaala sa Luneta” (Memories at Luneta), 1973. A song by the Bee Gees, “Charade,” was adapted by Willy Cruz into “Tag-Araw” (Summer), 1974, sung by Hajji Alejandro. The standard song “There Will Never Be Another You” was translated into “Ikaw Pa Rin” (Still You), 1975, by Tito Mina. Villar Records followed suit in 1974 with the release of the LP Unang Kagat (First Bite) and the single, “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You are the Miss Universe of My Life), recorded by the pop-rock band Hotdog. The popularity of the Miss Universe ditty spawned the movie Hotdog: Unang Kagat in 1975, starring the band, with some of the biggest names in local cinema—Fernando Poe Jr, Joseph Estrada, Nora Aunor, Vilma Santos, and Boots Anson Roa—in cameo roles.

Initially described as Manila Sound, the genre later called Original Pilipino Music (OPM) underwent a gradual process of reinvention. Sunshine Records, a sub-label of Vicor Music, assembled a studio band named Cinderella featuring Yolly Samson that released three significant albums. The first LP, Ang Boyfriend Kong Baduy (My Gaudy Boyfriend), 1974, was a collection of novelty songs and a soft style marketed as the Marshmallow Sound. The song spawned a movie of the same title, directed by Jose Gosiengfiao. Their second LP, Cinderella 2, 1975, featured a song composed by Ernani Cuenco titled “Bato sa Buhangin” (Pebble in the Sand) that became an enduring Filipino ballad and which also led to a movie of the same title, directed by Pablo Santiago. A third LP, T.L. Ako sa Yo (I’m Truly in Love with You), 1975, featuring a new singer, Cecile Colayco, returned the group to their novelty roots before it disbanded.

With the coming of the 1980s, the architects of OPM were gradually outgrowing the adaptive and novelty genres of the Manila Sound. Most notably, a popular cover group named Circus Band had ceased performing in Manila’s nightspots, starting an exodus of its members into the recording industry. The first to go was Basil Valdez who recorded for Blackgold Records, a subsidiary of Vicor Music, the single “Ngayon at Kailanman” (Now and Forever), 1977, a song by George Canseco loosely based on the Diana Ross song “All of My Life.” The Circus Band keyboardist, Boy Katindig, also released a well-received instrumental jazz album titled Midnight Lady for A&W Records International, a subsidiary of Villar Records.

By then, the media czar of the Marcos regime, Teodoro Valencia, had authored a memorandum instructing all radio stations to air three Filipino recordings each hour. He also co-organized the Metropolitan Popular Music Festival in 1978 to stimulate originality in the songwriting field. Winning the grand prize for the premier event was Ryan Cayabyab’s “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful is Our Music), interpreted by Hajji Alejandro of the Circus Band. Interestingly, one finalist of that contest who did not win was Freddie Aguilar, whose composition “Anak” (Child), became the most famous Filipino song in the world. In the following year, another Circus Band alumnus, Ray-An Fuentes, won first place with the song “Umagang Kay Ganda” (Beautiful Morning).

The Golden Age of OPM had begun, ushering in a fresh crop of artists who would define the character of the genre. Leading the throng were the APO (Apolinario Mabini) Hiking Society, which began with a comedic spin in their first two LPs, In Concert #$% *!?, 1974, and Collector’s Item, 1975, but later came up with a more mature repertoire of classic pop singles released by Jem Records, including “Mahirap Magmahal ng Syota ng Iba” (It’s Difficult to Love Someone Else’s Girlfriend), 1976, “Pumapatak ang Ulan” (Rain Is Falling), 1978, and “Lumang Tugtugin” (Old Tune), 1978. In 1985, when the group was already simply known as APO Hiking Society, Danny Javier, one of its members, wrote a song titled “Di na Natuto” (You Never Learn) for Blackgold Records for a gifted young singer named Gary Valenciano. Valenciano’s creativity as a composer and instrumentalist led to a series of LPs and singles for Universal Records, which culminated in the technically innovative album Moving Thoughts, 1988, that featured his original songs like “Sana Maulit Muli” (I Hope It Happens Again) and “Di Bale na Lang” (Never Mind). “Sana Maulit Muli” inspired a movie of the same title, directed by Mike Relon Makiling.

The convergence of musical recordings and film was best exemplified by the singer and actress Sharon Cuneta, dubbed “The Megastar,” whose 40 albums, 53 movies, and 10 television shows were unprecedented. Encouraged by her executive producer Vic del Rosario and aided by songwriters like George Canseco, Willy Cruz, and Rey Valera, Sharon Cuneta movies like Dear Heart, 1981, P.S. I Love You, 1981, Bukas Luluhod Ang Mga Tala (Tomorrow, the Stars Will Fall on their Knees), 1984, Bituing Walang Ningning (Star Without Sparkle), 1985, Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (May It Never End), 1986, and Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 1991, became indistinguishable from her soundtrack hits. Other musical artists took to the fashion, with stars like Kuh Ledesma, Martin Nievera, and Zsa Zsa Padilla being given their own television shows and movies. Songs like “Dito Ba” (Is It Here?), 1980, by Kuh Ledesma, composed by George Canseco; “Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin” (You Are Everything To Me), 1985, by Martin Nievera, composed by Cecile Azarcon-Picazo; and “Ikaw Lamang” (Only You), by Zsa Zsa Padilla, composed by Dodjie Simon, became household hits.

In 1982, the greatest Filipino jazz pianist of his time, Bobby Enriquez, emerged in the American limelight. He performed and recorded with some of the most established masters of the idiom, including the legendary trumpetist Dizzy Gillespie who fondly called him the “wild man from Mindanao.” The monicker stuck because it captured Bobby Enriquez’s unpredictable yet engrossing piano style. Crescendo Records, his record label in the United States, was distributed in the Philippines by Villar Records, and through the latter, his LPs The Wild Man and The Wild Man Meets The Madman became very popular jazz records in Manila.

In 1986, a new wave band called The Dawn released their first eponymous album and single, “Enveloped Ideas,” under OctoArts International, which created much enthusiasm in the Pinoy rock community. Many felt that the group could fill the void left by the Juan de la Cruz band. The Dawn’s second album in 1988, I Stand With You, with the single, “Love Will Set Us Free,” propelled the band to the top of the charts. Unfortunately, the untimely demise that year of its guitarist, Teddy Diaz, momentarily brought its rise to a standstill. After that, the band continued to release albums and remains active until today.

Executive Order No. 255 issued by Pres Corazon Aquino in 1987 stipulated that all local radio stations must air four or more OPM songs per hour. The karaoke sing-along device was also in vogue during this time, and helped propagate the OPM repertoire of songs far and wide. But the Golden Age of OPM reached a plateau towards the 1990s. The Philippine recording industry was in need of new blood. It was then that Francis Magalona, an actor and break-dancer in the 1980s ventured into the flourishing American genre called rap. Incorporating technique and social relevance, he emerged with records titled Yo!, 1990, which became the first commercially released Filipino rap album, and Rap is Francis M, 1992, both under PolyEast Records. His efforts at bringing nationalistic Filipino sensibilities to his field of artistic endeavor earned him a posthumous Presidential Medal of Merit.

In a parallel development, Eraserheads, a band formed in 1991 by students from the University of the Philippines (UP), was rejected at every turn until BMG Records Pilipinas signed the group up for a three-year contract. Their debut record in 1993 called Ultraelectromagneticpop had sold 300,000 copies by the end of the year. The second album in 1994, Circus, sold 200,000 copies, and the third album in 1995, Cutterpillow, was certified Gold prior to release and went on to sell 400,000 copies. All seven albums and four compilation albums of Eraserheads sold out. The group’s success is credited today for having opened the floodgates for alternative music in the Philippines. The character and flavor of alternative music encouraged independent recordings to prosper. The record companies, eager to emulate the success of the Eraserheads, signed dozens of nonmainstream acts like Rivermaya, Parokya ni Edgar, Urbandub, Razorback, and Sponge Cola. Independent commercial and institutional record labels also brought unexpected additions to a growing OPM tradition. Some of these independent labels such as Terno Recordings have created a large niche of their own in the music industry, featuring bands such as Up Dharma Down that released an album called Fragmented in 2006 that merited a a full-page mention in Time Magazine.

Joey Ayala, a native of Davao City, with his group Ang Bagong Lumad, independently released Panganay ng Umaga (Eldest of the Morning) in 1981, a folk album utilizing native Filipino instruments such as the hegalong (two-stringed lute), kubing (mouth harp) and kulintang (gongs of graduated sizes), released commercially by WEA Records in 1991. Ayala, with his sister, singer-songwriter Cynthia Alexander, independently recorded and released an album for the Asian puppet theater Sita at Rama (Sita and Rama), written by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio. In New York, two albums of original works by Jose Maceda were released by the Tzadik record label: Gongs and Bamboos, 2001, and Drone and Melody, 2007. In 2012, Humanfolk, a collaboration between jazz guitarist-composer Johnny Alegre and the New York-based kulintang advocate and percussionist Susie Ibarra, augmented by the talents of Cynthia Alexander and the electronica exponent Malek Lopez, was recorded. Their album, which combined gongs, bamboo, and conventional instrumentation with computer programming, was released by MCA Music Philippines in 2011. Similarly, two albums that have received critical acclaim among peers are the experimental albums Translating the Gongs, 2006, and Out of Tradition, 2014, which were independently recorded and released by guitarist-composer Bob Aves through his own record label, Tao Music.

The UP College of Music produced the records Ang Musika ng mga Kalinga (Kalinga Music), Ang Mga Kulintang sa Mindanao at Sulu (The Kulintang of Mindanao and Sulu), and Kulintang and Kudyapiq. The Asian Institute of Liturgy and Music came out with Buksan Mo ang Aming Labi (Open Our Lips), O, Señor Tagbalay (Oh, Lord of the House), and Mula sa Labi ng Mga Musmos (From the Mouths of Children). The CCP produced Pagdiriwang (Celebration), Messiah, Spectacular, and Blending, and the sarsuwela production kits of Walang Sugat (No Wounds), Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), and Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden). Written by Juan Bautista H. Alegre, with notes from Elmer L. Gatchalian, Milagros P. Carunungan, and Danny Yson
