text:
Music organizations are formal or informal associations or societies established by music aficionados or artists to promote appreciation of and support for musical performances, groups, or artists.

 

During the Spanish colonial period, some associations were devoted to the arts in general. The Sociedad de Artes y Oficios was founded in 1869 to propagate the arts, including vocal and instrumental music. The Liceo Cientifico Artistico Literario was founded in 1877 and sponsored occasional literary and musical contests and concerts to serve music lovers and propagate literature and the fine arts. Only political ferment prevented its founders from putting up a conservatory. However, it did publish a journal, the Revista del Liceo Cientifico Artistico y Literario de Manila (Review of the Scientific, Artistic, and Literary Lyceum of Manila). The Sociedad Artistico Literaria de Iloilo was organized in 1893 to hold concerts and theatrical presentations.

On 16 Apr 1885, several musicians met at the Sampaloc residence of Pedro Gruet, upon the behest of Manuel Garrido and Carlos Saco del Valle, to set up Union Artistico Musical. The other musicians included Francisco Domingo and his orchestra director Joaquin Aragon, Eulogio Revilla and his director Florencio Lerma, Bruno Santa Maria and his director Marcelo Adonay, and Carlos Saco del Valle. The league aimed to protect music teachers and cultivate music and art. The Sociedad Musical Filipina de Santa Cecilia was founded in 1888 to improve the quality of music and protect musicians. In November 1891, Marques de Ahumada and Francisco Roxas were elected president and vice-president, respectively. The society presented programs and concerts. The Circulo Musical was founded in 1893 by Cipriano Gonzales in Pandacan to encourage the study of vocal culture and stringed instruments.

Sometime in 1902, Severino Reyes founded the Gran Compañia de la Zarzuela Tagala which featured his sarsuwela productions in the first decade of the 20th century. Among the composers who wrote music for Reyes’s sarsuwela were Fulgencio Tolentino, Crispino Reyes, Gavino Carluen, and Juan S. Hernandez. This group was followed a year after by Hermogenes Ilagan’s Compañia de Zarzuela Tagala or Samahang Zarzuela Geronimo at Ilagan (later Compañia de Zarzuela Ilagan or Samahang Ilagan). Ilagan’s company had its own roster of actors and actresses, performing in Laguna, Bulacan, Bataan, Tayabas and other regions of Luzon. It presented sarsuwela such as Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), Lucha Electoral (Electoral Contest) and Ilaw ng Katotohanan (Light of Truth). Leon Ignacio composed the music for Dalagang Bukid and other Ilagan sarsuwela. Important singers were Casiana de Leon, Maria Carpena, Socorro Basilio, and later, Atang de la Rama.

During the American colonial regime, general artistic societies continued to flourish, but by the 1920s, special musical societies were formed. On 8 Jun 1901, the Centro Artistico was born. It held conferences, contests, concerts, and classes in solfeggio, violin and many other instruments, declamation, oratory, gymnastics, fencing, and drawing. Its officers were Juan Utor Fernando, president; Jose Silos, vice-president; Salvador Natividad, secretary; Tomas Guison, treasurer; and Clemente Jose Zulueta, librarian.

On 5 May 1907, the Philippine Musical Association was formed by Bonifacio Abdon, Marcelo Adonay, Jose A. Estella, Cayetano Jacobe, Vicente Marifosqui, Juan S. Hernandez, Alejandro Francisco, Crispino Reyes, and Tereso Zapata. Its goals were to foster camaraderie among its members, operate a printing press, open a music store, run a music school, and present regular concerts. The Club Euterpe, named after the muse of instrumental music, was founded in June 1907 to hold periodic concerts. Its officers were Filomena Barreto, president; Nena Zamora, vice-president; Lucia Hernandez, secretary; and Amada Arguelles, treasurer.

The famous Asociacion Musical de Filipinas was founded by Jovita Fuentes, Natividad Arellano, Victorina Lobregat, Adelina Gurrea, Bonifacio Abdon, Mamerto Roxas, and Juan Arellano on 3 Aug 1919. It aimed to cultivate good music, extend financial help to needy musicians, feature local compositions in concerts, sponsor visiting performers, and encourage local composers. The association presented the works of Francisco Santiago, Jose Estella, Juan S. Hernandez, and Antonio J. Molina. It also awarded educational grants to finance violinist Jose Vallejo and sopranos Jovita Fuentes and Luisa Tapales, and pianist Jose Maceda.

Specialized music societies included the Manila Chamber Music Society, founded 1921, Choral Art Association, 1930, and the Philippine Society for Chamber Music, 1936. The Manila Chamber Music Society was founded by a string quartet: violinists Bonifacio Abdon and Francisco Avellana, violist Jose Carrion, and cellist Felipe Marin. Chamber groups organized later enlarged the society. The society uniquely functioned without officers and did not collect fees. It was founded to cultivate local music, hone musicians, foster cooperation among musicians, and help deserving artists. It premiered some yet-unheard works of Western composers such as Schubert on 15 May 1924, and engaged Jascha Heifetz, who performed at the Manila Grand Opera House on 5 Apr 1927, and Toti del Monte, who gave a concert in 1931. It also staged operas. On 30 Aug 1936, Benito H. Lopez founded the Philippine Society for Chamber Music that sought to encourage chamber music performance. The society regularly sponsored free concerts featuring both European and Philippine compositions.

The promotion of choral music was enhanced by the Choral Art Association founded by Pacita Nolasco in 1930. The association worked to develop public appreciation of choral music and the teaching of choral singing. It sponsored several concerts featuring Antonio J. Molina’s choral works, such as the choral cycles, sung by the association’s female chorus under the baton of the composer himself. The Pro Arte Trio was a chamber ensemble composed of Ramon Tapales, Regina Feldman, and Jeno von Takacs organized to honor Johannes Brahms on 15 Sep 1933.

As more and more talented composers and performers emerged, so did associations that sought to promote local compositions, expose local talents, foster camaraderie among musicians, protect their welfare, expose the public to Western music, engage foreign artists, and publish notable works. One such group was the National Federation of Music, organized by Rodolfo S. Cornejo on 24 Sep 1933. The Manila Music Lovers’ Society Inc, formed in July 1935, was led by Molina, Alfredo Lozano, and Antonino Buenaventura. It was the only society then that established sister societies in the provinces such as the Peñaranda Music Lovers Society under Felipe Padilla de Leon, and the Cabuyao Music Lovers’ Society under Ramon Batallones, both founded in 1946.

The Philippine Cultural Concerts Society held regular concerts featuring the country’s noted musicians such as coloratura Mercedes Matias-Santiago on 23 Dec 1935, pianist Caridad Jison-Cruz on 15 Jan 1936, violinist Ramon Tapales on 12 Feb 1936, as well as soprano Enya Gonzales, pianist Purificacion Papa, and violinist Rizalina Exconde. The Amihan Musical Society, founded in Jul 1927 by Julianita P. de Loyzaga, aimed to improve operatic or dramatic and chamber music. Among its consultants were Jovita Fuentes, Encarnacion Pilapil, and Maria Mota. In the Visayas, the Iloilo Musical Association was founded by Benito H. Lopez to encourage performances and to build a concert hall.

The Philippine Society of Oriental Culture was founded on 25 Feb 1940 with the support of President Manuel L. Quezon. It aimed to enrich Philippine music, disseminate musico-literary broadcasts, and conduct research on Asian culture. It elected Eulogio Rodriguez, chair; Antonio J. Molina, secretary; and Alfredo Lozano, managing director. During World War II, the Camia Musical Society was organized. Its inaugural program at the Metropolitan Theater on 12 Dec 1943 featured an all-Philippine program. Composed of members of Manila’s elite, the society was headed by Pedro Aunario. After the war, more organizations reflected varied interests. They continued to sponsor performances but became more specialized. There were new organizations of composers, performers, music teachers, music critics, opera lovers, bands, choral groups, and scholarship foundations.

The National Musical Council of the Philippines was founded on 25 Mar 1953 in answer to UNESCO’s call for worldwide understanding of all artistic and literary heritages. The council specified the following objectives: to promote cooperation and understanding among artists, music organizations, and institutions in the Philippines; to revive and conserve Filipino folk music; to encourage musical congresses, festivals, concerts, and other activities; to bring music to the largest number of people; to catalogue, publish, and copy Filipino music; and to collaborate with UNESCO in developing music education. Tapales was elected chair of the executive board composed of Molina as vice-president for music creation; Federico Elizalde, vice-president for music promotion: Julio Esteban Anguita, vice-president for music profession; Candida Bautista, vice-president for music education; Lucrecia R. Kasilag, executive secretary; Trinidad Legarda, treasurer; and Alfredo Lozano, Antonino Buenaventura, Juan Javier, Sr Edgaria, Sr Gunfrida Schneider, Sor Catalina Ledesma, Pilar Lardizabal, and Liwanag Cruz as members. The Council organized the first conference of the Regional Music Commission of Southeast Asia in 1955. It organized the symposium “Musics of Asia” in 1966 and hosted the 1975 Third Asian Composers League Conference Music Festival.

The Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP), a brainchild of Fuentes, was created by the government on 18 Jun 1955. Tasked to promote good music, its Board of Trustees was composed of Fuentes, chair; Isabel Roces, vice-chair; Lucrecia R. Kasilag, secretary; Evelina Kalaw, treasurer; Ramon Tapales, liaison officer; and Liwanag Cruz, Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, and Felipe Padilla de Leon, members. During its almost two decades of existence, the MPFP sponsored operas, including Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), band concerts and competitions, ballet, sarsuwela, and symphony concerts. It commissioned music works and gave out music scholarships.

In Oct 1955, Eliseo M. Pajaro founded the League of Filipino Composers (LFC) under the auspices of the Regional Music Commission of Southeast Asia. The organization brought together the country’s leading composers. Its goals were to cultivate, promote, and propagate its members’ compositions. The LFC, subsidized by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), sponsored the annual Philippine Music Festival featuring its members’ works. It also sponsored composer workshops and seminars, and annual competitions for young composers.

Some organizations specialized in promoting opera. The Manila Opera Company, founded in 1952, staged a dozen productions and invited Arrigo Pola, Luciano Pavarotti’s mentor, to give a series of concerts. Its founding officers were Carmen Plana, president; Pacita Madrigal-Gonzalez, vice-president; Eduardo Visaya, secretary; Fe Claudio, treasurer; A.D. Prescilla, assistant treasurer; and Isabel Padua, Luis Ablaza, and P.E. Domingo, members. In 1969, the Opera Guild of the Philippines was founded by Dalisay Aldaba, Chito Madrigal Vasquez, Eloisa Revilla, Letty Montelibano, Lee Dilworth Dibbie, and Josephine Nicholoff. Its productions of Pagliacci and La Serva Padrona featured an all-Filipino cast directed by Zeneida Amador, with Oscar C. Yatco conducting the Manila Symphony Orchestra. Inactive for a time until revived in 1991 by Imelda Cojuangco, it mounted Verdi’s Rigoletto in 1992, featuring Italians Giorgio Lormi, Tosi Poleri, and Vincenzo Bello, as well as Filipinos Nomer Son, Vicente Antiporda, Gamaliel Viray, Josie Bailen, Luz Galvez, and Edgardo Crisol, with Regalado Jose conducting the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). The guild gives scholarships to young opera talents.

The Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines was founded through the efforts of Sonny Rodriguez and Teodoro Valencia. It restaged Walang Sugat (No Wounds) and Minda Mora in 1971 and 1982, and the opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf) in 1984. It also sponsored sarsuwela-writing contests and produced cassette tapes of Walang Sugat.

The cause of band music was taken up by the Pambansang Samahan ng Mga Banda sa Pilipinas (PASAMBAP) under Felipe Padilla de Leon in 1953. The association worked to unite all bands promote good band music and elevate the standards of band playing. It sought to end the practice of tambakan, a competition for bands that lasted for days, testing the limits of the participants’ physical endurance. The association sponsored festivals, concerts, and contests, and set up the Academy for Band Musicians which gave free music lessons. The PASAMBAP inspired the formation of the Pilipino Bandmasters Association which built a music library and published a newsletter.

The Philippine Choral Society was founded by Liwanag Cruz in 1951. The first professional choral group in the country, it paved the way for other choral groups. Dedicated to the study, performance, and propagation of choral music, it was inactive from 1960 to 1971 but bounced back to life on 21 Mar 1971 with a concert at the CCP.

In 1954, the students of the late Lucia Francisco, professor emeritus of the University of the Philippines College of Music, founded the Lucia Francisco Music Circle to encourage and train gifted piano students. The organization grants scholarships to students between the ages of five and 12. To upgrade music education, the Philippine Society for Music Education (PSME) was organized in 1972. Its officers included Luz Villanueva, Juan P. Ramos, Corazon Maceda, Lucrecia R. Kasilag, Ma. Luisa Navarro, Candida Bautista, Vicente Sales, Vilma Santiago-Felipe, and Crispina Garcia. PSME held symposia and seminars on mass media, legislation, business, and education. It also held lecture-demonstrations on various approaches to music education, particularly for elementary school children. The Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines (PTGP) was organized in 1973 under the auspices of the PSME to encourage and promote professional growth, foster goodwill among teachers, establish a board of accreditation of teachers to raise professional standards, form chapter guilds all over the country, and promote new compositions for the piano. In 1975, the guild passed a code of ethics for its members, which paved the way for accreditation of piano teachers.

In 1960, musicians led by Bienvenido Panganiban of the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music founded the local chapter of Jeunesses Musices of the Philippines (JMOP), which sought to expose young people to music. JMOP aimed to provide an environment conducive to the cultivation of musical taste and stimulation of musical activity. Also in the 1960s, Vicente Sales founded the Pasaknungan Philippines to train young violinists and build a reservoir of artistic talent. The organization originally catered to the children of Government Social Insurance System (GSIS) personnel. In 1970, however, it started accepting children of non-GSIS personnel, mainly from low-income families. Its membership once swelled to around 400. Today, it limits its trainees to 140, from ages six to 19. On Sundays, the children were taught solfeggio in the morning, and violin ensemble and orchestra performance in the afternoon. Since 1981, Pasaknungan Philippines has been funded by the Philippine National Oil Corporation and the CCP, and many of its musicians have gone on to become professional string players in the country’s major symphony orchestras.

The government created the National Music Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA) in 1973 to help discover talent in choral singing, piano, chamber music, family ensemble, and indigenous music. The government declared 26 Nov to 2 Dec National Music Week for Young Artists. With financial help and venue grants from the CCP and support from other organizations, NAMCYA has been holding annual competitions at the district, provincial, regional, and finally, national levels. Contestants must perform foreign as well as local compositions. The NAMCYA has recognized many brilliant young artists, including pianists Jaime Bolipata and Rowena Arrieta, singers Jonathan Velasco and Andion Fernandez, and violinists Joseph Esmilla and Alfonso Bolipata.

Various societies handling administrative management, fund raising, and marketing are behind the success of such major orchestras as the PPO, Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO), National Philharmonic Orchestra (NPO), and Manila Chamber Orchestra (MCO). The Manila Symphony Society (MSS) was founded in 1931, five years after the MSO was organized by Alexander Lippay. The MSO was first supported by the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas. Then the MSS took over planning and projects, bringing MSO performances not only to the theaters but also to the communities and schools in far-flung provinces and schools. MSS paid for the salaries of MSO musicians and musical directors, bought instruments and scores, and invested in promotions. In 1978, the Manila Metropolitan Theater (MET), was reopened and it became the base of the MSO until 1989. Due to financial difficulties, the MSO cancelled its 1988-1989 concert season, and staged its last concert at the Metropolitan Theater in 1989. The orchestra hibernated for a decade, until it was revived by violinist and orchestral conductor Basilio Manalo in 2001. It became known as MSO II, and the directorship was later passed on to Arturo Molina. A major force in its revitalization was the Philippine Research for Developing Instrumental Soloists (PREDIS), founded in 1984 by Manalo, with the aid of Sr Mary Placid of Saint Scholastica’s College, which eventually housed the MSO II from 2001 to 2014. PREDIS aims to develop young instrumentalists who will later supply the needs of the MSO and other orchestras.

In 1960, Redentor Romero founded the NPO. That same year, Romero established the National Philharmonic Society (NPS) to support the cultural programs of the NPO. When the orchestra folded in 1984, the NPS continued to present regular seasons of performances featuring foreign as well as Filipino artists. It has sponsored outreach programs to the provinces and produced recordings of Philippine classics with the London, Royal, and Moscow Philharmonic Orchestras.

The PPO is the only orchestra completely subsidized by the state, specifically, the CCP. It has conducted regular seasons at the CCP Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo (formerly Main Theater) under the directorship of Oscar C. Yatco and other conductors. In 1985, the Philippine Philharmonic Society Inc (PPSI) was formed to extend additional help to PPO members. It launched the Orchestra Endowment Fund in 1987 to handle PPO funds raised through donations and other projects and augments CCP’s allocation to the PPO. The PPSI was later renamed Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra Society, Inc. (PPOSI) in 1996, with the prime objective to promote, enhance and develop the premiere orchestra of the country, whose level of excellence can be comparable with its foreign counterparts.

Unlike the PPO, the Manila Chamber Orchestra (MCO) was fully subsidized in the past by the privately-owned PCI Bank through the MCO Foundation, which later went public in 1990 and included corporate institutions such as the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Co, Philips, Meralco, and IBM. Its annual concert season featured Filipino as well as foreign artists. It was being conducted by Sergio Esmilla Sr until the orchestra’s untimely dissolution in 1993.

In 1991, pianist Ingrid Sala-Santamaria returned to Cebu and, in her capacity as the chair of the Salvador and Pilar Sala Foundation, started a Ten-Year Development Program for the young music talents of the city, with the intention of forming a youth orchestra of a national caliber. It resulted in the founding of the Cebu Youth Symphony Orchestra in 1995, which later became the Peace Philharmonic Philippines in 2000.

Orchestral organizations founded in the 21st century include the Manila Philharmonic Orchestra, founded in 2003 and conducted by Rodel Colmenar, which is the only Filipino orchestra owned and managed by the musicians themselves; San Miguel Foundation Orchestra, founded in 2001 but disbanded in 2007; Metro Manila Community Orchestra, 2000, conducted by Chino Toledo; FILharmoniKA, 2005, originally named Global Studio Orchestra or GC4, conducted by Gerard Salonga; ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra, 2012, also conducted by Gerard Salonga; and the Orchestra of the Filipino Youth, 2013, with Jovianney Emmanuel Cruz as its artistic director.

The Friends of the CCP was founded in 1979 to attract a bigger audience for CCP events. Chito Madrigal was elected president and Lula Dawson vice-president. A heterogeneous group, Friends is composed of people of different nationalities and occupations. It disseminates information on art exhibits, performances, and other cultural events.

Music reviewing and criticism was pursued vigorously in the 1980s with the formation of the Music Critics Guild or Samahan ng Mga Manunuri at Manunulat sa Musika ng Pilipinas (SAMMPI) organized in 1983 by a group of music writers and reviewers led by Exequiel Molina. Officers and members were inducted by then-CCP president Lucrecia R. Kasilag. Founding members were Felipe de Leon Jr, Vilma Santiago-Felipe, Antonio C. Hila, Fe Mangahas, Pablo Tariman, Ana Leah Sarabia de Leon, and Felicidad Z. Reyes. The guild’s goals were to promote music criticism, appreciation of foreign, Philippine, pop, and serious or classical music, and train prospective music writers and critics. On the other hand, the interests of local composers, lyric writers, music publishers, and music copyright owners have been pursued by the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers, Inc (FILSCAP), which was established in 1965 to administer the performing and reproduction rights of its local members based on copyright legislation, and also provide representation for foreign composers, lyricists, and music publishers if agreed upon by similarly constituted societies to which they belong. Members of the FILSCAP included Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucrecia R. Kasilag, Santiago Suarez, Antonio Lustre, Ariston Avelino, Francisco Buencamino Jr, Constancio de Guzman, Antonio Maiquez, Delfin Manlapaz, and Restituto Umali.

A group called KATHA was founded in 1987 to promote the awareness and protection of the rights and privileges of local composers of popular music, as well as to promote camaraderie and a sense of community among its members. It has since held workshops for promising music writers which were conducted by the organization’s founding members, among them Odette Quesada, Ryan Cayabyab, Jim Paredes, Vehnee Saturno, Danny Tan, and Heber Bartolome. Another group of composers, the Asian Composers League-Philippines (ACL-Philippines), whose membership is by invitation only, was founded in 2005, with the aim of supporting and fostering the development of contemporary music works of Filipino composers.

Right after the EDSA Revolt of 1986, the Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP), the Alliance of Artists for the Creation of the Ministry of Culture (AACMC), and the Samahan sa Kultura at Sining (SAKSI) were formed to lobby for the creation of a ministry of culture to administer cultural affairs. In response, the Aquino government created the Presidential Commission for Culture and the Arts (PCCA) under Executive Order (EO) 118, dated 30 Jan 1987. This eventually became the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), by virtue of Republic Act (RA) 7356, passed on 8 Apr 1992. The NCCA was placed directly under the Office of the President solely for budgetary concerns. Its main task was to reconstruct the Filipino national identity by formulating cultural policies and coordinating the activities that promoted the culture of the people.

The Philippine Federation for Choral Music (PFCM), organized in 1996, was geared towards the promotion and appreciation of choral music. Part of its aim was to make choral music a potent force in the development of national culture. However, this organization did not last long. The Philippine Choral Directors Association (PCDA), with almost similar aims as the earlier PFCM, founded in 2008, continued the thrust of gathering choral conductors all over the Philippines. Since its foundation, the PCDA has been actively propagating Philippine choral arts through its annual conventions. In 2014, it hosted the meeting of its international counterpart, the International Federation for Choral Music (IFCM) in Ilocos Norte.

The Philippine Opera Company (POC), founded in 1999, is the only opera company in the country that regularly presents staged drama with music. It has produced operas, sarsuwela, and musicals for the contemporary theater audience. The POC has constructed its own Opera Haus, hailed as the permanent home for classical singers of the Philippines.

The Musicological Society of the Philippines (MSP) was founded in 2002 by Jose Buenconsejo and Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua, with the aim of advancing music scholarship in the country. Its incumbent president is Ramon P. Santos, who has held the position since 2004. The MSP has also hosted various musicological conferences and international music festivals. Moreover, members of the MSP have presented and published papers in related academic societies of the Philippines, notably the Philippine Studies Association.

In the field of popularmusic, several organizations have been formed to promote the welfare of performers and composers. Foremost among these organizations is the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI), successor of the Recording Industry Association of the Philippines (RIAP) which was established in the mid-1960s. Since its inception in 1976, PARI has been active in the supervision of the conduct of the local recording business and the improvement of local record production. Its key responsibility, however, has been to protect legitimate record producers from unscrupulous duplicators or pirates. PARI has duly recognized 32 recording companies as members. Its past presidents include Antonio Lustre (elected 1976) and James Dy (elected 1978). In 1981, Danilo P. Olivares was elected as PARI’s professional or lifetime president.

In 1986, singer Celeste Legaspi spearheaded the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit (OPM), a pioneering association that seriously pursues the proliferation and propagation of Filipino popular music, as well as the improvement, upliftment, and enhancement of the working conditions of both the performers and those directly involved in the singing field (e.g., talent managers, instrumentalists, production assistants, technical and lighting directors, press members). OPM has produced numerous concerts at major entertainment venues. It has also conducted talent development workshops and has granted scholarship awards to deserving new talents. OPM is currently headed by singer and comedienne Mitch Valdes. She was preceded by Celeste Legaspi who served from 1986 to 1988, and composer Jim Paredes who was elected in 1989.

The Jazz Society of the Philippines was launched on 16 Mar 2003, aimed as a venture for jazz loving enthusiasts to get together to enjoy, advance and promote jazz music in the Philippines. Among its founders was the jazz historian, Richie Quirino. Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

article.value: During the Spanish colonial period, some associations were devoted to the arts in general. The Sociedad de Artes y Oficios was founded in 1869 to propagate the arts, including vocal and instrumental music. The Liceo Cientifico Artistico Literario was founded in 1877 and sponsored occasional literary and musical contests and concerts to serve music lovers and propagate literature and the fine arts. Only political ferment prevented its founders from putting up a conservatory. However, it did publish a journal, the Revista del Liceo Cientifico Artistico y Literario de Manila (Review of the Scientific, Artistic, and Literary Lyceum of Manila). The Sociedad Artistico Literaria de Iloilo was organized in 1893 to hold concerts and theatrical presentations.

On 16 Apr 1885, several musicians met at the Sampaloc residence of Pedro Gruet, upon the behest of Manuel Garrido and Carlos Saco del Valle, to set up Union Artistico Musical. The other musicians included Francisco Domingo and his orchestra director Joaquin Aragon, Eulogio Revilla and his director Florencio Lerma, Bruno Santa Maria and his director Marcelo Adonay, and Carlos Saco del Valle. The league aimed to protect music teachers and cultivate music and art. The Sociedad Musical Filipina de Santa Cecilia was founded in 1888 to improve the quality of music and protect musicians. In November 1891, Marques de Ahumada and Francisco Roxas were elected president and vice-president, respectively. The society presented programs and concerts. The Circulo Musical was founded in 1893 by Cipriano Gonzales in Pandacan to encourage the study of vocal culture and stringed instruments.

Sometime in 1902, Severino Reyes founded the Gran Compañia de la Zarzuela Tagala which featured his sarsuwela productions in the first decade of the 20th century. Among the composers who wrote music for Reyes’s sarsuwela were Fulgencio Tolentino, Crispino Reyes, Gavino Carluen, and Juan S. Hernandez. This group was followed a year after by Hermogenes Ilagan’s Compañia de Zarzuela Tagala or Samahang Zarzuela Geronimo at Ilagan (later Compañia de Zarzuela Ilagan or Samahang Ilagan). Ilagan’s company had its own roster of actors and actresses, performing in Laguna, Bulacan, Bataan, Tayabas and other regions of Luzon. It presented sarsuwela such as Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), Lucha Electoral (Electoral Contest) and Ilaw ng Katotohanan (Light of Truth). Leon Ignacio composed the music for Dalagang Bukid and other Ilagan sarsuwela. Important singers were Casiana de Leon, Maria Carpena, Socorro Basilio, and later, Atang de la Rama.

During the American colonial regime, general artistic societies continued to flourish, but by the 1920s, special musical societies were formed. On 8 Jun 1901, the Centro Artistico was born. It held conferences, contests, concerts, and classes in solfeggio, violin and many other instruments, declamation, oratory, gymnastics, fencing, and drawing. Its officers were Juan Utor Fernando, president; Jose Silos, vice-president; Salvador Natividad, secretary; Tomas Guison, treasurer; and Clemente Jose Zulueta, librarian.

On 5 May 1907, the Philippine Musical Association was formed by Bonifacio Abdon, Marcelo Adonay, Jose A. Estella, Cayetano Jacobe, Vicente Marifosqui, Juan S. Hernandez, Alejandro Francisco, Crispino Reyes, and Tereso Zapata. Its goals were to foster camaraderie among its members, operate a printing press, open a music store, run a music school, and present regular concerts. The Club Euterpe, named after the muse of instrumental music, was founded in June 1907 to hold periodic concerts. Its officers were Filomena Barreto, president; Nena Zamora, vice-president; Lucia Hernandez, secretary; and Amada Arguelles, treasurer.

The famous Asociacion Musical de Filipinas was founded by Jovita Fuentes, Natividad Arellano, Victorina Lobregat, Adelina Gurrea, Bonifacio Abdon, Mamerto Roxas, and Juan Arellano on 3 Aug 1919. It aimed to cultivate good music, extend financial help to needy musicians, feature local compositions in concerts, sponsor visiting performers, and encourage local composers. The association presented the works of Francisco Santiago, Jose Estella, Juan S. Hernandez, and Antonio J. Molina. It also awarded educational grants to finance violinist Jose Vallejo and sopranos Jovita Fuentes and Luisa Tapales, and pianist Jose Maceda.

Specialized music societies included the Manila Chamber Music Society, founded 1921, Choral Art Association, 1930, and the Philippine Society for Chamber Music, 1936. The Manila Chamber Music Society was founded by a string quartet: violinists Bonifacio Abdon and Francisco Avellana, violist Jose Carrion, and cellist Felipe Marin. Chamber groups organized later enlarged the society. The society uniquely functioned without officers and did not collect fees. It was founded to cultivate local music, hone musicians, foster cooperation among musicians, and help deserving artists. It premiered some yet-unheard works of Western composers such as Schubert on 15 May 1924, and engaged Jascha Heifetz, who performed at the Manila Grand Opera House on 5 Apr 1927, and Toti del Monte, who gave a concert in 1931. It also staged operas. On 30 Aug 1936, Benito H. Lopez founded the Philippine Society for Chamber Music that sought to encourage chamber music performance. The society regularly sponsored free concerts featuring both European and Philippine compositions.

text:
Patronage refers to the support, encouragement, and financial aid that an agency or an individual grants to another individual or group. Music patronage may come as state, church, private, corporate, or institutional support for composers and musicians.

 

When the Spaniards colonized the Philippine Islands in 1565 and under the system of the Patronato Real, Hispanic cultures were assimilated by the natives in a long process that lasted from the late 16th century to the end of the 19th century. The Catholic Church was the principal patron of music during this time, and it was also the best archivist of works and other colonial cultural productions of the period. European music, used principally as a tool for conversion to Christian beliefs and the promotion of the Spanish crown, dominated the people’s choice for musical productions.

After the opening of the Philippine ports in 1834 and the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869, new forms of cultural activities emerged in urban areas that were no longer entirely dominated by the Spanish church and state. A number of organizations made up of prominent citizens and ilustrados (educated) bonded to form what could be called an incipient “civil society” in the cities. Naturally, owing to their Spanish education, they had a very strong bias towards Western music and art. These organizations were Sociedad de Anonima, established in 1862, Sociedad de Artes y Oficios, 1869, Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario, 1877, Union Artistico Musical, 1885, Sociedad Musical Filipina de Santa Cecilia, 1888, Circulo Musical, 1893, and Sociedad Artistico-Literaria de Iloilo. These associations generally had for their aims one or more of the following: (1) to promote and cultivate all kinds of arts, (2) to maintain and protect the interests of the lovers of music, fine arts, and literature and cultivate aesthetic taste, (3) to protect the common interests of Filipino musicians, (4) to encourage musical education, especially the study of vocal and stringed instruments, and (5) to render literary and musical entertainments, theatrical presentations, and literary and musical contests. These societies sponsored art competitions, produced musical-literary concerts or veladas, and held private tertulias (soirees), which provided a space for music performances.

But even as private organizations sponsored the arts, the Spanish colonial state and church continued to support musical organizations. In the 19th century, the Spanish Regimental Bands gave weekly concerts at Binondo Plaza and later, at the Luneta. Orchestras were maintained by church authorities in the Manila Cathedral and the San Agustin Church in Intramuros. A number of Filipino musicians were trained in these prestigious state- and church-endowed organizations. It was this group of elite musicians who then passed on their musical skills and knowledge to less-privileged Filipinos who played in bands for fiestas, religious processions, and komedya in the provinces. These cultural events were organized by the Comite de Festejos and supported by hermanos y hermanas mobilized by local priests and mayors during annual fiestas.

The American occupation of the Philippines (1898-1940) established a far-reaching public system of education. The secular culture which began to assert itself in the late 19th century intensified in the American period. The American Insular Government sponsored musical groups, most prominent of which was the Philippine Constabulary Band. At this time, the private sector organized and maintained musical societies, sometimes also called music academies because they were offering music lessons. These societies were Manila Dramatic Club, 1898, Music Academy or El Porvenir, 1900, Centro Artistico, 1901, Centro de Bellas Artes, 1902, Centro de Artistas, 1904, The Philippine Musical Association, 1907, Centro Artistico Literario, 1909, Talia Sociedad Dramatica de Aficionados, 1911, UP Conservatory of Music, 1916, Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, 1919, Manila Chamber Music Society, 1921, Circulo Escenico, 1923, Amihan Musical Society, 1927, Choral Art Association, 1930, Iloilo Musical Association, 1930, Manila Music Guild, 1933, National Federation of Music, 1933, Manila Music Lovers’ Society, 1935, Philippine Society for Chamber Music, 1936, Philippine Cultural Concerts Society, 1935, and Philippine Society of Oriental Culture, 1940. Some members of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, specifically the Legardas, became the nucleus of the Manila Symphony Society which supported Alexander Lippay’s Manila Symphony Orchestra beginning 1926.

During the Japanese occupation of the Philippines in 1941-45, Filipino musicians had to assert their “Asian-ness” in line with the official ideology of the “Greater East-Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere.” Some of the musical societies during this period were Camia Musical Society, 1943, Free Philippines Cultural Society, The New Philippine Symphony Society, 1942, and the New Philippine Musical Federation, 1943. In 1943, the latter presented a group of Japanese musicians which performed the “Grand March of the Free Philippines.” Because the Manila Symphony Orchestra did not agree to play for the puppet Philippine government, the Japanese colonizers, with impresario Alfredo Lozano, founded the New Philippine Symphony Orchestra (NPSO). The NPSO presented an all-Filipino music concert at the Metropolitan Theater on 29 Nov 1942, with Felipe Padilla de Leon as conductor. De Leon also composed “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Pilipinas” (Song for the Creation of a New Philippines) and “Dai Atiw ng Kalibapi” (Official March of the KALIBAPI) for the Japanese.

The postwar period was again a time for a rethinking of Filipino values. Foremost among the foundations that emphasized an upliftment of the Filipino musical talent was the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP), established through opera singer Jovita Fuentes’s initiative and created through Republic Act No. 1370 that was signed into law on 12 May 1955 by then-President Ramon Magsaysay. In effect, MPFP was the first government-funded organization that promoted the creation and performance of opera, sarsuwela, and symphonic music, and the creation through commissioning of major musical works. While the MPFP sponsored performances of western operas like La Traviata and Madame Butterfly, it did encourage the creation and performance of Filipino music. The MPFP mounted the premiere production and performance of Felipe de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1957, and, later on, El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1970. It commissioned a sarsuwela from Rosendo Santos, symphonies from Antonino Buenventura and Hilarion Rubio, a violin concerto from Eliseo Pajaro, a concert overture from Vicente Marqueses, and an overture for band from Alfredo Buenaventura. It also funded the activities of the Filipino Youth Orchestra, the Quezon City Philharmonic, and the UP Madrigal Singers. Among the more far-reaching projects the organization started was the radio program Musika ng Lahi (Music of the Race) that featured music of Filipino composers. The MPFP, together with Eugenia Puyat and her industrialist friends, also supported the productions of the Opera Foundation of the Philippines.

Other societies active during this period were the following: Islanders Choral Society, 1948, The Philippine Artists Union, The National Music Council of the Philippines, 1953, Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas, 1943, and The Manila Opera Company, 1953. By the 1970s, the Marcos regime, through the initiative of the then First Lady Imelda Marcos, the “Patroness of the Arts,” provided the needed support for some artists and musicians. After the opening of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1969, the following were established as national companies under the CCP, with the necessary and much-needed state support: Philippine High School for the Arts, 1977, CCP Philharmonic Orchestra, 1973 (renamed Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 1982), CCP Dance Company, 1970 (renamed Ballet Philippines in 1981), UP Madrigal Singers, 1963 (later known as the Philippine Madrigal Singers), Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, 1957, and Opera Company of the Philippines, 1983. The Young Artists Foundation of the Philippines was the arm of the Marcos regime that sent many talented young artists abroad to hone their craft under the best teachers and schools. Many of these musicians are now based abroad. Some of the more renowned scholar-musicians that received state support under YAFP were Rowena Arrieta, Jaime Bolipata, Ramon Bolipata, Jovianney Emmanuel Cruz, Joseph Esmilla, and Cecile Licad.

After 1986, the CCP, under Ma. Teresa E. Roxas and Nicanor Tiongson, implemented a five-point thrust that reoriented the institution’s previous elitist and colonial outlook into one that was decidedly Filipino, democratic, and decentralized, and was supportive of artistic excellence and the promotion of Filipino artists abroad. Instead of just a venue, CCP from 1986 onto the 1990s became a national coordinating center for arts activities throughout the country, thus providing more grants and support to many Filipino artists and arts groups outside of CCP. With CCP’s encouragement, local arts councils were institutionalized, and there were vibrant arts and cultural exchanges between Manila and the provinces. CCP’s Filipino Artists Series regularly featured notable Filipino musical artists performing classical, popular, and alternative music.

In 1990, Executive Order (EO) No 118 created the Presidential Commission on Culture and the Arts under President Cory Aquino. The EO was enacted into law in 1992 and, under Republic Act No. 7356, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) was established. In 1999, through EO No. 80, the CCP, Commission on Filipino Language, National Museum, National Historical Institute (now Commission), National Library, and Records Management and Archives Office, together with representatives from government bodies and cultural workers from the private sector, came together to compose the NCCA, the government entity that creates and coordinates national arts policy. The NCCA, through the subcommittees on the arts, cultural heritage, and cultural communities, and with funds from the National Endowment for Culture and the Arts (NEFCA), funded performances, competitions, researches, publications, and maintenance of cultural capital.

Private corporations also did their share for music patronage. When the Manila Symphony Orchestra, based at the Metropolitan Theatre in Liwasang Bonifacio beginning late 1970s, disbanded in 1989, the string section was absorbed by PCI Bank, which supported what became a fine string orchestra of the period—the Manila Chamber Orchestra under conductor Sergio Esmilla Jr. This orchestra had concert seasons in Francisco Santiago Hall until 1992. Between 2001 and 2007, San Miguel Corporation established and managed the San Miguel Foundation for the Performing Arts. Its cultural groups, the San Miguel Master Chorale and San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra, were among the best performing groups of the time. During its short but productive existence, the SMFPA released several albums, gave member-musicians a much-needed financial boost, and hired one of the country’s renowned musicians, Cipriano “Ryan” Cayabyab, as resident musical director as well as composer and arranger.

Meanwhile, outside of formal institutional patronage, different forms of grassroots communities self-support the production of various types of music that are expressive of subcultural identities and are catalysts for group bonding and affinity. These communities feed on nonmainstream music such as indie, alternative, underground, rock, sound art, jazz, and hip-hop, that are heard in clubs like Conspiracy, a songwriters’ hub; My Bro’s Mustache in Timog and Balete in Kamias for acoustic guitar; Saguijo, Route 196, and 70s Bistro for rock; and Monk’s Inn for jazz.

In this regard, choirs in local churches all over the Philippines share a similar position. Churches do not employ them and thus choirs can be considered private, voluntary associations. However, they are given a space in the church premises to rehearse their songs, and this is already a form of support. In exchange, choirs sing for the churches’ services. Lastly, nongovernment foundations are also a source of support for music. Some are attached to music schools like the PREDIS Chamber Orchestra program of Saint Scholastica’s College, which trains young children in string music; the Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines made up of piano teachers from UP and UST who have organized piano recitals and competitions; and the Music Research Foundation (MUSARFOUND) of the UP College of Music, which provides tuition scholarship and funds for music research and creative works. Another foundation of note is the Francisco Buencamino Sr Music Foundation, Inc, which has been supporting talented musicians. Cecile Licad, being a renowned member of the Buencamino clan, holds regular concerts in the Philippines to partially fund the scholars. Written by Raul C. Navarro

article.value: When the Spaniards colonized the Philippine Islands in 1565 and under the system of the Patronato Real, Hispanic cultures were assimilated by the natives in a long process that lasted from the late 16th century to the end of the 19th century. The Catholic Church was the principal patron of music during this time, and it was also the best archivist of works and other colonial cultural productions of the period. European music, used principally as a tool for conversion to Christian beliefs and the promotion of the Spanish crown, dominated the people’s choice for musical productions.

After the opening of the Philippine ports in 1834 and the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869, new forms of cultural activities emerged in urban areas that were no longer entirely dominated by the Spanish church and state. A number of organizations made up of prominent citizens and ilustrados (educated) bonded to form what could be called an incipient “civil society” in the cities. Naturally, owing to their Spanish education, they had a very strong bias towards Western music and art. These organizations were Sociedad de Anonima, established in 1862, Sociedad de Artes y Oficios, 1869, Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario, 1877, Union Artistico Musical, 1885, Sociedad Musical Filipina de Santa Cecilia, 1888, Circulo Musical, 1893, and Sociedad Artistico-Literaria de Iloilo. These associations generally had for their aims one or more of the following: (1) to promote and cultivate all kinds of arts, (2) to maintain and protect the interests of the lovers of music, fine arts, and literature and cultivate aesthetic taste, (3) to protect the common interests of Filipino musicians, (4) to encourage musical education, especially the study of vocal and stringed instruments, and (5) to render literary and musical entertainments, theatrical presentations, and literary and musical contests. These societies sponsored art competitions, produced musical-literary concerts or veladas, and held private tertulias (soirees), which provided a space for music performances.

But even as private organizations sponsored the arts, the Spanish colonial state and church continued to support musical organizations. In the 19th century, the Spanish Regimental Bands gave weekly concerts at Binondo Plaza and later, at the Luneta. Orchestras were maintained by church authorities in the Manila Cathedral and the San Agustin Church in Intramuros. A number of Filipino musicians were trained in these prestigious state- and church-endowed organizations. It was this group of elite musicians who then passed on their musical skills and knowledge to less-privileged Filipinos who played in bands for fiestas, religious processions, and komedya in the provinces. These cultural events were organized by the Comite de Festejos and supported by hermanos y hermanas mobilized by local priests and mayors during annual fiestas.

The American occupation of the Philippines (1898-1940) established a far-reaching public system of education. The secular culture which began to assert itself in the late 19th century intensified in the American period. The American Insular Government sponsored musical groups, most prominent of which was the Philippine Constabulary Band. At this time, the private sector organized and maintained musical societies, sometimes also called music academies because they were offering music lessons. These societies were Manila Dramatic Club, 1898, Music Academy or El Porvenir, 1900, Centro Artistico, 1901, Centro de Bellas Artes, 1902, Centro de Artistas, 1904, The Philippine Musical Association, 1907, Centro Artistico Literario, 1909, Talia Sociedad Dramatica de Aficionados, 1911, UP Conservatory of Music, 1916, Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, 1919, Manila Chamber Music Society, 1921, Circulo Escenico, 1923, Amihan Musical Society, 1927, Choral Art Association, 1930, Iloilo Musical Association, 1930, Manila Music Guild, 1933, National Federation of Music, 1933, Manila Music Lovers’ Society, 1935, Philippine Society for Chamber Music, 1936, Philippine Cultural Concerts Society, 1935, and Philippine Society of Oriental Culture, 1940. Some members of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, specifically the Legardas, became the nucleus of the Manila Symphony Society which supported Alexander Lippay’s Manila Symphony Orchestra beginning 1926.

During the Japanese occupation of the Philippines in 1941-45, Filipino musicians had to assert their “Asian-ness” in line with the official ideology of the “Greater East-Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere.” Some of the musical societies during this period were Camia Musical Society, 1943, Free Philippines Cultural Society, The New Philippine Symphony Society, 1942, and the New Philippine Musical Federation, 1943. In 1943, the latter presented a group of Japanese musicians which performed the “Grand March of the Free Philippines.” Because the Manila Symphony Orchestra did not agree to play for the puppet Philippine government, the Japanese colonizers, with impresario Alfredo Lozano, founded the New Philippine Symphony Orchestra (NPSO). The NPSO presented an all-Filipino music concert at the Metropolitan Theater on 29 Nov 1942, with Felipe Padilla de Leon as conductor. De Leon also composed “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Pilipinas” (Song for the Creation of a New Philippines) and “Dai Atiw ng Kalibapi” (Official March of the KALIBAPI) for the Japanese.

The postwar period was again a time for a rethinking of Filipino values. Foremost among the foundations that emphasized an upliftment of the Filipino musical talent was the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP), established through opera singer Jovita Fuentes’s initiative and created through Republic Act No. 1370 that was signed into law on 12 May 1955 by then-President Ramon Magsaysay. In effect, MPFP was the first government-funded organization that promoted the creation and performance of opera, sarsuwela, and symphonic music, and the creation through commissioning of major musical works. While the MPFP sponsored performances of western operas like La Traviata and Madame Butterfly, it did encourage the creation and performance of Filipino music. The MPFP mounted the premiere production and performance of Felipe de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1957, and, later on, El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1970. It commissioned a sarsuwela from Rosendo Santos, symphonies from Antonino Buenventura and Hilarion Rubio, a violin concerto from Eliseo Pajaro, a concert overture from Vicente Marqueses, and an overture for band from Alfredo Buenaventura. It also funded the activities of the Filipino Youth Orchestra, the Quezon City Philharmonic, and the UP Madrigal Singers. Among the more far-reaching projects the organization started was the radio program Musika ng Lahi (Music of the Race) that featured music of Filipino composers. The MPFP, together with Eugenia Puyat and her industrialist friends, also supported the productions of the Opera Foundation of the Philippines.

Other societies active during this period were the following: Islanders Choral Society, 1948, The Philippine Artists Union, The National Music Council of the Philippines, 1953, Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas, 1943, and The Manila Opera Company, 1953. By the 1970s, the Marcos regime, through the initiative of the then First Lady Imelda Marcos, the “Patroness of the Arts,” provided the needed support for some artists and musicians. After the opening of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1969, the following were established as national companies under the CCP, with the necessary and much-needed state support: Philippine High School for the Arts, 1977, CCP Philharmonic Orchestra, 1973 (renamed Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 1982), CCP Dance Company, 1970 (renamed Ballet Philippines in 1981), UP Madrigal Singers, 1963 (later known as the Philippine Madrigal Singers), Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, 1957, and Opera Company of the Philippines, 1983. The Young Artists Foundation of the Philippines was the arm of the Marcos regime that sent many talented young artists abroad to hone their craft under the best teachers and schools. Many of these musicians are now based abroad. Some of the more renowned scholar-musicians that received state support under YAFP were Rowena Arrieta, Jaime Bolipata, Ramon Bolipata, Jovianney Emmanuel Cruz, Joseph Esmilla, and Cecile Licad.

After 1986, the CCP, under Ma. Teresa E. Roxas and Nicanor Tiongson, implemented a five-point thrust that reoriented the institution’s previous elitist and colonial outlook into one that was decidedly Filipino, democratic, and decentralized, and was supportive of artistic excellence and the promotion of Filipino artists abroad. Instead of just a venue, CCP from 1986 onto the 1990s became a national coordinating center for arts activities throughout the country, thus providing more grants and support to many Filipino artists and arts groups outside of CCP. With CCP’s encouragement, local arts councils were institutionalized, and there were vibrant arts and cultural exchanges between Manila and the provinces. CCP’s Filipino Artists Series regularly featured notable Filipino musical artists performing classical, popular, and alternative music.

In 1990, Executive Order (EO) No 118 created the Presidential Commission on Culture and the Arts under President Cory Aquino. The EO was enacted into law in 1992 and, under Republic Act No. 7356, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) was established. In 1999, through EO No. 80, the CCP, Commission on Filipino Language, National Museum, National Historical Institute (now Commission), National Library, and Records Management and Archives Office, together with representatives from government bodies and cultural workers from the private sector, came together to compose the NCCA, the government entity that creates and coordinates national arts policy. The NCCA, through the subcommittees on the arts, cultural heritage, and cultural communities, and with funds from the National Endowment for Culture and the Arts (NEFCA), funded performances, competitions, researches, publications, and maintenance of cultural capital.

Private corporations also did their share for music patronage. When the Manila Symphony Orchestra, based at the Metropolitan Theatre in Liwasang Bonifacio beginning late 1970s, disbanded in 1989, the string section was absorbed by PCI Bank, which supported what became a fine string orchestra of the period—the Manila Chamber Orchestra under conductor Sergio Esmilla Jr. This orchestra had concert seasons in Francisco Santiago Hall until 1992. Between 2001 and 2007, San Miguel Corporation established and managed the San Miguel Foundation for the Performing Arts. Its cultural groups, the San Miguel Master Chorale and San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra, were among the best performing groups of the time. During its short but productive existence, the SMFPA released several albums, gave member-musicians a much-needed financial boost, and hired one of the country’s renowned musicians, Cipriano “Ryan” Cayabyab, as resident musical director as well as composer and arranger.

Meanwhile, outside of formal institutional patronage, different forms of grassroots communities self-support the production of various types of music that are expressive of subcultural identities and are catalysts for group bonding and affinity. These communities feed on nonmainstream music such as indie, alternative, underground, rock, sound art, jazz, and hip-hop, that are heard in clubs like Conspiracy, a songwriters’ hub; My Bro’s Mustache in Timog and Balete in Kamias for acoustic guitar; Saguijo, Route 196, and 70s Bistro for rock; and Monk’s Inn for jazz.

In this regard, choirs in local churches all over the Philippines share a similar position. Churches do not employ them and thus choirs can be considered private, voluntary associations. However, they are given a space in the church premises to rehearse their songs, and this is already a form of support. In exchange, choirs sing for the churches’ services. Lastly, nongovernment foundations are also a source of support for music. Some are attached to music schools like the PREDIS Chamber Orchestra program of Saint Scholastica’s College, which trains young children in string music; the Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines made up of piano teachers from UP and UST who have organized piano recitals and competitions; and the Music Research Foundation (MUSARFOUND) of the UP College of Music, which provides tuition scholarship and funds for music research and creative works. Another foundation of note is the Francisco Buencamino Sr Music Foundation, Inc, which has been supporting talented musicians. Cecile Licad, being a renowned member of the Buencamino clan, holds regular concerts in the Philippines to partially fund the scholars. Written by Raul C. Navarro
