text:
Sections

The Spanish Colonial Period (1500-1900)
The American Colonial Period (1900-50)
The Period of the Republics (1946-2014)

Music research or musicology, the science of music, is concerned with the study of oral or written music in its cultural context. As a scholarly discipline in the university, musicology did not exist in the Philippines before 1950, although inquiries into the subject of Philippine music had begun much earlier, as seen in the works of intellectuals like Pedro Paterno, Fernando Canon, Epifanio de los Santos, Raymundo Bañas, Norberto Romualdez, and Alfredo Roa. There is much material prior to 1950 which may not be technically “musicological” or “ethnomusicological” but is of great value to the music scholar and historian. The material includes accounts in journals, magazines, newspapers, monographs, books, and related studies written mostly by anthropologists, linguists, folklorists, and cultural historians. Information can also be gleaned from the writings of early explorers, travelers, missionaries, and civil servants.

 

The Spanish Colonial Period (1500-1900)

 

The principal sources of information on music of this period are the historical chronicles and travelogues by Spanish friars or government officials. Although dealing primarily with military conquest, government, administration, or Christian conversion, the vast assortment of documents, including letters, maps, statistics, narrations, and descriptions, occasionally mention music. Although the information is not detailed, it gives scholars a historical perspective.

 

Antonio Pigafetta’s Primo Viaggio Intorno al Mondo (First Voyage Around the World), 1536, an account of the first voyage around the world led by Magellan from 1519 to 1522, contains what is probably the earliest written mention of music in the Philippines: a gong-drum ensemble in Cebu, the use of gongs and bamboo trumpets in a ritual ceremony, and the use of gongs and songs in a water festival.

An account of the Franciscan mission in the Philippines, Historia de las Islas del Archipielago (History of the Islands of the Archipelago), 1601, by Fray Marcelo de Ribadeneira mentions the teaching of canto llano (Gregorian Chant), canto d’organo (polyphony), organ, flute, violin, and clarions to young boys in Camarines. Subsequent chronicles of the Franciscan mission, like the Estatutos y Ordenaciones (Statutes and Decrees), 1732, and Chronicas (Chronicles) 1738, 1741, and 1744, mention the beneficial results of the 1573 mandate to establish schools for boys in towns. Detailed descriptions of the Franciscan schools enumerate the functions and duties of singers and single out the efforts of Frs Geronymo Aguilar, Pedro Bautista, and Juan de Santa Marta. The latter headed a school of 400 boys in Lumbang, Laguna. Jesuits Fr Pedro Chirino’s Relacion de las Islas Filipinas (Account of the Philippine Islands), 1604, and Fr Pedro Murillo Velarde’s Historia de la Provincia de Philipinas de la Compania de Jesus (History of the Province of the Philippines of the Society of Jesus), 1749, and Geographica Historia de las Islas Philipinas (Geographic History of the Philippine Islands), 1752, carry descriptions of indigenous music—drums and bells used during sacrificial rituals, bells in important announcements and epics containing genealogies, and musical instruments like the cutyapi or coryapi, bangsi, nose flute, harpa, rabel, and guitarra in burial and wake ceremonies, as well as Western music as embodied in the choirs, the organ-playing during mass, the church celebrations during feasts, and the abundance of violinists, flutists, and oboists in towns.

 

Francisco Combes’s Historia de Mindanao e Jolo (History of Mindanao and Jolo), 1667, and William Dampier’s A New Voyage Round the World, 1729, describe native instruments like the agun, guimbao, kulintangan and their uses during ceremonies. Dr John Francis Careri’s A Voyage Round the World, 1732, describe responsorial singing of successive stanzas of a song to the accompaniment of a metal drum, the practice of sounding drums and other instruments during an eclipse to fight away the dragon who swallows the moon, and shamans called catalonan among the Tagalog and babaylan among the Visayan.

Juan de la Concepcion wrote in Historia General de las Islas Filipinas (General History of the Philippine Islands), 1788-1792, of the Filipino’s ease and facility in playing instruments. The remark was echoed by many other writers such as Franciscan Juan de Medina, who wrote in 1630 that there were very good singers in Manila, and Fray Francisco de Santa Ines, who wrote in 1676 that there were types of music in the Philippines that could rival those of the cathedrals in Spain.

 

Around 1750, Fray Juan J. Delgado mentioned Palawan indigenous music accompanied by dancing and singing, improvised responsorial singing called cauitaan and siray, music used in rites for the sick and the dead, and various types of wood used in making instruments. After 1750, much more published material—compilations of historical documents by religious, military, and civil servants, and a growing number of travelogues—described local musical practices. Captain Thomas Forrest’s A Voyage to New Guinea and the Moluccas, 1779, mentioned gongs with knobs from Java called kallintang, as well as gongs without knobs from China. He included the text, with translation, of a leader-chorus type of rowing song called “Maguindanao Mangaio.”

Fr Joaquin Martinez de Zuñiga’s Mis Viajes por este Pais en 1800 (My Voyages in this Country in 1800), 1893, contained descriptions of songs, dances, and literary works of Lipa, Batangas, and church choirs in Manila singing “Kyrie,” “Credo,” and “Gloria.” He also described Filipinos as fast learners in any art form. Furthermore, Fr Martinez described the kundiman as a song-dance genre—it only became a “mere” song about love in the late 19th-early 20th century. Kundiman as a song-dance genre was confirmed in Jose Honorato Lozano’s drawing, supplemented by prose description and transcription, which appeared in Gervasio Gironella’s illuminated manuscript titled Album: Vistas de las Yslas Filipinas y Trages de sus Abitantes (Album: Views of the Philippine Islands and the Clothing of their Inhabitants), 1847.

 

In his account of a Voyage to Peking and Manila Between the Years 1784-1801, M. de Guignes described balls in Manila where fandango, bolero, and minuet were danced. Young ladies in Manila, he wrote, also sang and played the piano. Adolfo Puya Ruiz also noted in Filipinas: Descripcion General de la Provincia de Bulacan (Philippines: General Description of the Province of Bulacan), 1838, that most women knew how to play the piano, harp, bajo or bandolon (smaller guitar with 24 metal strings), and bamboo flute, and that they danced the pandanggo, jota, and balitaw, though the more educated preferred waltz, polka, habanera, rigodon, and lanceros. Informe Sobre el Estado de las Islas Filipinas en 1842 (Information on the State of the Philippine Islands in 1842) by Sinibaldo de Mas cited an organ made of bamboo and told of the manufacture of harps and guitars.

The 19th century saw the publication of a number of travel accounts in English, including those by Otto Kotzebue, 1821; John White, 1823; A.M. Stewart, 1831; Abbey Jane Morrell, 1829-1833; Sir Edward Belcher, 1848; Frank S. Marryat, 1848; George Windsor Earl, 1853; Paul Proust de la Gironiere, 1854; Karl Scherzer, 1857-9; Henry T. Ellis, 1859; John Bowring, 1859; and Feodor Jagor, 1873. The descriptions of music showed how quickly Filipinos assimilated Spanish customs and practices. The educated urban upper class sang Andalucian songs and danced Spanish dances. Ellis wrote that the harp was “the instrument of the country.” Jagor described instruments such as the bamboo zither, baringbau, and bamboo mouth harp as similar to those of the Mintras of the Malay peninsula.

Many other travelogues were published in Spanish. Some were in French. M.G.L. de Rienzi and Gabriel Lafond, in 1836 and 1844, respectively, both wrote of the Filipino’s love for music and their assimilation of European musical forms. Francisco Michelina y Rojas in 1843 described the elegant balls held in Manila homes. Jean Baptiste Mallat in 1846 described the corrido, comintang de la conquista, sinanpablo, batangueño, and cavitegan. He mentioned the viguela (guitar with many strings) as a favorite instrument, the bandolon, and a large bajo de viguela.

Jean de Man in 1875 described Manila theaters and mentioned the visit of an Italian opera troupe. Joseph Earle Stevens in 1909 described in more detail musical life in Manila and nearby environs in 1893-6. Francisco Cañamaque in 1877 echoed the much repeated observation of the Filipinos’ talent for assimilation. Other travellers who went further north or south briefly described indigenous music there. Manuel Scheidnagel in 1878 had terse descriptions of the gansa (flat gong), sulibao (cone-shaped drum), and paggong (three-holed flute) of northern Luzon. Joseph Montano in 1886, who travelled in 1879, described a quartet of ophicleide, guitar, and two flutes in connection with rice planting in Abucay, and the agun, kulintang, and various dances in the south. Juan Alvarez Guerra’s De Manila a Tayabas (From Manila to Tayabas), 1878, and Manuel Sastron’s Filipinas, Pequeños Estudios de Batangas (Philippines, Short Studies on Batangas), 1895, described the kumintang. However, Pedro Paterno went into more detail in El Individuo Tagalo y Su Arte (The Tagalog and his Art), 1893. He defined the kumintang, which originated from Balayan, Batangas, as an old type of melody with rhythms appropriate for Tagalog poetry, compared the kumintang of old with the “modern,” and included the text of a kumintang. Paterno called the kundiman the Filipino love song and also included a sample text, and described the balitaw as a national dance. The descriptive essay also mentioned the harp as well as older instruments such as the bamboo nose flutes and bamboo zithers. Paterno published a music transcription of these genres, along with an original composition by his sister Dolores, in a collection titled Musica de la Antigua Civilicacion Filipina published in Madrid, 1887.

The last quarter of the 1800s saw accounts of customs and traditions more specialized than the earlier travelogues. Alexander Schadenberg travelled in southern Mindanao and northern Luzon. In Zeitschrift fur Ethnologie (Yearbook for Ethnology), 1885-7, he described Bagobo, Tinguian, and Guianen musical instruments and their uses, citing the Bagobo agun (gong), plandong (flute), zuglum (two-stringed boat lute), and togo (bamboo zithers). He also described the Tinguian nose flute, boleton (bamboo zither), dedeco (bamboo panpipes), and buncacan (bamboo buzzer). In his 1887 Zeitschrift, he described the instruments of the Guianen (Kalinga)—panpipes, bamboo zither, bamboo buzzer, nose flute, and bronze mouth harp—likening them to the Tinguian’s. His ethnographic collections were presented to the Rijks Ethnographisch Museum in Leyden, the Staatliches Museum für Völkerkunde, Vienna, and the Dresden Staatliches Museum für Tierkunde und Völkerkunde.

Similar studies included those by Francisco Villa, 1882; Jose Maria Ruiz, 1887; Buenaventura Campa, 1894; Enrique Polo de Lara, 1897; and Ramon Reyes Lala, 1898. Ferdinand Blumentritt’s Versuch einer Ethnographie der Philippinen (Research on the Ethnography of the Philippines), 1882, cited musical instruments, songs, or dances of the Aeta (zither, guitarre), Tagalog (kumintang, talindao), Ilongot, Tinguian, Catalongan, Bikol, Visaya, Mindanao, and Sulu (kulintangan). Jose Tenorio’s account of religious and other customs (e.g., marriage, death) of his people, the Tiruray, was translated to Spanish as Costumbres de los Indios Tirurayes (Customs of the Tiruray Natives), 1892.

Manuel Walls y Merino authored a monograph, La Musica Popular de Filipinas (Popular Music of the Philippines), 1892, containing descriptions and musical transcriptions of vocal forms such as pasyon, kumintang, kundiman, remeros, and popular dances like the kuratsa, pandanggo, jota valenciana, and balitaw.

 

The American Colonial Period (1900-50)

 

Published accounts with reference to music became more numerous during the American colonial period. Main sources of information were studies of various linguistic groups by anthropologists, ethnologists, folklorists, and linguists, some of whom wrote special studies on Philippine music. Anthropological researches most often cited for their information on indigenous music include William A. Reed’s Negritos of Zambales, 1904; Emerson B. Christie’s Subanons, 1909; Fay Cooper-Cole’s Tribes of Davao District, 1913, The Tingguians, 1915, and Bukidnon, 1956; Albert E. Jenks’ Bontoc Igorot, 1906; Otto Scheerer’s Nabaloi, 1905, and Kalinga, 1921; James Alexander Robertson’s Igorots of Lepanto, 1914; Henry Hall’s Bagobo, 1916; Laura Benedict’s Bagobo, 1916; Roy F. Barton’s Kalingas, 1949; Claude Russell Moss’s Nabaloi and Kankanai, 1920; John Garvan’s Manobos, 1931; Alphonse Claerhoudt’s Igorots, 1925-1930; Morice Vanoverbergh’s Isneg, 1932; Dean Worcester’s Non-Christian Tribes of N. Luzon, 1906-1912; Fletcher Gardner’s Mangyans and H. Otley Beyer’s Philippine folklore, Customs and Beliefs, both in 1922; and various studies on the peoples of northern Luzon such as Francis Lambrecht’s Ifugao, 1932, Samuel Kane’s Ifugao, 1933, and Lawrence L. Wilson’s Ilonggot, Apayao, 1947, and Kankanay, 1953.

Cole’s The Tingguians, 1922, contained an analysis and transcription of 35 sample songs by Albert Gale. Frances Densmore wrote “The Music of the Filipinos,” which appeared in the American Anthropologist in 1906, and did an earlier study on scale formation in Philippine music of the Aeta, Ifugao, Maguindanaon, and Maranao, based on information gathered from participants of the 1904 Saint Louis International Exposition. In 1919, Moss and A.L. Kroeber’s “Nabaloi Songs,” which was published in American Archaeology and Ethnology, compared their findings with Densmore’s and included a transcription of 10 songs, with attention to intervals, and rhythmic and scale patterns.

Norberto Romualdez, a judge who travelled all over the Philippines collecting music and musical instruments as a hobby, wrote Filipino Musical Instruments and Airs of Long Ago, 1932, the earliest known compilation of data on Philippine musical instruments done by a Filipino. It contained descriptions of 18 instruments, sketches, photographs, and short musical notations of some melodies. The work was reprinted in Zoilo M. Galang’s Encyclopedia of the Philippines, 1935, and much of its data appeared in Chapter 2 of Raymundo Bañas’s The Music and Theater of the Filipino People, 1924, which was reprinted as Pilipino Music and Theater, 1970. Aside from the chapter on instruments, Bañas included descriptions of indigenous Philippine music, and details of music, musicians, and their society in Manila at the turn of the 19th and up to the early 20th centuries.

The most comprehensive collection of source material on the Philippines is the 55-volume Philippine Islands, 1493-1898, 1903-1909, edited by Emma Helen Blair and James Alexander Robertson. Volume 53 contains a 419-page bibliography with its own index of authors, while volumes 54 and 54, with their numerous cross-references, comprise the index. Wenceslao Emilio Retana’s significant compilations include the three-volume Aparato Bibliografico de la Historia General de Filipinas (Bibliographic Apparatus of the General History of the Philippines), 1906, which chronologically lists down about 2,700 items preceded by an introduction about bibliographies and collections of Philippine materials, and the five-volume Archivo del Bibliofilo Filipino (Archive of the Filipino Bibliophile), 1895-1905, which lists unpublished manuscripts and rare printed items.

The era saw more articles on various aspects of music which, although written in a popular rather than scholarly vein, shed light on how musicians and music lovers of the time thought, and offered insights and valuable information on indigenous and Western-influenced Philippine music. Most outstanding contributors to the literature included Antonio J. Molina, A.V.H. (Abram Von Heymingen) Hartendorp, Charles Griffith, Felipe Padilla de Leon, and Maximo Ramos. Molina’s mimeographed compilation, Philippine Music - Partial List of Articles, Essays, Researches, Materials for Study of Philippine Music, dated 29 Apr 1967, included 46 of his own articles, essays, and speeches, and 27 studies by his students. Molina covered a wide range of topics, including biographical sketches of Filipino musicians like Marcelo Adonay and Ladislao Bonus, discussions on Philippine music education, folk songs, the rondalla, church music, and musicians.

Many undergraduate and graduate theses did not deal directly with Philippine music, but with related subject matter (e.g., literature, folklore, epics, aspects of Western music). One of the earliest studies was Francisca Reyes-Tolentino’s (later Aquino) master of arts thesis, 1926, for the University of the Philippines (UP), which was expanded to become several editions and volumes on Philippine folk dances.

 

The Period of the Republics (1946-2014)

 

Systematic studies on Philippine music began in the 1950s. The most extensive research on Philippine music was done by Jose Maceda at the Department of Music Research (DMR, presently called Department of Musicology) of the UP College of Music. Titled An Ethnomusicological Survey of the Philippines, it began with researches done in the field by Maceda on the Hanunuo in 1952, Kalinga in 1953, Maguindanaon and Tiruray in 1954, Tagbanwa in 1956, and Ibaloy in 1960. He continued his research in the 1960s and 1970s, with modest financial support from the University Social Science Research Center, National Science Research Council, and the Council for Living Traditions. From 1985 to 1989, the Ford Foundation supported continuing research, including field work and laboratory work. The UP now has the largest and most representative scientific collection of Philippine music and the only one of its kind in Southeast Asia. It has 2,500 hours of music on tape from 51 ethnolinguistic groups, field notes, musical instruments, photographs, text transcriptions and translations, and music transcriptions.

From this material, students and research assistants of the DMR conducted special studies in the 1970s and 1980s: “A Distribution of Polychordal Bamboo Zithers,” “Scale Formation of Bamboo Zither Instruments,” “Occasions for Music among the Tagalog,” “Scales in Two-stringed Boat Lutes,” “The Sanghiyang Ritual of Cavite,” “Life Cycle of the Kalinga in Relation to Music,” “Ifugao Musical Terms,” “Tunings of the Kulintang,” “Classification of Flutes,” “Classification of Philippine Vocal Music,” “Tunings of 15 Bamboo Zithers,” and “Classification of Music of the Kalinga, Bontok, Cebuano, Ilocano, and Bicol.”

Musika Jornal I, 1977, II, 1978, and III, 1980, and Mga Paminsanang Sulatin sa Pananaliksik sa Musika (Periodic Notes on Music Research), 1988, were published for school teachers, professionals, and students. Specialized articles on music in these journals include “Ang Musika ng Yakan sa Basilan” (The Music of Yakan in Basilan); “Ang Musikang Tagalog” (The Tagalog Music); “Udlot-Udlot: Tugtugin para sa Libo-libong Tao” (Udlot-Udlot: Music for a Thousand Performers); “Mga Ilang Tala Ukol sa Musika ng mga Ifugao” (Some Notes on the Music of the Ifugao); “Ang Musikang Pantinig ng mga Ayta Magbukun” (The Vocal Music of the Ayta Magbukun); “Ang Musika sa Pilipinas sa ika-19 na Daangtaon” (Philippine Music in the 19th Century); “Ang Musika ng mga Bontok Igorot sa Sadanga” (The Music of the Bontok Igorot in Sadanga); “Musikang Pangritwal ng mga IbaIoy” (Ritual Music of the Ibaloy); and “Ang Musikolohiya sa Pilipinas” (Musicology in the Philippines).

The DMR prepared educational materials such as A Manual for Field Research with Special Reference to Southeast Asia, edited by Jose Maceda, and Poster Set of Philippine Musical Instruments, edited by Corazon C. Dioquino. The DMR also issued several music discs with corresponding annotations: Ang Kulintang sa Mindanao at Sulu (The Kulintang in Mindanao and Sulu), 1977; Ang Musika ng mga Kalinga (The Music of the Kalinga), 1978; The Music of the Kenya and Modang in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, 1979; Filippiny, 1981, published in Poland in cooperation with the DMR; and Kulintang and Kudyapiq, 1988. In addition, the DMR prepared two documentary films: The Music of the Buwaya, Kalinga and The Music of the Maguindanao.

The UP College of Music has produced 40 holders of the master of music degrees. Of special interest are studies of specific Philippine groups like Felicidad Prudente’s “Ang Musika ng mga Kuyunon sa Pulo ng Cuyo” (The Music of the Cuyunon in the Cuyo Island), 1977; and Raquel Georsua’s “Traditional Practices among the Subanun in Lapuyan, Zamboanga del Sur with Special Reference to Music,” 1987. Especially helpful are the annotated compilations of musical references from publications and periodicals: Leticia Guevarra’s “References to Music in Periodicals (1862-1918) at the Filipiniana, National Library,” 1970, which compiled news items and articles on music, musicians, and musical events from various newspapers; Asuncion Laureola’s thesis, “Musical Reference Books Published Before 1900 in the UP Filipiniana Library,” 1971, which surveyed 87 titles; and Melissa Mantaring’s “Philippine Musical References from the Lopez Museum—1601 to 1848,” 1983, which covered 65 titles. Works with special pedagogical value include the following: “Gaddang Songs as Material for Teaching Music,” 1971, by Mauricia Borromeo; “Piano Music by Three Filipino Composers: Ma. Rosalina Abejo, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucrecia R. Kasilag,” 1973, by Emmanuel Laureola; “A Music Transcription of Selected Songs from Thirty-one Cultural Linguistic Groups of the Philippines,” 1979, by Sr Lilia Tolentino; “The Manila Elementary School Center for the Arts,” 1987, by Telly P. Ong; “A Listening Kit on Philippine Modern Music for Secondary Schools,” 1987, by Flerida Nolasco; and “Maranao Songs as Teaching Materials in Music,” 1990, by Evelyn P. Flores. Of more general interest are Helen Samson’s “Extant Music in the Zarzuelas of Severino Reyes,” 1973; Milagros Feril’s “Philippine Folk Melodies as Utilized by Contemporary Filipino Composers (An Analysis of Selected Works Written after 1950),” 1981; and Janet O. Ho’s “A Descriptive Study of the Sunday Service Ritual Music in the Seng Guan Buddhist Temple, Manila,” 1991.

Music-related theses written in other UP colleges included Fe Nera’s “Relating Course Offerings and Reforms in Selected Music Schools to Visions of Preferred Futures in Music: An Approach to Proactive Planning in Education,” 1988; Lydia M. Ico’s “A Critical Analysis of the Pangasinan Cancionan: a Folk Debate in Song,” 1981; Felisa R. Legaspi’s “Ang mga Awiting Bayan ng Bataan” (Folk Songs of Bataan), 1981; Rozzano Locsin’s “Effects of Preferred Music and Guided Imagery on the Pain of Selected Postoperative Patients,” 1987; Arsenio Nicolas’s “Ritual Transformation and Musical Parameters,” 1989; and Honey Achanzar’s “The Philippine Kampana,” 1992.

Other universities also undertook musicological and ethnomusicological research. The Philippine Women’s University music department in Manila has a small collection of Philippine musical instruments and tapes. Silliman University, Dumaguete City, has field recordings and studies based on them, including those of Priscilla V. Magdamo’s “Folk and Traditional Music of the Visayas and Mindanao: 1956-1957” and Elena Maquiso’s “Ulahingan, a Manobo Epic,” 1963; Timoteo S. Oracion’s “Magahat Field Research Recordings,” 1964; William Pfeiffer’s “Collections of Ethnic and Folk Music from Mindanao and the Visayas 1965, 1969, 1974” and Rosemary Diaz’s “Songs from Guindulman,” 1972. These studies have given rise to the six-volume Folk Songs of the Visayas and Songs from Guindulman: 68 Bohol Folk Songs.

In 1966, a University of Washington team surveyed Philippine music under the guidance of the then Department of Asian Music (now the Department of Musicology) of the UP College of Music. The survey, supported by the JDR III Fund of New York, produced 11 films on music and dance of the Ibaloy, Ilocano, Yakan, Maguindanao, Bagobo, Manobo, Maranao, the hill peoples of northern Luzon, the groups of the Sulu islands, the Sama of Taluksangay, and Mindanao. The UP Center for Ethnomusicology archives has a duplicate of the tape collection.

There are several dissertations and theses on Philippine music written abroad. Jose Maceda’s “The Music of the Maguindanao in the Philippines,” a doctor of philosophy dissertation submitted to the University of California in Los Angeles (UCLA) in 1963, was the first major ethnomusicological study on a Philippine group. Other studies followed: William R. Pfeiffer’s “A Musical Analysis of Some Ritual Songs of the Manobo in Mindanao Island in the Philippines” (MA thesis, University of Hawaii, 1965); Ricardo Trimillos’s “Some Social and Musical Aspects of the Music of the Tausug in Sulu, Philippines” (MA thesis, University of Hawaii, 1965), and “Tradition and Repertoire in the Cultivated Music of the Tausug of Sulu, Philippines” (PhD dissertation, UCLA, 1972); Usopay H. Cadar’s “The Maranao Kolintang Music: An Analysis of the Instruments, Musical Organization, Etymologies, and Historical Documents” (MA thesis, University of Washington, 1971) and “Context and Style in the Vocal Music of the Muranao in Mindanao, Philippines” (PhD dissertation, University of Washington, 1980); Steven Walter Otto’s “The Muranao Kakolintang: An Approach to the Repertoire” (PhD dissertation, University of Washington, 1976); Hans Brandeis’s “Zur Musik der Higa-onon am Libang-Fuss, Agusan del Sur, Mindanao” (MA thesis, Berlin, 1980); Kristina Benitez’s “Towards the Understanding of Gong-Drum Ensembles in Southeast Asia: A Study of Resultant Melodies in the Music of Two Gong Ensembles from the Philippines” (MA thesis, University of Michigan, 1983); and Felicidad Prudente’s “Musical Process in the Gasumbi Epic of the Buwaya Kalinga People of Northern Luzon” (PhD dissertation, University of Michigan, 1984).

Some dissertations, while not concerned with ethnomusicology, dealt with related aspects of Philippine music: A. Beunoni Espina’s “Music in the Philippines and the Development of Sacred Music There” (doctor of sacred music dissertation, Union Theological Seminary, 1961); Corbelita Astraquillo’s “A Study and Evaluation of the Development of Vocal Art Music in the Philippines During the First Half of the 20th Century” (PhD dissertation, Indiana University, 1962); Alejandra Atabug’s “Rationale and Design or an Interdisciplinary Music and Visual Arts Course in Philippine Liberal Arts Colleges” (PhD dissertation, University of Michigan, 1971); Angelica Rosario Franquelli’s “Lucrecia R. Kasilag: The Western and Critical Influences in Her Compositions” (musical arts dissertation, Peabody Institute of the Johns Hopkins University, 1979); Francisco F. Feliciano’s “Four Asian Contemporary Composers—The Influence of Tradition in Their Works” (MA thesis, School of Music, Yale University, 1980), and Enrique Cantel Cainglet’s “Hispanic influences on the West Visayan Folk Song Tradition of the Philippines” (PhD thesis, University of Adelaide, Elder Conservatorium of Music, 1982).

Four recordings antedated those issued by UP. Hanunoo Music, produced by Ethnic Folkways in 1955, was a joint effort by anthropologist Harold C. Conklin and Jose Maceda. The 20-page annotations contained ethnological descriptions of the Hanunuo, including occasions for use of music, detailed descriptions of the instruments, different types of vocal forms, as well as music analysis of each band in the recording, with some music transcriptions. A subsequent issue by Ethnic Folkways Library in 1957 titled Music of the World’s Peoples culled samples from the Music of the Hanunuo with notes by Henry Cowell. The two-record album Music of the Maguindanao was issued in 1961 by Folkways Ethnic Library with annotations and recordings by Jose Maceda. The first record contained instrumental music. Rhythmic modes of the gong ensemble were discussed and amply illustrated with recordings of both the ensemble and individual instruments. The second record gave the various types of Maguindanaon vocal music.

In 1970, the Indiana University Archives of Traditional Music and Folklore Institute produced a two-disk set, Music from the Tausug of Sulu, with recordings, notes, and photographs by Thomas M. Keifer. One disk was devoted to instrumental music, the other to vocal music. The annotations described the instruments and the music in great detail. There were numerous photographs, text transcriptions, and translations. Meanwhile, Steven W. Otto and Usopay H. Cadar edited a two-disk series, Muranao Kakolintang: Philippine Gong Music from Lanao (Lyrichord Stereo), with recorded music from five Lake Lanao villages.

Tribal Music of the Philippines, 1958, edited by Priscilla V. Magdamo, is a two-record series produced by Silliman University. Sama de Sitangkai (Philippines: Archipel de Sulu), edited by Alain Martenot, is the result of fieldwork conducted from 1974 to 1976 under a grant from Centre de Documentation et de Recherches sur l’Asie du Sud-Est et le Mon de Insulindien (CEDRASEMI). Martenot and Maceda wrote the descriptions of the instruments, and Maceda prepared the musical transcriptions, tables, and analyses. Nicole and Charles MacDonald conducted fieldwork in Palawan, also funded by CEDRASEMI and the Fyssen Foundation. Their efforts resulted in a recording, Philippines, Musique des Hautes-terres Palawan, 1984. Maceda collaborated with the researchers and penned the musical annotations.

More and more articles, monographs, and books on various facets of Philippine music were written beginning in the mid-1950s. Maceda has written over 70 articles and papers—entries on Philippine music in the New Harvard Dictionary of Music, 1969, the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, 1980, and Musikgeschicte in Bildern, Leipzig, 1979; the article “Arts of Southeast Asian People, Music” in Encyclopedia Britannica, 1974; “Music in the Philippines” in Handbuch der Orientalistik, Leyden, 1972; “Philippines” in Dictionnaire de la Musique, Paris, 1976; and “Filippine” in Dictionario Enciclopedico Universale della Musica e dei Musicisti, Torino, 1981. His articles on indigenous Philippine music cover many groups—Bukid, Hanunuo, Sagada, Maguindanaon, the peoples of the Cordillera, Sama, and Palawan. He also wrote about his researches in Sarawak, Thailand, Kalimantan, and Brazil, relating their music to that of the Philippines. His articles on aesthetics include “Philippine Music and Contemporary Aesthetics,” “Western Idiom in Eastern Music,” “The Place of Asian Music in Philippine Contemporary Society,” “Music in the Philippines in the 19th Century,” “Music in Southeast Asia: Tradition, Nationalism, Innovation,” “Philippine Music Life, Sources of Musical Thought in Southeast Asia,” and “A Classicism in a Music of Southeast Asia.” As a composer, he draws from Asian compositional structures and philosophies, which he expounded on in some of his writings: “Drone and Melody in the Philippine Musical Instruments,” “Elements for a New Music in Southeast Asia,” “A Primitive and a Modern Technology in Music,” “A Search for an Old and a New Music in Southeast Asia,” “Contemporary Music in the Philippines and Southeast Asia,” and “A Concept of Time in a Music of Southeast Asia.” He has written papers and articles on bossed gongs, flat gongs, lutes, and other Philippine instruments.

In 1975, Jeno Takacs’s “A Dictionary of Musical Instruments,” published in Archiv fur Volkerkunde 29 when the author was a professor at the UP Conservatory of Music included data collected in 1932-1934 and was based on his fieldwork and notes published before 1934. The dictionary is divided into two parts: the first section consisting of an alphabetical listing of the indigenous groups and information on their musical culture, and the second, consisting of a dictionary of native terms found in the previous section. The 432 items do not all pertain to instruments. Editor Christian F. Feest added data on specimens of Philippine musical instruments in the Schadenberg collection at the Museum fur Volkerkunde, Vienna. The dictionary systematically compiles material from previously cited pre-1934 sources (i.e., Romualdez, Schadenberg, Scheerer, Garvan, Jenks, Beyer, Moss) and is therefore dated despite its recent publication.

Towards an Inventory of Philippine Musical Instruments, 1978, by E. Arsenio Manuel is a checklist of musical instruments from 23 Philippine ethnolinguistic groups and based on the Philippine instrument collection in the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago. The 238 names of instrument are presented by ethnolinguistic groups and evaluated by checking printed sources to find out what instruments are not represented in the museum’s collection. The biographical entries of musicians in Manuel’s three-volume Dictionary of Philippine Biographies are also useful. Helen Samson compiled 22 biographies of contemporary Philippine composers in Contemporary Filipino Composers, 1976. The League of Filipino Composers published a Directory and Catalogue of Selected Works, 1989, which contains biographical sketches and lists of the important works of its 30 members.

A 10-volume encyclopedia, Filipino Heritage: The Making of a Nation published by Lahing Pilipino Publishing, Inc in 1977, contains articles on different facets of Philippine music. These include: “Tingguian Music” by Ester Samonte Madrid; “Cordillera Mountain Music” and “A Tradition of Gongs and Lutes” by Jose Maceda; “The Magic Doll” by Nicole Revel-MacDonald; “Great Chants of the Mountain Minstrels” by P. Lambrecht; “Music Unfolding” and “Island Music Mix” by E. Arsenio Manuel; “Musical Repertory of Ilocos Norte” by Annabelle Hernando; “Sounds Around Lake Lanao” by Usopay H. Cadar; “Tagalog Song Book” by Marialita Tamanio; “The Sentiment of Kundiman” by Antonio J. Molina; “Banda Uno, Banda Dos” and “Manila Welcomes the Opera” by Felipe Padilla de Leon; “The Roving Rondalla” by Hilarion F. Rubio; “A Folio of Nonsense Rhymes and Songs” by Gilda Cordero-Fernando; “Curtain Call” by Corazon C. Dioquino; “The Seditious Theater” by Behn Cervantes; “Role of the Music Makers” by Vilma R.S. Felipe; and “Music in the New Era” by Lucrecia R. Kasilag.

Madrid contributed two articles to Diliman Review, both in 1954: “The Structure of Philippine Music II,” a review of Gale’s “music” in Cole’s The Tingguians, and “What is Philippine Music,” a discussion of Ilocano, Tagalog, and Visayan songs, and songs of the Aeta, Igorot, and Moro, using Western musical idioms. Cadar wrote “The Role of Kulintang in Maranao Society” in Selected Reports in Ethnomusicology and coauthored with Robert Garfias “Some Principles of Formal Variation in the Kolintang Musica of the Maranao” in Ethnomusicology, 1974.

The Asian Culture Quarterly, Taipeh, 1979, contains papers read at an International Symposium on Asian Music which discussed traditional Asian music and the state of ethnomusicological research in Asia. Corazon C. Dioquino prepared “Ethnomusicology in the Philippines,” followed by an expanded version published in Acta Musicologica in 1982.

While the above-mentioned works deal solely with music, there are many related studies, particularly those dealing with folk oral tradition. Done by nonmusicians, mostly folklorists, anthropologists, and linguists, the studies emphasize different aspects of the oral tradition such as its literary value, possible educational uses, or sociocultural context. Some make special mention of music used in rituals, epics, and other celebrations. All contain valuable information and insights for the music scholar.

The Philippine Folklore Society, founded in 1958, aims to collect, organize, and publish research. Its first published paper was Manuel’s “Philippine Folklore Bibliography: A Preliminary Survey,” 1965. The bibliography includes folk dance and music, folk songs, and musical instruments as branches of folklore. Part Two is an index of the materials, arranged by ethnolinguistic grouping and geographical area. In 1975, papers from the First National Congress of Philippine Folklore and Other Scholars were published in Dialogue for Development edited by Francisco R. Demetrio, SJ. Of particular value to the music scholar are the annotated bibliographies in the papers by Manuel, Eugenio, and Marcelino Foronda. Manuel’s “A Review of Oral Literature Scholarship” surveyed over 70 theses and dissertations from various Philippine universities, only nine of which dealing with folk songs: Flora Amoranto Ylagan’s “Tagalog Popular and Folk songs as a Reflection of Tagalog Life and Culture” (UP, 1934); Consejo V. Cauayani’s “Some Popular Songs of the Spanish Period and Their Possible Use in the Music Program of Our Schools” (UP, 1954); Maria Colina Gutierrez’s “The Cebuano Balitao and How It Mirrors Visayan Culture and Folklife” (University of San Carlos, 1955); Sampaguita S. Buenaflor’s “A Study of Ballads in Negros Occidental” (University of Negros Occidental, 1962); Aurora T. Gozo’s “Educational Elements of the Folk Songs of Tacloban City” (Divine Word University, 1968); Bienvenido B. Segundo’s “Cagayan Folk Songs and Their Possible Uses in Current Educational Practices in Elementary Schools” (LNC, Laoag, 1969); Thelma Reyes Rocha’s “A Study of Folk Songs of the Minority Groups Served by Zamboanga Normal College” (Far Eastern University, 1969); Luz A. Pelayo’s “Pampango Folk Songs: Their Cultural Significance” (Angeles University, 1971); and Esteban C. Torres’s “Folk Songs of the Bikol Region: An Interpretative Analysis” (Centro Escolar University, 1971). Cauayani, Segundo, Torres, and Rocha included music transcriptions in their works.

Eugenio’s bibliography in “A Survey of Tagalog Folklore Scholarship” include 447 titles, 30 of which are on Tagalog folk songs. The earliest, dated 1893, is “El Kumintang, Su Musica y Su Baile” in La Solidaridad. Iloko Folklore Bibliography by Marcelino Foronda has 229 titles, including three typescript Ilocano song collections (two by Christie, 1912, and one undated) in the Ayer collection of the Newberry Library, Chicago, and other papers on the oral traditions of the Bukidnon (Opeña), Tausug (G. Rixhon), Maranao (N.T. Madale), Mansaka (Magaña), Dibabaon-Mandaya (Tiamzon), and Palawan (N. Revel-MacDonald). The same volume also listed 154 samples of oral traditions from 49 ethnolinguistic groups enumerated in Archive of Philippine Languages, University of the Philippines. Eighty of the titles are folk songs. Maceda’s Preliminary Listing of Vocal Music covers 42 ethnolinguistic groups. Earlier, Maceda wrote “A Classification and Distribution of Musical Instruments in the Philippines” in Musics of Asia, 1966.

The Mindanao Journal, Vol 4, published by the Mindanao State University contained the proceedings of the Third National Folklore Congress held at the University of San Carlos, Cebu City in Nov 1976. It contained several papers of interest to the music scholar, particularly Florentino Hornedo’s “Ivatan Oral Tradition: A Survey,” which included eight musical transcriptions. The proceedings of a folklore congress held at UP in Jul 1980 were edited by Alfredo Tiamson and Rosalinda Canda came out as Readings in Philippine Folklore and Functional Literacy.

Various resident and visiting anthropologists, linguists, and folklorists have been publishing since 1965. Although it is not within the scope of this essay to cite them all, a few who have advanced music research bear mentioning: Francis Lambrecht on the Kalinga and other northern Philippine groups; William Henry Scott on the Cordillera groups; Charles and Nicole MacDonald on the Palawan; E. Arsenio Manuel on the Manobo; Conklin on the Ifugao; Michelle Rosaldo on the Ilongot; Edward Dozier on the Kalinga; Hubert Reynolds on the Isneg; Francisco Billiet on the Kalinga Ullalim; Charles Warren on the Batak of Palawan; F. Landa Jocano on the Sulod; H. Arlo Nimmo on the Badjao (now Sama Dilaut); James O’Brien on the Bikol; and Andrew Sherfan on the Yakan. Scholars who studied particular forms include Nicanor G. Tiongson on the sinakulo and komedya; Antoon Postma on the ambahan; Nid Anima on courtship and marriage practices; Phylis Flattery on divination in seven Mountain Province cultures; Paula Carolina Malay on the matrimonyo; Lawrence Reid on ritual and ceremony in the Mountain Province; and Teresita Gimenez-Maceda on the music of the communist and socialist parties, 1930-1955.

The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) produced a series of 28 video documentaries and monographs from 1989 to 1994, collectively known as Tuklas Sining, on the seven arts of the Philippines. Part of this series is four monographs and videos on history of Philippine music and on the indigenous, Spanish, and American colonial and contemporary traditions in Philippine music. The CCP also pioneered in producing three popular sarsuwela in cassette tape format with one tape featuring a sarsuwela with voice and orchestra, and the other an orchestra minus-one for groups interested in putting up the sarsuwela. These sarsuwela are Walang Sugat (No Wounds), Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), and Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden).

Music research topics from 1992 to 2015 broadened and diversified, which was a result of the heterogeneous backgrounds of its researchers. UP College of Music continued to lead in research outputs. In 1998, Jose Maceda with assistant Marialita Yraola, published the landmark book that summarized their organological survey of indigenous musical instruments begun four decades ago: Gongs and Bamboo: A Panorama of Philippine Music Instruments. This came out a year after the UP Center for Ethnomusicology of the UP College of Music became separate from the Department of Music Research (presently called the Department of Musicology), to become an archive and research center. After Maceda’s death in 2004, Ramon P. Santos became director of the UP Center for Ethnomusicology. In 2005, Santos published a collection of his essays in a book Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music, which dealt with the modernism of Nicanor S. Abelardo’s music, the orality of bad’w and Maranao vocal music, and the history of the UP Conservatory of Music. The work is exemplary for its analytical and music critical approach. This was followed by another book on the transmission of music tradition, Laon-Laon: Perspectives in Transmission and Pedagogy of Musical Traditions in Post-Colonial Southeast Asia, 2012.

Helen F. Samson wrote a dissertation in Cologne Germany and published this as Die Zeitgenössische Kunstmusik der Philippinen im Spannungsfeld Zwischen Nationalem Erbe und Europäischem Einflus, 1989. Samson also wrote the Contemporary Filipino Composers, 1976, and The Bamboo Organ of Las Piñas, originally published in 1977, but revised and updated in 2006. Elena Rivera Mirano, working on her 1991 PhD dissertation in Philippine studies, published a structural analysis of Ang mga Tradisyonal na Musikang Pantinig sa Lumang Bauan, Batangas (The Vocal Music Traditions of Old Bauan, Batangas), 1997.

General survey-type essays on Philippine music continued to be written during the period. Jose Maceda updated his article on Philippine music in the second edition of the The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, 2001. In this reference material, a new entry on the Spanish colonial music of Manila by historian William Summers appeared. Jose Maceda, Corazon Dioquino, and Ramon Santos later contributed essays in The Garland Encyclopedia of World Music, 1998. Dioquino also edited an anthology of articles published by the National Research Council of the Philippines, Compendium of the Humanities of the Philippines: Musical Arts. Meanwhile, the UP Center for Ethnomusicology revived Jose Maceda’s Musika Jornal which contained essays on different topics since 2008. The Center, with editor Ramon Santos, also came up with a Dictionary of Filipino Music Terms, 2013.

The masteral research programs in musicology and music education of the UP College of Music produced theses, some of which for the masteral degree in music, concentrating in music education: Edna Aurora C. Culig, “The Philippine Bandurria: A Study on its Educational and Artistic Possibilities”; Evelyn P. Flores, “Maranao Songs as Teaching Materials in Music”; and Jocelyn T. Guadalupe, “Musika sa Makabayan: Teaching Music in Makabayan Three Using the Thematic and Analogous Approaches,” 2008. For the MA in musicology, there were Edna Marcil Martinez, “The Life and Music of Colonel Antonino Buenaventura: A Study of Three Major Orchestral Works,” 1995; Arwin Tan, “Evolving Filipino Music and Culture in the Life and Works of Don Lorenzo Ilustre of Ibaan, Batangas,” 2007; Lilymae F. Montano, “Crafting Gongs in Two Ifugao Communities in Northern Philippines,” 2008; Sr Ma. Theresa Asencio, “Continuity and Renewal of Catholic Liturgical Music in the Congregation of the Sisters of Saint Paul of Chartres, Philippine Province (1935-2008),” 2009; Christine May de Vera, “An Understanding of Communities of Singers in the Context of a Funeral Ceremony in Bontoc, Mountain Province, Philippines,” 2010; Mihyun Oh, “Classifications of Sarangani Blaan Instrumental Music Repertoire,” 2010; Leo Eva Rempola, “Metaphors of Power and Propaganda in Lucino T. Sacramento’s Ang Maharlika and Ang Bituin Concertos for Piano and Orchestra,” 2011; and Ma. Edelquinn S. Beltran, “Alexander Lippay (1892-1939): Austrian Composer and Conductor in Manila, 1925-1939,” 2015.

In 2002, Maceda witnessed and endorsed the foundation of the Musicological Society of the Philippines, which was initiated by Jose Buenconsejo and Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua. The Musicological Society of the Philippines came at a time when graduates of the UP College of Music who earned doctoral degrees in music, mostly in the United States, came home to teach in the country. Jose Buenconsejo inaugurated a type of music research that was wholly contextual, interpreting the meaning of the Agusanon Manobo ritual song tud-om against the background of mythology and political economy in Songs and Gifts at the Frontier: Person and Exchange in the Agusan Manobo Possession Ritual, Philippines, 2002. LaVerne de la Peña, previously active in composition, wrote an ethnomusicological work “Traversing Boundaries: A Situated Music Approach to the Study of Day-Eng Performance Among the Kankana-Ey of Northern Philippines,” 2000. Mary Arlene Pe Chongson, who, like de la Peña was in composition before crossing to ethnomusicology, wrote “Pasyon and Holy Week: A Study of Music, Acculturation, and Local Catholicism in the Philippines” for the University of Texas at Austin, 2000. A student of Jose Maceda, Racquel Berdon-Georsua, finished her doctorate in Australian on ritual music titled “Where Heaven and Earth Meet: The Buklog of the Subanen in Zamboanga Peninsula, Western Mindanao, the Philippines” (University of Melbourne), 2004, and thereafter taught at Cebu Normal University. Then a year after, Kristina Benitez finished her dissertation on “The Maguindanaon Kulintang: Musical Innovation, Transformation and the Concept of Binalig,” 2005, and returned home to teach at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU). Benitez later established a PhD in ethnomusicology program at PWU. Another graduate of the musicology program from UP College of Music was Pamela Grace Costes who finished her PhD with a work on translocal Philippine music, “Tunog Pil-Am: Creating and Reinventing the Sound of the Filipino Natives of America,” University of Washington at Seattle, 2005.

Other alumni of the UP College of Music also finished their doctoral degrees in the previous decade. They researched on aspects of Philippine music that deal with music repertory and style analysis. In 1992, Raul Sunico wrote a PhD dissertation for the faculty of the School of Education, Health, Nursing and Arts Professions in New York University titled “Selected Philippine Piano Concerti: A Performance Guide.” For his doctor of musical arts (DMA) degree in choral conducting, Joel M. Navarro wrote “A Style Study of Selected Choral Works of Ramon Pagayon Santos,” 2006. Then in 2010, Abelardo Galang wrote “The Development of Philippine Piano Literature” for the Technical University in Berlin.

Outside of the UP College of Music, many contributed to music research as well. Arsenio Nicolas Jr wrote “Musical Exchange in Early Southeast Asia: The Philippines and Indonesia, Ca. 100 to 1600 Ce” for his PhD degree at Cornell University, 2007. A number of articles published in international journals came out of this work. Nicolas finished a master’s degree at the UP Asian Center, which was also where Grace Nono studied. She turned her master’s thesis into a book on the orality of Philippine traditional song titled The Shared Voice: Chanted and Spoken Narratives from the Philippines, 2008. Grace Nono continued her interest in orality and extended this into the realm of indigenous spirituality in Song of the Babaylan: Living Voices, Medicines, Spiritualities of Philippine Ritualist-Oralist-Healers, 2013. In 2014, she finished her PhD at New York University with a dissertation titled “Babaylan Sing Back: Philippine Shamans on Voice, Gender, and Transnationalism.” Another UP alumna who did music research was Fredeliza Z. Campos of the UP Archeological Studies Program who wrote “A Study of the Musical Instruments of Ifugao in the Cordillera Region, Northern Philippines” for her master in philosophy degree at the University of Hong Kong, 2012. And from the theater program at the UP College of Arts and Letters, meLê Yamomo wrote “Sounding Modernities: Music and Theatre in Manila and the Asia Pacific, 1869-1948” for the Ludwig Maximilians Universität-München in Munich, Germany, 2014.

As there was not yet a doctoral program in music at the UP College of Music in the early 2000s, a number of its faculty went to the tri-college Philippine Studies program in UP and earned their degrees in Philippine studies, albeit still writing on Philippine music. The first to finish from the UP College of Music was Raul C. Navarro who crafted a dissertation in Filipino, Kolonyal na Patakaran at ang Nagbabagong Kamalayang Filipino: Musika sa Publikong Paaralan sa Pilipinas, 1898-1935 (Colonial Policy and the Changing Mindset of the Filipino: Music in Philippine Public Schools, 1898-1935), 2007. He followed this up with another book in Filipino, Musika at Bagong Lipunan: Pagbuo ng Lipunang Filipino, 1972-1986 (Music and the New Society: The Creation of the Filipino Society, 1972-1986), 2014. After Navarro, Jonas Baes in the PhD Philippine Studies, College of Social Science and Philosophy, wrote “Modes of Appropriation in Philippine Indigenous Music: The Politics of the Production of Cultural Difference,” 2004. He was followed by Christine Muyco who wrote a dissertation “Sibod in Binanog: Understanding of the Binanog Tradition of the Panay Bukidnon (Philippines),” 2008. Lastly, for the Philippine Studies in UP Asian Center, Michiyo Yoneno-Reyes finished her PhD with “Unsettling ‘Salidummay’: A Historico-ethnography of a Music Category,” 2010. Music scholars of this decade actively disseminated their papers in conferences organized by local academic societies such as the Philippine National Historical Society, Bagong Kasaysayan, UGAT (Anthropological Association of the Philippines), and the Arts Studies Association and by international societies like International Conference of Philippine Studies, International Conference in Philippine Linguistics, International Council for Traditional Music, and the Performing Arts of Southeast Asia Study Group. Consequently, these papers resulted in conference proceedings and publications in local and international journals like Musika Jornal, Humanities Diliman, Journal of Asian Studies, Daluyan, Budhi, Saliksik (of Bagong Kasaysayan), Plaridel, Bulawan, Journal for the Arts, Culture, and the Humanities (UST), Philippine Studies, and Kritika.

In 2011, the UP College of Music organized an international conference on the theme “The Impact of Music in Shaping Southeast Asian Societies” where topics on music in Philippine popular cultures were represented. These were LaVerne de la Peña’s “Verse versus Verse: the Articulation of Changing Filipino Sensibilities in the Performance of the Repartee of Day-eng, Awit, and Pinoy Rap,” Michiyo Yoneno-Reyes’s “American Movie Songs and the Salidummay in the Northern Luzon Highlands,” meLê Yamomo’s “Global Currents, Musical Streams: the Musical Trade Route between Europe and Manila in Early Globalization,” Jose S. Buenconsejo’s “Philippine Piano Music Folklore circa 1860s: An Early Articulation of Filipino Identity,” Christi-Anne Castro’s “Musicking Race: U.S. and Philippine Encounters,” and Renato Lucas’s “A Preliminary Annotation of Selected Discography by Filipino Artists, 1913–1946.” Topics on music and politics that are a staple in new critical musicology were apparent as well as seen in Jonas Baes’s “Patangis-Buwaya: Research and a Philosophy of Praxis in Music Composition in Southeast Asia” and Raul Navarro’s “Propaganda-Image and Music: The Making of the New Society, 1965-1986.”

Another conference was organized by the UP College of Music in cooperation with the UP College of Mass Communications in 2013, this time on the theme “Seeing-Sounding Social Transformation in (The Music) of Philippine Theaters.” The politics of cultures was again highlighted such as in Resil Mojares’s “Musica Moralia: The Buenaventuras, Music, and Politics,” Teresita Maceda’s “Pagkanta ng Totoo sa mga Lipunang Sinilensyo,” Roselle Pineda’s “Femmecees Reprznt! The Lives, Strides and Rhymes of Filipina Rappers at the Dawn of Pinoy Hip-hop in the Late 80s and Early 90s,” Jose S. Buenconsejo’s “The Many-splendoured Kundiman in the ‘Paki-usap’ Film Score (1940): A criticism on the Seeing-Sounding of ‘Romantic Love’ in a Philippine Feudalistic Class Structure,” and Nicanor G. Tiongson’s “Contesting Ideologies in the Theater of 1902.”

As ease of travel across nation-state borders made it easy for scholars to do fieldwork in the country, the subject of Philippine music attracted foreign scholars. The majority of these were Americans like Stephen Grauberger who wrote a master’s thesis on “Diatonic Harp of the Philippines: An Historical Overview and an Organological Comparison of the Cebuano-Bisayan Harp” for the University of Hawaii Manoa, 1994. This was followed by David Joseph Kendall’s PhD dissertation on “Spanish Colonial Liturgical Music in the Philippines: Inventing a Tradition,” 2010, and Neal D. Matherne’s “Naming the Artist, Composing the Philippines: Listening for the Nation in the National Artist Award,” 2014. Both were from the University of California Riverside. Filipino-Americans at UCLA such as Christi-Anne Castro and Mary Talusan wrote about Philippine music, the former writing a cultural history dissertation that became the book Musical Renderings of the Philippine Nation, 2011, while the latter dealt with “Cultural Localization and Transnational Flows: Music in the Magindanaon Communities of the Philippines,” 2005. Almost a decade later, another Filipino-American named Marilyne Antonette Adiova researched on the “Music, Dance, and Negotiations of Identity in the Religious Festivals of Bicol, Philippines,” 2014, for her PhD dissertation at the University of Michigan. And in 2015, another Fil-Am, Bernard Ellorin completed his dissertation on the “Trans-cultural commodities: the Sama-Bajau Pan Musical Industries and Identities on the Peripheries of Maritime Southeast Asia,” University of Hawaii, 2015.

Non-American researchers include Japanese Yoshitaka Terada who worked on Maranao kulintang; Australian Manolote Mora who did years of fieldwork in Mindanao and who came up with an outstanding book Myth, Mimesis and Magic in the Music of the T’Boli, Philippines, 2008; David RM Irving who engaged intensively with written records to produce Colonial Counterpoint: Music in Early Modern Manila, 2010; and South African Lee William Watkins who interviewed Filipino musicians and wrote “Minstrelsy in the Margin Re-Covering the Memories and Lives of Filipino Musicians in Hong Kong” for the University of Hong Kong. This work on Filipino popular culture is similar to Malaysian Stephanie Sooklynn Ng’s dissertation “Filipino Bands Performing in Hotels, Clubs and Restaurants in Asia: Purveyors of Transnational Culture in a Global Arena,” submitted to the University of Michigan in 2006.

The decade 2000 was indeed very productive. New topics in Philippine musicology and new theoretical approaches such as ethnographic/cultural history, analysis and music criticism, and popular music culture came to the fore. Top among these researches was the subfield of historical musicology, which is characterized by archival research methods that interpret social meanings in music manuscripts and prints. Maria Alexandra Iñigo Chua transformed her UP master’s thesis in musicology into a book that decoded early 19th century archaic liturgical music notation, Kirial de Baclayon, Año 1826: Hispanic Sacred Music in 19th Century Bohol, Philippines, 2010. She was inspired by the works of music historian William Summers, who published findings in the local journal Budhi: A Journal of Ideas and Culture titled “Listening for Historic Manila: Music and Rejoicing in an International City” and “Rediscovering the Hidden Muses of Bohol: Filipino Music Maestri From Corella Church, Bohol.” Within this circle of historical musicologists, David Irving also contributed new knowledge about music in Manila from the 17th to 18th centuries, such as his essay on the “Historical and Literary Vestiges of the Villancico in the Early Modern Philippines” that appeared in the book Devotional Music in the Iberian World, 1450-1800, 2007. Irving also wrote “Keyboard Instruments and Instrumentalists in Manila” in Anuario Musical 60, 2005, and “Musical Politics of Empire: The Loa in Eighteen-Century Manila” in Early Music, 2004.

Interest in historical musicology also influenced local scholars, notably Elena Rivera Mirano, who wrote The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay, 2009. On a separate stream, Antonio C. Hila who was primarily trained as a historian, published his essays in Music in History, History in Music, 2004. This book encompassed the broad field of history and criticism. From the UP College of Arts and Letters, Juliet Bien wrote a master’s thesis titled “The Invencion of Calabanga, Camrines Sur: The Dynamics of Family, Land, and Power,” 2009 and, for the same degree, Patricia Lopez wrote “Expressions of Devotion: The Flores de Mayo in Poblacion, Oslob,” 2013.

Independent initiatives in Philippine music research were also a new feature of this period. Richie Quirino compiled sources to write anecdotal books on the history of jazz in the Philippines. Robert L. Yoder wrote the history of the famed early 20th century Philippine Constabulary, In Performance: Walter Howard Loving and the Philippine Constabulary Band, 2013. In addition, the period also saw the flowering of biographies, many of which were hagiographies being self-published or commissioned like de la Torre, 1985; Lucresia Kasilag, 2000; Andrea Veneracion, 2001; Antonino Buenaventura, 2004; Angel Peña and Diego Cera, 2008; and Salido, Gilopez Kabayao, and Juan de Sahagun Hernandez, 2010. While a critical researcher would naturally be aware of the partiality of these works, these biographies are, nonetheless, important source materials for doing a more systematic research on acculturated Philippine music traditions.

Despite the upsurge in research about Philippine music history, the field of ethnomusicology was not neglected because there were indeed works that were ethnomusicological, yet still in keeping with the 1990s pre-occupation with reflexivity and intersubjectivity. Ricardo D. Trimillos wrote “Agency and Voice: The Philippines at the 1998 Smithsonian Folklife Festival.” This appeared in the book Music and Cultural Rights, 2009. He also touched upon politics in the article “Histories, Resistances, and Reconciliations in a Decolonizable Space: The Philippine Delegation to the 1998 Smithsonian Folklife Festival,” which was published in The Journal of American Folklore, 2008. French anthropological linguist Nicole Revel re-issued her 1980 recordings in a CD with informative notes titled Philippines Musique Des Hautes-Terres Palawan, 1992, which had music descriptions by Jose Maceda. Revel also continued her work on epics and produced an analysis of Masinu’s epic The Quest for a Wife: A Palawan Epic, 2000, and, with Harry Nimmo and Alain Martenot, wrote the Silungan Baltapa: Le Voyage au Ciel d’un Héros Sama (The Voyage to Heaven of a Sama Hero), 2005. Her project Literature of Voice: Epics in the Philippines, 2005, is particularly important because it is a fruit of an honest collaboration with indigenous artists, in particular with the Saway family of Bukidnon.

Aside from Trimillos and Revel, other foreign scholars published Philippine music research. Like Revel’s aforementioned book, these were in collaboration with local scholars such as Matthew C. M. Santamaria whose essay was included in Alain Martenot, Birgit Abels, and Hanafi Hussin’s Oceans of Sound: Sama Dilaut Performing Arts, Dedicated to Alain Martenot (1946-2010), 2012. Another scholar was Glenn Stallsmith of Summer Institute of Linguistics who worked in the Cordillera in Luzon, whose essay was included in Brigit Abels’s monography titled Austronesian Soundscapes: Performing Arts in Oceania and Southeast Asia, 2011. Michiyo Yoneno-Reyes continued to deal with popular culture and wrote the essay “Under Attack: Mass Media Technology and Indigenous Musical Practices in the Philippines,” which appeared in Global Goes Local: Popular Culture in Asia, edited by Timothy J. Craig, and Richard King, 2002.

The period covering music research from 1992 to the present would not be complete without mentioning Craig A. Lockard’s essay on Philippine protest songs, which was a chapter in his book Dance of Life: Popular Music and Politics in Southeast Asia, 1998, and Teresita G. Maceda’s book Mga Tinig Mula sa Ibaba: Kasaysayan ng Partido Komunista ng Pilipinas at Sosialistang Partido ng Pilipinas sa Awit, 1930-1955 (Voices from the Grassroots: The History of the Communist Party and the Socialist Party of the Philippines in Song, 1930-1955), 1996, which was about underground political songs.

Not too many books have been published on popular contemporary forms, so Richie Quirino’s three-volume work on Filipino jazz traditions is truly pioneering and seminal. These include Pinoy Jazz Traditions, 2004, covering the history of jazz in the Philippines from 1898 to the 1960s; Mabuhay Jazz: Jazz in Postwar Philippines, 2008, recounting jazz history from the 1950s to the 1970s; and Contemporary Jazz in the Philippines: 1970 to the Year 2010, 2011, focusing on jazz during martial law up to the 2000s.

Musicological and ethnomusicological scholarship in the Philippines has a long history. Still, many fields of study remain to be explored. Studies have just begun to tap into the vast wealth of the Filipino musical heritage. There is a need for more extensive collection and preservation of music, especially in the contexts of change and acculturation that are inevitable. Informed by recent perspectives in postcolonial studies and performance theory, documentations of Philippine music should not be limited to understanding why traditions endure or are “re-invented,” but also how they respond specifically to modernities that result in cultural hybridities. It is also equally urgent to organize collected material so that it is available for further study. More text translations and music transcriptions are needed so that collected material can be properly evaluated. But, in addition to such organizing and collecting, these materials need to be understood as responses to particular historical moments. Only then can the fundamental structures of music in the Philippines, and the relationships between music and society be properly described. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

article.value: Sections

The Spanish Colonial Period (1500-1900)
The American Colonial Period (1900-50)
The Period of the Republics (1946-2014)

Music research or musicology, the science of music, is concerned with the study of oral or written music in its cultural context. As a scholarly discipline in the university, musicology did not exist in the Philippines before 1950, although inquiries into the subject of Philippine music had begun much earlier, as seen in the works of intellectuals like Pedro Paterno, Fernando Canon, Epifanio de los Santos, Raymundo Bañas, Norberto Romualdez, and Alfredo Roa. There is much material prior to 1950 which may not be technically “musicological” or “ethnomusicological” but is of great value to the music scholar and historian. The material includes accounts in journals, magazines, newspapers, monographs, books, and related studies written mostly by anthropologists, linguists, folklorists, and cultural historians. Information can also be gleaned from the writings of early explorers, travelers, missionaries, and civil servants.
The Spanish Colonial Period (1500-1900)

The principal sources of information on music of this period are the historical chronicles and travelogues by Spanish friars or government officials. Although dealing primarily with military conquest, government, administration, or Christian conversion, the vast assortment of documents, including letters, maps, statistics, narrations, and descriptions, occasionally mention music. Although the information is not detailed, it gives scholars a historical perspective.

article.value: Antonio Pigafetta’s Primo Viaggio Intorno al Mondo (First Voyage Around the World), 1536, an account of the first voyage around the world led by Magellan from 1519 to 1522, contains what is probably the earliest written mention of music in the Philippines: a gong-drum ensemble in Cebu, the use of gongs and bamboo trumpets in a ritual ceremony, and the use of gongs and songs in a water festival.

An account of the Franciscan mission in the Philippines, Historia de las Islas del Archipielago (History of the Islands of the Archipelago), 1601, by Fray Marcelo de Ribadeneira mentions the teaching of canto llano (Gregorian Chant), canto d’organo (polyphony), organ, flute, violin, and clarions to young boys in Camarines. Subsequent chronicles of the Franciscan mission, like the Estatutos y Ordenaciones (Statutes and Decrees), 1732, and Chronicas (Chronicles) 1738, 1741, and 1744, mention the beneficial results of the 1573 mandate to establish schools for boys in towns. Detailed descriptions of the Franciscan schools enumerate the functions and duties of singers and single out the efforts of Frs Geronymo Aguilar, Pedro Bautista, and Juan de Santa Marta. The latter headed a school of 400 boys in Lumbang, Laguna. Jesuits Fr Pedro Chirino’s Relacion de las Islas Filipinas (Account of the Philippine Islands), 1604, and Fr Pedro Murillo Velarde’s Historia de la Provincia de Philipinas de la Compania de Jesus (History of the Province of the Philippines of the Society of Jesus), 1749, and Geographica Historia de las Islas Philipinas (Geographic History of the Philippine Islands), 1752, carry descriptions of indigenous music—drums and bells used during sacrificial rituals, bells in important announcements and epics containing genealogies, and musical instruments like the cutyapi or coryapi, bangsi, nose flute, harpa, rabel, and guitarra in burial and wake ceremonies, as well as Western music as embodied in the choirs, the organ-playing during mass, the church celebrations during feasts, and the abundance of violinists, flutists, and oboists in towns.

article.value: Francisco Combes’s Historia de Mindanao e Jolo (History of Mindanao and Jolo), 1667, and William Dampier’s A New Voyage Round the World, 1729, describe native instruments like the agun, guimbao, kulintangan and their uses during ceremonies. Dr John Francis Careri’s A Voyage Round the World, 1732, describe responsorial singing of successive stanzas of a song to the accompaniment of a metal drum, the practice of sounding drums and other instruments during an eclipse to fight away the dragon who swallows the moon, and shamans called catalonan among the Tagalog and babaylan among the Visayan.

Juan de la Concepcion wrote in Historia General de las Islas Filipinas (General History of the Philippine Islands), 1788-1792, of the Filipino’s ease and facility in playing instruments. The remark was echoed by many other writers such as Franciscan Juan de Medina, who wrote in 1630 that there were very good singers in Manila, and Fray Francisco de Santa Ines, who wrote in 1676 that there were types of music in the Philippines that could rival those of the cathedrals in Spain.
