text:
Recording refers to the process of making copies of a piece or pieces of music for public dissemination. The process includes the preproduction phase, in which the producers and their assistants decide on the concept, programming, and performance of the piece/pieces of music; the production phase, which includes the creation of the musical arrangements, the rehearsals, the actual performance and recording, and the editing and mixing; and the postproduction phase, which concentrates on the duplication of copies, and the promotion and marketing of the finished products.

 

The making of a record begins with the search for material. The producer can personally ask composers for new works or do research on unrecorded music in the music library, usually housed within the premises of the recording company. Popular music composers include Jess Saclo, Danny Subido, Ernani Cuenco, George Canseco, Vic Villafuerte, Mike Hanopol, Joey “Pepe” Smith, Freddie Aguilar, Heber Bartolome, Ryan Cayabyab, Willy Cruz, Jim Paredes, Danny Javier, Gines Tan, Danny Tan, Florante de Leon, Gary Granada, Jose Mari Chan, Ernie de la Peña, Nonong Pedero, Cecile Azarcon-Palma, Odette Quesada, Nonoy Gallardo, Paul Galang, Charo Unite, Tats Faustino, Snaffu Rigor, Nonoy Tan, Vehnee Saturno, Rey Valera, Louie Ocampo, Jimmy Antiporda, and Gary Valenciano. In this search for material, the producer is assisted by the audition and research (A & R) person, who takes care of looking for talents and studios to be rented, establishing contacts with the arranger and sound engineers, and attending to the copyright demands of the selected songs.

A preproduction meeting is set so that the singer, the producer, the A & R person, and preferably the arranger, can hear and study prospective materials. For a more objective evaluation of their works, the composer of these materials is usually excluded from the discussion. The group brainstorms and decides on the concept of the record, including the final selections, the type of arrangement needed, and the target audience (i.e., rural or urban). The producer gives all the guidelines to the singer, who will then study the lyrics and melody for a week or so before recording sessions formally start.

 

The production phase is usually the domain of an audio recording engineer. He is responsible for recording, manipulating, mixing, and mechanically reproducing sound. He works closely with songwriters, music arrangers, and especially session musicians, vocalists, and instrumentalists who render parts of musical arrangements in sound studios.

First to be recorded or dubbed is the minus one or the instrumental accompaniment. The arranger creates this according to the guidelines laid out by the producer as to the desired beat, key, and instrumentation. Some of the music industry’s arrangers are Domingo Amarillo, Emi and Eddie Munji, Jun Latonio, Emil Mijares, Lorrie Ilustre, Danny Favis, Amado Triviño, Butch Miraflor, Angel M. Peña, Rey Magtoto, and Dante Trinidad, most of whom have harnessed their talents in arranging song-entries to the Metropop contest. Others have branched into musical direction for TV shows or concerts: Dominic Salustiano was the resident arranger and musical director of RPN 9’s Bagong Kampeon (New Champion), a popular amateur singing contest on TV; Mon Faustino regularly did the arrangements for Gary Valenciano’s concerts; Mel Villena was the regular musical director of Sharon Cuneta’s concerts here and abroad; Homer Flores was the regular musical director of musical variety shows like Vilma! and Eat Bulaga!; and Egay Gonzales did several musical directing stints in local concerts of pop singing idols and was also the musical director of the Sunday noontime show Sa Linggo nAPO Sila. Some arrangers devoted most of their time to individual singers, like Alvin Nuñez who regularly did the arrangements of Jose Mari Chan’s songs.

The singer is asked to attend this first recording session to make sure he or she is comfortable with the key of the accompaniment. Once the arrangement is approved, the arranger rehearses the session musicians who have been recruited by the A & R person. When the musicians are ready, the recording is done. Before the singer’s voice is recorded, though, he or she may listen to the songs as sung by the composer with the minus one and from there create his or her own interpretation of the song. The singer undergoes lengthy rehearsals with the producer or composer for emotional motivation and musical approach.

After the lead vocals have been recorded, another session is set for the backup vocals, as required by the arranger. The lead performer need not be present at this point because the support vocalists can already go by his or her voice track in the minus one. Session musicians used to be recruited from Aroma Cafe in the post-World War II decades. Later, individual musicians were contacted directly or drawn from established orchestras. Some of the session musicians who recorded for the industry were Polding Silos, Jun Regalado, Roger Herrera, Narding Castañeda, Ponching Belsonda, and Rudy Lozano, as well as musicians from the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and Manila Symphony Orchestra.

The editing-mixing stage is considered the most crucial. Here, the various recorded tracks are manipulated to create an aural picture of the entire performance. The trained ears of mixers intimately attend to the details, as they study each track to decide which instrument must be heard only on the left or right speaker, or which song should be added if there are still vacant tracks available. As with the vocals, it is here where the singer or singers’ mistakes and deficiencies can be electronically corrected and improved through proper adjustments on the reverb, echo, or sustain functions.

Most of the technology that the music recording industry in the United States developed from the 1960s to the present have been imported and used through the last three decades by major Filipino-owned recording companies. Some notable technological innovations of the last decade include the multitrack systems of recording sounds and the use of synthesizers. The commercial viability of sound recordings also brought musical entrepreneurship into vogue.

With the introduction of the synthesizer in the 1980s, recording sessions have become much more explorative than ever. Not only is this computer-aided equipment capable of reproducing sound, but it can also push the limits of one’s audial fantasy by virtually inventing new sounds. Recordings channeled through synthesizers achieve the desired balance of sounds through the preprogrammed tracking assignments. An obvious drawback of a total dependence on synthesizers, however, is that it can dehumanize the recording session or render it mechanical and predictable. It can replace the human fingers on the piano or guitar, and can mask or eliminate a singer’s faltering notes, giving a wrong impression of the singer’s abilities.

Towards the mid-1980s, keyboard devices and synthesizers became very affordable in the Philippines. By stacking the audio output from these varied instruments, keyboardists and musical arrangers attempted to approximate the rich textures and densities of a real orchestra simply by linking and overlapping sound modules together. This was made possible by a technology, then emerging, called Musical Instrument Digital Interface (MIDI). The process to manipulate multiple sounds in the studio from a common point (most often, a keyboard “controller”) caused MIDI’s popularity to soar. Musical elements like tempo, vibrato, dynamics, tuning, and quantization became standard parameters of modern audio design, manipulated by knobs, sliders, levers, and buttons that memorized entire performances. MIDI also brought music sequencers into the recording mainstream that assimilated streams of hardware devices and application products to record, edit, and play back pop music as it has not been previously realized.

The disadvantage was that sequencers effectively disenfranchised numerous studio session musicians from studio work, including violinists, violists, cellists, and brass ensemble players. There was an exodus of traditional musicians to jobs in other environments such as cruise ships and overseas hotels. Sequencers also became virtual recording studios by themselves, despite elements missing that could not be replicated such as vocals, guitars, and saxophone solos. Despite their detrimental impact, sequencers became hugely popular in the Philippines, dominating the character of pop music in the 1980s. Among the most illustrious of Manila’s sequencer-based arrangers were Willy Cruz, Dante Trinidad, Homer Flores, Gerry Paraiso, and Sunny Ilacad. The technology allowed producers to book recording studios with practically half of the arrangements already pre-recorded, hence at only half the regular expense. Soon, the commercial appeal of sequencer methods in the Philippine recording industry pushed record producers, arrangers, and even aspiring recording artists to follow suit. Anyone, even those with little or no skill to read or write musical notation, became quickly empowered songwriters and MIDI orchestrators on sequencer booms. Soon the technology became pervasive that DIY (Do It Yourself) home recording studios spread far and wide in Manila.

In the 1990s, numerous recording studios began utilizing Pro Tools, a hardware-software combination in the Apple Mac computer that simulated traditional analog recording processes in a digital environment. Subsequently, a slew of Windows-based DAW (Digital Audio Workstation) platforms also became prevalent.

Much progress has been achieved in studio recording: from the restrictive mono, to the 2, 4, 8, 16, and even 24-track capacity, which allows the recording of as many instruments or voices. Multitrack recorders in the United States can go up to 72 tracks. The multitrack or multihead recording gives the arranger free rein in putting emphasis or in downplaying a particular sound from among the tracks in use. The piano, for example, can be highlighted, while the guitars, drums, and other instruments can be muffled.

In the early 1970s, digital recording started to replace analogue recording. Analogue recording has to cope with a whole range of levels and frequencies. Digital recording improves on the analogue by describing sound using binary numbers, such that the tape recorder need only to distinguish between two conditions—the presence or the absence of a pulse. In the 1980s, digital recording technology was already being applied to multitrack studio recorders. The final combination of sounds is cut into the master disc from which commercial pressing will be made. The disc, a thin aluminum plate coated with plastic lacquer, has a surface that is cut by a helium-cooled stylus driven by a spiral form from a special tape machine. The disc-cutting lathe is a high-precision machine tool, and is fully automated. It controls the movement of the lathe so that grooves containing loud passages in the music are cut wider than those on soft passages.

In duplication, stampers are fitted to the pattern of hydraulic power which automatically puts labels on both sides and presses the plastic into the shape of the record at a pressure of 1,000 kilograms per square meters and at a temperature of 100 degrees centigrade. After the record is formed, it is mechanically removed from the press, trimmed, slipped into an inner sleeve which is then slipped into an outer sleeve. The process takes 25 seconds for a long-playing (LP) record.

A parallel operation is the high-speed duplication of music cassettes and cartridges. A master tape in the loop form replays continuously, feeding the program to the banks of slave recorders each loaded with “pancakes” (coils) of tapes 2,450 meters long. Both A and B titles are recorded on any one pass. Completely recorded pancakes are loaded into a machine which cuts the tapes, loads them into cassettes, and applies the label. The process takes 4.5 minutes.

With the advent of PCM (Pulse Code Modulation) digital recording and the development of compact disc (CD) format by Philips and Sony, the compact disc has become the fastest growing medium for the dissemination of prerecorded music. From the late 1980s to the present, sales of CDs now account for at least 10 percent of total sales of all prerecorded music.

After the music is recorded, visual artists, photographers, and printers collaborate to give the music a “face,” through appropriate and appealing graphic design on the album jacket or compact disc and cassette case. Since singers are an important selling point, their portrait usually graces the jacket or case. That portrait, however, as well as other elements of design such as color, letter types, and lines should be handled such that they reflect the kind of music the record contains. Soft, even romantic, images are usually associated with ballads, while experimental and innovative visuals are deemed perfect for heavy metal rock and new wave.

For promotion purposes, the first several hundred copies of the packaged record are distributed to most radio and TV stations and to some entertainment writers and reviewers. To boost record sales, the promotion strategy usually requires the artist to plug his or her album on radio stations in the country, which now number over 300, stage free mini-concerts in shopping malls, run provincial tours, and have scheduled appearances on TV variety shows.

In the mid-1970s, the production of a single cost between 1,500 to 2,500 pesos while an LP was from 20,000 to 30,000 pesos. A decade later, it went up to 10,000 to 15,000, and 80,000 pesos to 150,000 pesos, respectively. To date, the cost runs between 250,000 to 300,000 pesos for a respectable LP record of 10 songs. This amount excludes advertising and promotion costs, which could sometimes cost as much as production. That is why most recording companies do not release singles anymore.

The origin of commercial audio recordings in the Philippines could be traced back to the early 20th century. The first ever recording of Filipino music was done in 1906 in Louisiana, USA by musicologist Frances Densmore. Used in the recording were the indigenous instruments that were on display in the United States at that time. The said record and instruments were later donated to the Smithsonian Institute Library.

Decades earlier, French inventors Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville described ways to inscribe sounds with a phonautograph pen in 1857, and Émile-Hortensius-Charles Cros, in 1877, discovered a process called photoengraving that etched the inscription into a groove. A playback device called the phonograph was patented a year later by the American entrepreneur Thomas Edison. This machine had a stylus that ran through the groove, sending the inscription through a diaphragm and back into the air as sound. Records were originally sold as prerecorded wax cylinders, containing songs, instrumental music, or spoken word. The early phonograph cylinders were difficult to mass-produce until the arrival of the gramophone. Invented by the German-born American Emile Berliner in 1887, it utilized flat horizontal disks as the recording medium. Berliner supposedly worked with the businessman Elridge Johnson in founding the Victor Talking Machine Company, but the disruptive association concluded in Berliner’s defection to start his own Deutsche Grammophon.

Upon the official conclusion of the Philippine-American War in 1902, the Victor Talking Machine Company began selling phonographs in the fledgling American colony. Victor Records conducted the first series of recording sessions in the country, hoping to enhance and eventually cash in on the country’s rich musical tradition. The Erlanger & Galinger group scouted for local composers, singers, and musicians and within the year launched and popularized many of its discoveries.

Sometime before 1913, Major Anderson set up an audio production facility for Victor Records on the second floor of the Manila Hotel, most likely utilizing a mechanical recording process described as “direct-to-disc.” Performers gathered around a large acoustic horn while vibrations from its diaphragm guided a cutting lathe, etching the sound as a modulated groove onto the surface of a wax master disk. This master disk was sent to a processing plant in the United States where it was electroplated to create a negative metal stamper used to mold durable replicas of the recording. The discography of American historical recordings in the University of California Santa Barbara lists seven musical compositions by Jose Estella which were recorded from Jun 1912 to Oct 1914. These include “La Tagala” (The Tagalog Lady), “Mi Valse Soñado” (My Dream Waltz), “Piling,” and “Manila Carnival Rag.” These were works performed by brass bands, whose members were some of the first studio session musicians in the country.

Among the earliest Victor talents was sarsuwela star Maria Carpena, who did solos and duets with famous tenor Victorino Carrion. Her best pieces were “Ang mga Ibon” (The Birds) and “Ang Maya” (The Sparrow), both Tagalog waltzes by composer Jose Estella, and “Ang Geisha” (The Geisha) from the sarsuwela La Venta de Filipinas al Japon (The Sale of the Philippines to Japan). Other recording artists were Patrocinio Tagaroma and Jose Carvajal, who did songs from Spanish zarzuelas; and Socorro Basilio, Isabel Quintana, Sor F. Geronimo, Hilaria Alvarez, Atang de la Rama, and Amado Infante, who performed songs from the sarsuwela. The Molina Orchestra was the most sought-after session musicians at that time. There are extant ledgers from the RCA-Victor in America of seminal electrical recordings in later years by pioneer Philippine recording artists such as vocalists Natividad “Tinay” Arellano, Katy de la Cruz, who was the acknowledged “Jazz Queen” of her time, Pacita de Tavera, and Florentino Ballecer; songwriter-composers like Nicanor S. Abelardo; and spoken word performers such as Joaquin Gabino and Mercedes Nonato.

The subsequent invention of the microphone, a transducer or sensor that converted sound vibrations into electrical impulses, was a breakthrough that jumpstarted electrical recording, which, together with the sound amplifier, made mechanical recording methods obsolete in 1925. By 1933, acoustic recording was completely disused.

Later on, sound recording activities became indispensable to the emerging Philippine motion picture industry. The era’s most commercially viable talkies (i.e., sound pictures) debuted in local entertainment upon the arrival of Syncopation, 1929, an American musical film that utilized RCA’s photophone sound-on-film process, which premiered in 1930 at the Radio Theater located in Plaza Santa Cruz, Manila. Soon after, the film Ang Aswang (The Vampire), produced by George Musser and sound engineered by the audiographer William Smith at the Manila Talkatone Studio in Pandacan, was unveiled as the first talking film in the Philippines. It was simultaneously screened in Jan 1933 in the Tivoli Theater in Plaza Santa Cruz and the Lyric Theater in Manila’s fashionable Escolta Street. Competition must have been fierce, as only two months after, in early Mar 1933, the movie by the pioneering director Jose Nepomuceno, Punyal na Guinto (Golden Dagger), was screened at the Lyric Theater as the country’s first complete sound film, integrating dialogue and background music. The advent of movie talkies proved to be a new goldmine for music enthusiasts. Kundiman, jazz, ballad, and bodabil ditties virtually became the soundtrack of the Filipino way of life. These years of frenzied creation saw the growing competition between the pioneer Victor Records and the emerging Columbia and Odeon Companies, as radio stations KZIB, KZRM, and KZEG tried to outdo each other in hiring Filipino artists and technicians. Remarkable was the volume of musical compositions registered for copyright at the National Library, particularly in 1929.

Local vocalists and instrumentalists who mostly came from the bodabil stage cut records which gave them a name both here and abroad. Among those whose records earned praise in the United States, Europe, Mexico, and South America were Natividad Arellano, Jovita Fuentes, Mercedes Matias, Vicente Ocampo, Dionisia Castro, Honorata “Atang” de la Rama who was hailed as the “Queen of Kundiman and the Sarsuwela,” and Katy de la Cruz. Because of the popularity of declaimed poetry, the poems of Jose Corazon de Jesus and Florentino Collantes as well as the balagtasan between these two giants were also recorded. Bernabe Solis became the first Filipino record producer in 1926. His debut project, a Tagalog repertoire by Arellano, had to be recorded in the United States, for lack of proper equipment in the Philippines.

With the importation of advanced equipment after World War II, enterprising singer and band leader Cecil Lloyd and his friends set up the first Filipino-owned recording company in April 1948. The Philippine Recording System, under the labels Bataan and Molave, offered the public a version of “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut) and other popular folk songs arranged to rhumba rhythm. These innovations were, however, considered distasteful by the conservative audience.

Many names of the movie sound department personnel during this era would have been lost if not for the rosters of the annual Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awards that began in 1952. Charles Gray (Lebran Productions), Angelo Larraga (Sampaguita Pictures), July P. Hidalgo (LVN Pictures), Demetrio de Santos (Premiere Productions), Joseph Straight (Sampaguita Pictures), Luis Reyes (LVN Pictures), Flaviano Villareal (Sampaguita Pictures), Juanito Clemente (Nepomuceno Productions), Ben Patajo (LVN Pictures), and Enrique Bautista (LVN Pictures) were cited as the leading sound-on-film engineers during the Philippine movie industry’s Golden Age.

Much of the music that became popular before and after the World War II was American popular songs. Struggling against the overwhelming trend of American pop songs in radio, film, and recording was Villar Records, which specialized in the recording and dissemination of Filipino song forms. Villar Records, an independent Philippine record label specializing in folk music and popular songs using traditional forms, was launched by Manuel P. Villar in 1950. Lauded in later years as the “Father of Philippine Recording,” Villar produced songs by contemporary kundiman masters such as Constancio de Guzman, Levi Celerio, Leopoldo Silos, and Mike Velarde, committing their works to posterity. He became the founding president of the Record Industry Association of the Philippines (RIAP), the precursor of the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI). Villar Records itself belonged to a larger conglomerate that included an extensive radio network and recording facility whose sound engineer, Cesar Armario, was responsible for countless recordings of classic Philippine songs. The pioneering efforts of Villar Records became mainstream after the 1970s, when Pinoy pop music grew in leaps and bounds, specially because of the Metro Manila Popular Music Festival (Metropop) and the government order requiring that original Pilipino music (OPM) be played by all radio stations at regular intervals.

Other recording companies which produced OPM music in the last two decades are Wea (now Universal) Records, Vicor Music Corporation, OctoArts International, Dyna-ENU Records, BMG-Pilipinas, Viva Records, Alpha Records, Ivory Records, Platinum Records, Grandeur Records, Praise Records, Jem Records, A&W Records, GOI Records, Valley Records, Concorde Productions, Audio Music Corporation, Backbeat Music, Exotica Records, Golden Music Arts, Hitwave Marketing, Love Records and Tapes, JR Records and Tapes, Philharmonic Records, Richtone Corporation, Sound Publishing, Striker Records and Tapes, Telesis Recording and Entertainment Corp, VNM Productions, and A&B Recording.

There were recording studios in the country such as Greenhills Sound Production, Audio Captain Productions, Cinema Audio, JR Recording Studio, Studio Twenty-Two, Abbey Road Recording Studio, PM Recording Studio, and Richtone Studios. The vast Sampaguita Pictures compound in San Juan, Rizal operated a recording studio that serviced not only their internal sound stage requirements but also record companies that desired the live sound of their spacious recording room. The expertise of audio engineers such as Jess Payumo, Jun Orenza, Dante San Pedro, and Monching Payumo were sought by record company clients for their award winning circa-1970s mixes as disparate as “Ang Himig Natin” (Our Music) by the Juan de La Cruz Band and the jazz orchestra album of Lito Molina & The Jazz Friends. When Sampaguita Pictures closed their doors in the 1980s, their engineers migrated to a nearby facility in San Juan City that was just as expansive and had good acoustics—the Green Hill Recording Studio.

Responding to a soaring demand for professionally recorded musical films during the mid- to late 1960s boom, the actor Jose Mari Gonzales opened his own Cinema-Audio Recording Studios that largely defined the sound of classic OPM at the turn of the decade. The sound engineering team headed by Dindo Aldecoa, along with Ric Santos and Boy Roxas, was responsible for the rise of such recording stars as Sharon Cuneta, Kuh Ledesma, Freddie Aguilar, APO Hiking Society, and Basil Valdez.

The Tasha Recording Studio located in Libis, Quezon City, was built in the early-1980s by an expatriate American singer, Morris Albert, who employed the sound engineer, Edwin Luna. Together, they created a unique OPM sound characterized by automated reverberation effects and panoramic sound imaging that helped create the hits of Martin Nievera, Zsa Zsa Padilla, and Gary Valenciano. The comedian and politician Tito Sotto purchased the studio later in 1986, and commercial bookings continued until a tragic fire accident gutted the edifice. The setback was devastating to the OPM scene, if not symbolic of the changing times ahead.

For music produced from synthesizers, the final production needed the technical proficiency that can only be possible through mastering the final product in a recording studios. When expertise was required, boutique studios went into vogue such as the specialized Sweet Spot Solutions studio in Pasig City owned by the electronica music mavens Malek Lopez and the Hong Kong British expatriate Noel de Brackinghe; the more elaborate Tower of Doom studio in Quezon City servicing the heavy metal genre, operated by rock producer Eric Perlas; the Acoustic Underground in Quezon City, operated by Aji Manalo; and Sound Weavers, the recording studio in Makati City geared for the blues music community, operated by Gerry Diwa.

There were elaborately priced all-digital commercial enclaves typified by the award-winning Hit Productions in Makati City, owned by the songwriter expatriate Salito Malca and staffed by musician-engineers such as the siblings Angelo Villegas and Mike Villegas. But there were studios, too, that have become “indie remedies,” that is, those that bridged gear-deficient home recording studios and pricey enclaves but were popularly priced. One such Pro Tools studio was Sound Creation Studio, a facility with an elaborate acoustical room infrastructure run by the Filipino sound engineer Hazel Pascua and its owner, the expatriate Japanese musician-engineer Shinji Tanaka.

Youth bands playing real guitars and drums had a huge impact in pushing music recording into the digital age. Eraserheads and their producer Robin Rivera infused creativity into the multi-track magnetic tape environment of Jun Regalado’s JR Studio in Makati to shape their multi-platinum albums, Circus, 1994, and Cutterpillow, 1995, with the sound engineer, Lito Palco. Across the metropolis, in Pasig City, the studio named TRACKAcoustics/Studios, owned by the acoustic designer, Mike Pedero, and engineered by Angee Rozul had been making headway recording the world-folk album, Rippingyarns, 2000, by singer-songwriter Cynthia Alexander. Recording engineers and mixers are a prolific lot in the industry and have earned recognition from their peers. Some of those who have devoted many years to perfecting musical technology are Egay Guerrero, Lito Balagtas, Willy Munji, Dindo Aldecoa, Jess and Monching Payumo, Dante San Pedro, Jun Orense, Edwin Borja, Boy Roxas, Edwin Luna, Bobby Bagayava, Jaime Godinez, Joseph Roxas, and Voltaire Olpiano.

The long process of birthing a new record and the technological developments in sound recording all happen away from the spotlight, but these have certainly helped these performers’ rise in popularity: in the 1950s, Sylvia La Torre, Bobby Gonzales, Ruben Tagalog, Ric Manrique Jr, the Mabuhay Singers, and later Diomedes Maturan; in the 1960s, Pilita Corrales, Carmen Soriano, Carmen Pateña, Mercy Molina, and later, Helen Gamboa, Jeanne Young, Wing Duo, Reycard Duet, Tiongco Brothers, Pauline Sevilla, Eddie Peregrina, Nora Aunor, Tirso Cruz III, Vilma Santos, and Edgar Mortiz; in the 1970s, Juan de la Cruz Band, Hotdog, Lerma de la Cruz, Mike Hanopol, and later, the New Minstrels, Something Special, Circus Band, APO HikingSociety, Celeste Legaspi, Leah Navarro, Tillie Moreno, Aloha (now Ali Sotto), Coritha, Jacqui Magno, Lirio Vital, Susana Pichay, Cynthia Garcia, Maricris Bermont, Ray-an Fuentes, Basil Valdez, Rico J. Puno, Hajji Alejandro, Anthony Castelo, Rex Dimavivas, The Boyfriends, VST & Co., and Freddie Aguilar; in the 1980s, Imelda Papin, Eva Eugenio, Claire de la Fuente, Hagibis, Ric Segreto, and through the 1990s, Freddie Aguilar, Heber Bartolome, Yoyoy Villame, Dulce, Louie Reyes, Eugene Villaluz, Kuh Ledesma, Celeste Legaspi, Sharon Cuneta, Lea Salonga, Joey Albert, Ivy Violan, Vernie Varga, Zsa Zsa Padilla, Pops Fernandez, Regine Velasquez, Jamie Rivera, Odette Quesada, Nonoy Zuñiga, Marco Sison, Gary Valenciano, Martin Nievera, Randy Santiago, and Francis Magalona. Contemporary group performers include APO Hiking Society, Joey Ayala at ang Bagong Lumad, Smokey Mountain, Tux, The CompanY, The Opera, Neocolours, The Dawn, Side A Band, The Hayp, The Introvoys, The Afterimage, and Eraserheads.

There are ongoing discussions favoring the well-defined digital domain versus the warmth of natural acoustics. These discussions have ramifications on the characteristics of the musical creative process, and the genres they engender, which ultimately influences public perception, artistic preferences, and the overall business process itself of a very challenged and diversified recording industry. Written by Joseph Voltaire L. Contreras, Juan Bautista H. Alegre, and Arwin Q. Tan

article.value: Recording refers to the process of making copies of a piece or pieces of music for public dissemination. The process includes the preproduction phase, in which the producers and their assistants decide on the concept, programming, and performance of the piece/pieces of music; the production phase, which includes the creation of the musical arrangements, the rehearsals, the actual performance and recording, and the editing and mixing; and the postproduction phase, which concentrates on the duplication of copies, and the promotion and marketing of the finished products.

article.value: The making of a record begins with the search for material. The producer can personally ask composers for new works or do research on unrecorded music in the music library, usually housed within the premises of the recording company. Popular music composers include Jess Saclo, Danny Subido, Ernani Cuenco, George Canseco, Vic Villafuerte, Mike Hanopol, Joey “Pepe” Smith, Freddie Aguilar, Heber Bartolome, Ryan Cayabyab, Willy Cruz, Jim Paredes, Danny Javier, Gines Tan, Danny Tan, Florante de Leon, Gary Granada, Jose Mari Chan, Ernie de la Peña, Nonong Pedero, Cecile Azarcon-Palma, Odette Quesada, Nonoy Gallardo, Paul Galang, Charo Unite, Tats Faustino, Snaffu Rigor, Nonoy Tan, Vehnee Saturno, Rey Valera, Louie Ocampo, Jimmy Antiporda, and Gary Valenciano. In this search for material, the producer is assisted by the audition and research (A & R) person, who takes care of looking for talents and studios to be rented, establishing contacts with the arranger and sound engineers, and attending to the copyright demands of the selected songs.

A preproduction meeting is set so that the singer, the producer, the A & R person, and preferably the arranger, can hear and study prospective materials. For a more objective evaluation of their works, the composer of these materials is usually excluded from the discussion. The group brainstorms and decides on the concept of the record, including the final selections, the type of arrangement needed, and the target audience (i.e., rural or urban). The producer gives all the guidelines to the singer, who will then study the lyrics and melody for a week or so before recording sessions formally start.

article.value: The production phase is usually the domain of an audio recording engineer. He is responsible for recording, manipulating, mixing, and mechanically reproducing sound. He works closely with songwriters, music arrangers, and especially session musicians, vocalists, and instrumentalists who render parts of musical arrangements in sound studios.

First to be recorded or dubbed is the minus one or the instrumental accompaniment. The arranger creates this according to the guidelines laid out by the producer as to the desired beat, key, and instrumentation. Some of the music industry’s arrangers are Domingo Amarillo, Emi and Eddie Munji, Jun Latonio, Emil Mijares, Lorrie Ilustre, Danny Favis, Amado Triviño, Butch Miraflor, Angel M. Peña, Rey Magtoto, and Dante Trinidad, most of whom have harnessed their talents in arranging song-entries to the Metropop contest. Others have branched into musical direction for TV shows or concerts: Dominic Salustiano was the resident arranger and musical director of RPN 9’s Bagong Kampeon (New Champion), a popular amateur singing contest on TV; Mon Faustino regularly did the arrangements for Gary Valenciano’s concerts; Mel Villena was the regular musical director of Sharon Cuneta’s concerts here and abroad; Homer Flores was the regular musical director of musical variety shows like Vilma! and Eat Bulaga!; and Egay Gonzales did several musical directing stints in local concerts of pop singing idols and was also the musical director of the Sunday noontime show Sa Linggo nAPO Sila. Some arrangers devoted most of their time to individual singers, like Alvin Nuñez who regularly did the arrangements of Jose Mari Chan’s songs.

The singer is asked to attend this first recording session to make sure he or she is comfortable with the key of the accompaniment. Once the arrangement is approved, the arranger rehearses the session musicians who have been recruited by the A & R person. When the musicians are ready, the recording is done. Before the singer’s voice is recorded, though, he or she may listen to the songs as sung by the composer with the minus one and from there create his or her own interpretation of the song. The singer undergoes lengthy rehearsals with the producer or composer for emotional motivation and musical approach.

After the lead vocals have been recorded, another session is set for the backup vocals, as required by the arranger. The lead performer need not be present at this point because the support vocalists can already go by his or her voice track in the minus one. Session musicians used to be recruited from Aroma Cafe in the post-World War II decades. Later, individual musicians were contacted directly or drawn from established orchestras. Some of the session musicians who recorded for the industry were Polding Silos, Jun Regalado, Roger Herrera, Narding Castañeda, Ponching Belsonda, and Rudy Lozano, as well as musicians from the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and Manila Symphony Orchestra.

The editing-mixing stage is considered the most crucial. Here, the various recorded tracks are manipulated to create an aural picture of the entire performance. The trained ears of mixers intimately attend to the details, as they study each track to decide which instrument must be heard only on the left or right speaker, or which song should be added if there are still vacant tracks available. As with the vocals, it is here where the singer or singers’ mistakes and deficiencies can be electronically corrected and improved through proper adjustments on the reverb, echo, or sustain functions.

Most of the technology that the music recording industry in the United States developed from the 1960s to the present have been imported and used through the last three decades by major Filipino-owned recording companies. Some notable technological innovations of the last decade include the multitrack systems of recording sounds and the use of synthesizers. The commercial viability of sound recordings also brought musical entrepreneurship into vogue.

It can replace the human fingers on the piano or guitar, and can mask or eliminate a singer’s faltering notes, giving a wrong impression of the singer’s abilities.

Towards the mid-1980s, keyboard devices and synthesizers became very affordable in the Philippines. By stacking the audio output from these varied instruments, keyboardists and musical arrangers attempted to approximate the rich textures and densities of a real orchestra simply by linking and overlapping sound modules together. MIDI also brought music sequencers into the recording mainstream that assimilated streams of hardware devices and application products to record, edit, and play back pop music as it has not been previously realized.

The disadvantage was that sequencers effectively disenfranchised numerous studio session musicians from studio work, including violinists, violists, cellists, and brass ensemble players. There was an exodus of traditional musicians to jobs in other environments such as cruise ships and overseas hotels. Anyone, even those with little or no skill to read or write musical notation, became quickly empowered songwriters and MIDI orchestrators on sequencer booms. Soon the technology became pervasive that DIY (Do It Yourself) home recording studios spread far and wide in Manila.

In the 1990s, numerous recording studios began utilizing Pro Tools, a hardware-software combination in the Apple Mac computer that simulated traditional analog recording processes in a digital environment. Subsequently, a slew of Windows-based DAW (Digital Audio Workstation) platforms also became prevalent.

Much progress has been achieved in studio recording: from the restrictive mono, to the 2, 4, 8, 16, and even 24-track capacity, which allows the recording of as many instruments or voices. Multitrack recorders in the United States can go up to 72 tracks. The multitrack or multihead recording gives the arranger free rein in putting emphasis or in downplaying a particular sound from among the tracks in use. The piano, for example, can be highlighted, while the guitars, drums, and other instruments can be muffled.

In the early 1970s, digital recording started to replace analogue recording. Analogue recording has to cope with a whole range of levels and frequencies. Digital recording improves on the analogue by describing sound using binary numbers, such that the tape recorder need only to distinguish between two conditions—the presence or the absence of a pulse. In the 1980s, digital recording technology was already being applied to multitrack studio recorders. The final combination of sounds is cut into the master disc from which commercial pressing will be made. The disc, a thin aluminum plate coated with plastic lacquer, has a surface that is cut by a helium-cooled stylus driven by a spiral form from a special tape machine. The disc-cutting lathe is a high-precision machine tool, and is fully automated. It controls the movement of the lathe so that grooves containing loud passages in the music are cut wider than those on soft passages.

In duplication, stampers are fitted to the pattern of hydraulic power which automatically puts labels on both sides and presses the plastic into the shape of the record at a pressure of 1,000 kilograms per square meters and at a temperature of 100 degrees centigrade. After the record is formed, it is mechanically removed from the press, trimmed, slipped into an inner sleeve which is then slipped into an outer sleeve. The process takes 25 seconds for a long-playing (LP) record.

A parallel operation is the high-speed duplication of music cassettes and cartridges. A master tape in the loop form replays continuously, feeding the program to the banks of slave recorders each loaded with “pancakes” (coils) of tapes 2,450 meters long. Both A and B titles are recorded on any one pass. Completely recorded pancakes are loaded into a machine which cuts the tapes, loads them into cassettes, and applies the label. The process takes 4.5 minutes.

With the advent of PCM (Pulse Code Modulation) digital recording and the development of compact disc (CD) format by Philips and Sony, the compact disc has become the fastest growing medium for the dissemination of prerecorded music. From the late 1980s to the present, sales of CDs now account for at least 10 percent of total sales of all prerecorded music.

After the music is recorded, visual artists, photographers, and printers collaborate to give the music a “face,” through appropriate and appealing graphic design on the album jacket or compact disc and cassette case. Since singers are an important selling point, their portrait usually graces the jacket or case. That portrait, however, as well as other elements of design such as color, letter types, and lines should be handled such that they reflect the kind of music the record contains. Soft, even romantic, images are usually associated with ballads, while experimental and innovative visuals are deemed perfect for heavy metal rock and new wave.

For promotion purposes, the first several hundred copies of the packaged record are distributed to most radio and TV stations and to some entertainment writers and reviewers. To boost record sales, the promotion strategy usually requires the artist to plug his or her album on radio stations in the country, which now number over 300, stage free mini-concerts in shopping malls, run provincial tours, and have scheduled appearances on TV variety shows.

In the mid-1970s, the production of a single cost between 1,500 to 2,500 pesos while an LP was from 20,000 to 30,000 pesos. A decade later, it went up to 10,000 to 15,000, and 80,000 pesos to 150,000 pesos, respectively. To date, the cost runs between 250,000 to 300,000 pesos for a respectable LP record of 10 songs. This amount excludes advertising and promotion costs, which could sometimes cost as much as production. That is why most recording companies do not release singles anymore.

The origin of commercial audio recordings in the Philippines could be traced back to the early 20th century. The first ever recording of Filipino music was done in 1906 in Louisiana, USA by musicologist Frances Densmore. Used in the recording were the indigenous instruments that were on display in the United States at that time. The said record and instruments were later donated to the Smithsonian Institute Library.

Decades earlier, French inventors Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville described ways to inscribe sounds with a phonautograph pen in 1857, and Émile-Hortensius-Charles Cros, in 1877, discovered a process called photoengraving that etched the inscription into a groove. A playback device called the phonograph was patented a year later by the American entrepreneur Thomas Edison. This machine had a stylus that ran through the groove, sending the inscription through a diaphragm and back into the air as sound. Records were originally sold as prerecorded wax cylinders, containing songs, instrumental music, or spoken word. The early phonograph cylinders were difficult to mass-produce until the arrival of the gramophone. Invented by the German-born American Emile Berliner in 1887, it utilized flat horizontal disks as the recording medium. Berliner supposedly worked with the businessman Elridge Johnson in founding the Victor Talking Machine Company, but the disruptive association concluded in Berliner’s defection to start his own Deutsche Grammophon.

Upon the official conclusion of the Philippine-American War in 1902, the Victor Talking Machine Company began selling phonographs in the fledgling American colony. Victor Records conducted the first series of recording sessions in the country, hoping to enhance and eventually cash in on the country’s rich musical tradition. The Erlanger & Galinger group scouted for local composers, singers, and musicians and within the year launched and popularized many of its discoveries.

Sometime before 1913, Major Anderson set up an audio production facility for Victor Records on the second floor of the Manila Hotel, most likely utilizing a mechanical recording process described as “direct-to-disc.” Performers gathered around a large acoustic horn while vibrations from its diaphragm guided a cutting lathe, etching the sound as a modulated groove onto the surface of a wax master disk. This master disk was sent to a processing plant in the United States where it was electroplated to create a negative metal stamper used to mold durable replicas of the recording. The discography of American historical recordings in the University of California Santa Barbara lists seven musical compositions by Jose Estella which were recorded from Jun 1912 to Oct 1914. These include “La Tagala” (The Tagalog Lady), “Mi Valse Soñado” (My Dream Waltz), “Piling,” and “Manila Carnival Rag.” These were works performed by brass bands, whose members were some of the first studio session musicians in the country.

Among the earliest Victor talents was sarsuwela star Maria Carpena, who did solos and duets with famous tenor Victorino Carrion. Her best pieces were “Ang mga Ibon” (The Birds) and “Ang Maya” (The Sparrow), both Tagalog waltzes by composer Jose Estella, and “Ang Geisha” (The Geisha) from the sarsuwela La Venta de Filipinas al Japon (The Sale of the Philippines to Japan). Other recording artists were Patrocinio Tagaroma and Jose Carvajal, who did songs from Spanish zarzuelas; and Socorro Basilio, Isabel Quintana, Sor F. Geronimo, Hilaria Alvarez, Atang de la Rama, and Amado Infante, who performed songs from the sarsuwela. The Molina Orchestra was the most sought-after session musicians at that time. There are extant ledgers from the RCA-Victor in America of seminal electrical recordings in later years by pioneer Philippine recording artists such as vocalists Natividad “Tinay” Arellano, Katy de la Cruz, who was the acknowledged “Jazz Queen” of her time, Pacita de Tavera, and Florentino Ballecer; songwriter-composers like Nicanor S. Abelardo; and spoken word performers such as Joaquin Gabino and Mercedes Nonato.

The subsequent invention of the microphone, a transducer or sensor that converted sound vibrations into electrical impulses, was a breakthrough that jumpstarted electrical recording, which, together with the sound amplifier, made mechanical recording methods obsolete in 1925. By 1933, acoustic recording was completely disused.

Later on, sound recording activities became indispensable to the emerging Philippine motion picture industry. The era’s most commercially viable talkies (i.e., sound pictures) debuted in local entertainment upon the arrival of Syncopation, 1929, an American musical film that utilized RCA’s photophone sound-on-film process, which premiered in 1930 at the Radio Theater located in Plaza Santa Cruz, Manila. Soon after, the film Ang Aswang (The Vampire), produced by George Musser and sound engineered by the audiographer William Smith at the Manila Talkatone Studio in Pandacan, was unveiled as the first talking film in the Philippines. It was simultaneously screened in Jan 1933 in the Tivoli Theater in Plaza Santa Cruz and the Lyric Theater in Manila’s fashionable Escolta Street. Competition must have been fierce, as only two months after, in early Mar 1933, the movie by the pioneering director Jose Nepomuceno, Punyal na Guinto (Golden Dagger), was screened at the Lyric Theater as the country’s first complete sound film, integrating dialogue and background music. The advent of movie talkies proved to be a new goldmine for music enthusiasts. Kundiman, jazz, ballad, and bodabil ditties virtually became the soundtrack of the Filipino way of life. These years of frenzied creation saw the growing competition between the pioneer Victor Records and the emerging Columbia and Odeon Companies, as radio stations KZIB, KZRM, and KZEG tried to outdo each other in hiring Filipino artists and technicians. Remarkable was the volume of musical compositions registered for copyright at the National Library, particularly in 1929.

Local vocalists and instrumentalists who mostly came from the bodabil stage cut records which gave them a name both here and abroad. Among those whose records earned praise in the United States, Europe, Mexico, and South America were Natividad Arellano, Jovita Fuentes, Mercedes Matias, Vicente Ocampo, Dionisia Castro, Honorata “Atang” de la Rama who was hailed as the “Queen of Kundiman and the Sarsuwela,” and Katy de la Cruz. Because of the popularity of declaimed poetry, the poems of Jose Corazon de Jesus and Florentino Collantes as well as the balagtasan between these two giants were also recorded. Bernabe Solis became the first Filipino record producer in 1926. His debut project, a Tagalog repertoire by Arellano, had to be recorded in the United States, for lack of proper equipment in the Philippines.

With the importation of advanced equipment after World War II, enterprising singer and band leader Cecil Lloyd and his friends set up the first Filipino-owned recording company in April 1948. The Philippine Recording System, under the labels Bataan and Molave, offered the public a version of “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut) and other popular folk songs arranged to rhumba rhythm. These innovations were, however, considered distasteful by the conservative audience.

Many names of the movie sound department personnel during this era would have been lost if not for the rosters of the annual Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awards that began in 1952. Charles Gray (Lebran Productions), Angelo Larraga (Sampaguita Pictures), July P. Hidalgo (LVN Pictures), Demetrio de Santos (Premiere Productions), Joseph Straight (Sampaguita Pictures), Luis Reyes (LVN Pictures), Flaviano Villareal (Sampaguita Pictures), Juanito Clemente (Nepomuceno Productions), Ben Patajo (LVN Pictures), and Enrique Bautista (LVN Pictures) were cited as the leading sound-on-film engineers during the Philippine movie industry’s Golden Age.

Much of the music that became popular before and after the World War II was American popular songs. Struggling against the overwhelming trend of American pop songs in radio, film, and recording was Villar Records, which specialized in the recording and dissemination of Filipino song forms. Villar Records, an independent Philippine record label specializing in folk music and popular songs using traditional forms, was launched by Manuel P. Villar in 1950. Lauded in later years as the “Father of Philippine Recording,” Villar produced songs by contemporary kundiman masters such as Constancio de Guzman, Levi Celerio, Leopoldo Silos, and Mike Velarde, committing their works to posterity. He became the founding president of the Record Industry Association of the Philippines (RIAP), the precursor of the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI). Villar Records itself belonged to a larger conglomerate that included an extensive radio network and recording facility whose sound engineer, Cesar Armario, was responsible for countless recordings of classic Philippine songs. The pioneering efforts of Villar Records became mainstream after the 1970s, when Pinoy pop music grew in leaps and bounds, specially because of the Metro Manila Popular Music Festival (Metropop) and the government order requiring that original Pilipino music (OPM) be played by all radio stations at regular intervals.

Other recording companies which produced OPM music in the last two decades are Wea (now Universal) Records, Vicor Music Corporation, OctoArts International, Dyna-ENU Records, BMG-Pilipinas, Viva Records, Alpha Records, Ivory Records, Platinum Records, Grandeur Records, Praise Records, Jem Records, A&W Records, GOI Records, Valley Records, Concorde Productions, Audio Music Corporation, Backbeat Music, Exotica Records, Golden Music Arts, Hitwave Marketing, Love Records and Tapes, JR Records and Tapes, Philharmonic Records, Richtone Corporation, Sound Publishing, Striker Records and Tapes, Telesis Recording and Entertainment Corp, VNM Productions, and A&B Recording.

There were recording studios in the country such as Greenhills Sound Production, Audio Captain Productions, Cinema Audio, JR Recording Studio, Studio Twenty-Two, Abbey Road Recording Studio, PM Recording Studio, and Richtone Studios. The vast Sampaguita Pictures compound in San Juan, Rizal operated a recording studio that serviced not only their internal sound stage requirements but also record companies that desired the live sound of their spacious recording room. The expertise of audio engineers such as Jess Payumo, Jun Orenza, Dante San Pedro, and Monching Payumo were sought by record company clients for their award winning circa-1970s mixes as disparate as “Ang Himig Natin” (Our Music) by the Juan de La Cruz Band and the jazz orchestra album of Lito Molina & The Jazz Friends. When Sampaguita Pictures closed their doors in the 1980s, their engineers migrated to a nearby facility in San Juan City that was just as expansive and had good acoustics—the Green Hill Recording Studio.

Responding to a soaring demand for professionally recorded musical films during the mid- to late 1960s boom, the actor Jose Mari Gonzales opened his own Cinema-Audio Recording Studios that largely defined the sound of classic OPM at the turn of the decade. The sound engineering team headed by Dindo Aldecoa, along with Ric Santos and Boy Roxas, was responsible for the rise of such recording stars as Sharon Cuneta, Kuh Ledesma, Freddie Aguilar, APO Hiking Society, and Basil Valdez.

The Tasha Recording Studio located in Libis, Quezon City, was built in the early-1980s by an expatriate American singer, Morris Albert, who employed the sound engineer, Edwin Luna. Together, they created a unique OPM sound characterized by automated reverberation effects and panoramic sound imaging that helped create the hits of Martin Nievera, Zsa Zsa Padilla, and Gary Valenciano. The comedian and politician Tito Sotto purchased the studio later in 1986, and commercial bookings continued until a tragic fire accident gutted the edifice. The setback was devastating to the OPM scene, if not symbolic of the changing times ahead.

For music produced from synthesizers, the final production needed the technical proficiency that can only be possible through mastering the final product in a recording studios. When expertise was required, boutique studios went into vogue such as the specialized Sweet Spot Solutions studio in Pasig City owned by the electronica music mavens Malek Lopez and the Hong Kong British expatriate Noel de Brackinghe; the more elaborate Tower of Doom studio in Quezon City servicing the heavy metal genre, operated by rock producer Eric Perlas; the Acoustic Underground in Quezon City, operated by Aji Manalo; and Sound Weavers, the recording studio in Makati City geared for the blues music community, operated by Gerry Diwa.

There were elaborately priced all-digital commercial enclaves typified by the award-winning Hit Productions in Makati City, owned by the songwriter expatriate Salito Malca and staffed by musician-engineers such as the siblings Angelo Villegas and Mike Villegas. But there were studios, too, that have become “indie remedies,” that is, those that bridged gear-deficient home recording studios and pricey enclaves but were popularly priced. One such Pro Tools studio was Sound Creation Studio, a facility with an elaborate acoustical room infrastructure run by the Filipino sound engineer Hazel Pascua and its owner, the expatriate Japanese musician-engineer Shinji Tanaka.

Youth bands playing real guitars and drums had a huge impact in pushing music recording into the digital age. Eraserheads and their producer Robin Rivera infused creativity into the multi-track magnetic tape environment of Jun Regalado’s JR Studio in Makati to shape their multi-platinum albums, Circus, 1994, and Cutterpillow, 1995, with the sound engineer, Lito Palco. Across the metropolis, in Pasig City, the studio named TRACKAcoustics/Studios, owned by the acoustic designer, Mike Pedero, and engineered by Angee Rozul had been making headway recording the world-folk album, Rippingyarns, 2000, by singer-songwriter Cynthia Alexander. Recording engineers and mixers are a prolific lot in the industry and have earned recognition from their peers. Some of those who have devoted many years to perfecting musical technology are Egay Guerrero, Lito Balagtas, Willy Munji, Dindo Aldecoa, Jess and Monching Payumo, Dante San Pedro, Jun Orense, Edwin Borja, Boy Roxas, Edwin Luna, Bobby Bagayava, Jaime Godinez, Joseph Roxas, and Voltaire Olpiano.

The long process of birthing a new record and the technological developments in sound recording all happen away from the spotlight, but these have certainly helped these performers’ rise in popularity: in the 1950s, Sylvia La Torre, Bobby Gonzales, Ruben Tagalog, Ric Manrique Jr, the Mabuhay Singers, and later Diomedes Maturan; in the 1960s, Pilita Corrales, Carmen Soriano, Carmen Pateña, Mercy Molina, and later, Helen Gamboa, Jeanne Young, Wing Duo, Reycard Duet, Tiongco Brothers, Pauline Sevilla, Eddie Peregrina, Nora Aunor, Tirso Cruz III, Vilma Santos, and Edgar Mortiz; in the 1970s, Juan de la Cruz Band, Hotdog, Lerma de la Cruz, Mike Hanopol, and later, the New Minstrels, Something Special, Circus Band, APO HikingSociety, Celeste Legaspi, Leah Navarro, Tillie Moreno, Aloha (now Ali Sotto), Coritha, Jacqui Magno, Lirio Vital, Susana Pichay, Cynthia Garcia, Maricris Bermont, Ray-an Fuentes, Basil Valdez, Rico J. Puno, Hajji Alejandro, Anthony Castelo, Rex Dimavivas, The Boyfriends, VST & Co., and Freddie Aguilar; in the 1980s, Imelda Papin, Eva Eugenio, Claire de la Fuente, Hagibis, Ric Segreto, and through the 1990s, Freddie Aguilar, Heber Bartolome, Yoyoy Villame, Dulce, Louie Reyes, Eugene Villaluz, Kuh Ledesma, Celeste Legaspi, Sharon Cuneta, Lea Salonga, Joey Albert, Ivy Violan, Vernie Varga, Zsa Zsa Padilla, Pops Fernandez, Regine Velasquez, Jamie Rivera, Odette Quesada, Nonoy Zuñiga, Marco Sison, Gary Valenciano, Martin Nievera, Randy Santiago, and Francis Magalona. Contemporary group performers include APO Hiking Society, Joey Ayala at ang Bagong Lumad, Smokey Mountain, Tux, The CompanY, The Opera, Neocolours, The Dawn, Side A Band, The Hayp, The Introvoys, The Afterimage, and Eraserheads.

There are ongoing discussions favoring the well-defined digital domain versus the warmth of natural acoustics. These discussions have ramifications on the characteristics of the musical creative process, and the genres they engender, which ultimately influences public perception, artistic preferences, and the overall business process itself of a very challenged and diversified recording industry. Written by Joseph Voltaire L. Contreras, Juan Bautista H. Alegre, and Arwin Q. Tan

text:
Indigenous and Western musical instruments are both used in the Philippines. Around 10 percent of the Philippine population plays indigenous music during religious rituals and feasts, and in secular activities, while the remaining percent performs using instruments that are mostly Western in origin. Among the indigenous musical instruments used are bamboo instruments such as buzzers, clappers, scrapers, paired-string zithers, slit drums, mouth harps, flutes, reed pipes, and polychordal zithers; bronze instruments like flat gongs and suspended gongs; and two-string lutes called kutyapi (boat lute). On the other hand, Western musical instruments, which the Philippines adopted through more than three hundred years of Spanish occupation (from 1565 to 1898), include string, wind, percussion, and keyboard instruments.

 

Performers who work with musical instruments must be complemented by skilled instrument makers to assure their artistic survival and growth. This article focuses on makers of Western instruments in the Philippines, particularly stringed instrument makers.

The migration of craftsmen, including makers of musical instruments, from Mexico to the Philippines happened during the transpacific galleon trade in the 16th century. These Mexican luthiers spread across the Philippines and became responsible for the arrival of many types of stringed instruments in the islands. Unfortunately, records did not mention specific names of early luthiers who built stringed instruments in the country until the late 19th century.

Pedro Buencamino was the earliest stringed instrument maker and repairer on record. He was born on 1 Aug 1866 in Abukay, Bataan. Buencamino never finished his schooling and became a circus performer at thirteen years old. He toured around the country as part of the circus, from which he learned to play the guitar. After ten years of performing in the circus, Buencamino decided to retire and settled in Manila, then later on began repairing guitars in his house at Isaac Peral Street. It is believed that he acquired his skill from his frequent visits to repair shops in Ongpin Street, Manila. During the revolution in 1896, he and his wife Petra Martin evacuated to San Fernando, Pampanga where they established a music store cum barber shop. After three years, the couple decided to go back to Manila. Later on, Buencamino was awarded a medal in 1904 when he exhibited his stringed instruments at the Philippine Exposition. He established the music store El Sol Mayor in 1916. This store, located in Rizal Avenue, Santa Cruz, Manila, he maintained until his death in 1923.

Aside from guitars, Buencamino also manufactured violins, violoncellos, and basses. Moreover, Buencamino, together with another luthier named Andres, operated another guitar factory in San Miguel District in Manila. To commemorate the existence of the factory in that neighborhood, the district’s bridge was named Puente Guitarrero or Guitarist’s Bridge. Buencamino used local woods for his guitars like narra, laniti, and langka for the backs and sides; palochina or white pine for the top; and kamagong for the fingerboard.

Buencamino’s former workers, namely Fausto Martin and Alejandro de la Rosa, continued the tradition of stringed instrument making in the country. Martin became an expert violin and cello repairman. He was known because of the recommendation of famous musicians during the time such as Ramon Corpus, Bonifacio Abdon, Alejandro Arellano, Ernesto Vallejo, and Antonio Molina, who lauded his ability to improve the appearance as well as the tonality of the instruments.

Meanwhile, de la Rosa opened a violin repair shop in Tondo, Manila. His specialization in enhancing and refining the tonal features of the violin earned him the title “Hari” or “King of Filipino Repairmen.” Alejandro de la Rosa was made famous by foreign violin virtuosi who visited the country, as these violinists like Cecilia Hanson and Piastro were impressed with his work when they asked him to restore their Stradivarius violins. Because of his exceptional ability, these foreigners recommended him to others after going back to their countries. As a result, de la Rosa was highly regarded not only in the Philippines but also in other countries—he even got offers from repair shops in the United States, France, Italy, Germany, and Russia to supervise their manufacturing and repairing of violins, but he decided to stay in the country. Besides violin repairing and manufacturing, de la Rosa was also a famous guitar maker. He started making toy guitars from coconut shells before the age of ten, and before he was twenty, the guitars he made became very popular in the cities and provinces of the country.

Innovation and experimentation were also seen in the early part of the history of Filipino stringed instrument makers. One of those who dared was Casto Maria de Nieva. He was born 1 Jul 1873 in Boac, Marinduque. In 1882, de Nieva went to Manila and studied at the Ateneo de Manila then finished his bachelor of arts degree at the University of Santo Tomas in 1894. He was known for being innovative as he made his own repairing and manufacturing tools. He also experimented on the use of a wood in 1925, as he made a special violin using one wood, the laniti, for the top, back and sides, neck, and scroll. It had been said that to produce a good sound, the violin’s body should not be made of a single kind of wood. But, de Nieva’s experiment proved to be successful, as observed by the former National Library Director Epifanio de los Santos. He also built cellos or violoncellos, based on the paper labels of his instruments which said “Casto Nieva, Constructor de Violines y Violoncellos, Manila, Islas Filipinas.” He died on 21 May 1935, leaving behind violins which were products of his creativity.

Another expert violin repairman was Domingo Pesigan, born in Calamba, Laguna on 24 Jul 1906 and recognized during the early part of the 20th century. He became a worker of well-known violinmaker Alejandro de la Rosa, but later, after honing his skills, he established his own music shop in Manila. He also explored the use of Philippine woods like laniti, pino, and kamagong. Among his customers and patrons who kept his shop busy and thriving were Ramon Tapales, Servilla Castillejos, Pablo Palomo, Manuel Bautista, and Basilio Manalo.

In 1911, a shop named Compositor de Instrumentos de Cuerda was established by Eusebio Cabiluña. Cabiluña was a famous repairman of wind and percussion instruments as well as a maker of guitars, banjos, ukuleles, and rondalla. Cabiluña supplied instruments to Cebu’s rondalla group La Juventud Filipina.

One of the most significant guitar makers in the Philippines during the second half of the 1900s was Michael Romero. A native of Baliangao, Misamis Occidental, Romero used to be a customs officer in Manila during the 1960s. He started to become curious about why imported classical guitars passing through their office were always being declared of high value. He started researching on the materials and process used for making classical guitar. He bought books and tools on making quality classical guitars. In 1969, Romero started building quality guitars in his house in Magallanes Village, Makati City. On 19 Apr 1970, he decided to commercially open a guitar store and shop in Mercedes Street, Pinagkaisahan, Makati City. He named his shop Guitarmasters. He recruited guitar makers from the Visayas to become his workers. The number one luthier in the shop was Flavio Bilbao from the province of Bohol. In addition, Romero also hired guitar luthiers from Cebu province such as Demetrio Aying, Nardo Ompad, and Alex Ompad.

Guitarmasters was considered one of the first to make high quality guitars in Metro Manila. The shop used imported quality woods like spruce and rosewood to be able to build good-sounding guitars. It also experimented in using local woods such as langka for the top and ipil for the back and sides. During the 1970s, the shop also became the favorite hangout place of classical guitarists Jose Valdez, Raul Manikan, and Mario Rodriguez. Aside from making and selling guitars, the shop also offered guitar lessons to aspiring students.

Another achievement of Guitarmasters was that it provided quality instruments to concert guitarists during this time when guitar concertizing in the country was only beginning. The elite classical guitarists helped in promoting Guitarmasters by using its guitars during concerts and recommending them to their students, friends, and guitar aficionados. Romero also made a ten-string guitar exclusively for Jose Valdez in 1973. On 14 Dec of the same year, Valdez held a concert at the Philamlife Auditorium using the Imelda Model, a specially made guitar by Guitarmasters inspired by then-First Lady Imelda Marcos’s efforts to revive music in the country. Guitarmasters flourished from 1970 to 1983. Because of unfortunate events in the family of the owner, Guitarmasters experienced financial instability and closed down in the latter part of the 1980s.

The tradition of stringed instrument making in the country developed with the help and contributions of the luthiers in the latter part of the 20th century. Some of these are guitar makers Dominguez Javier, Mario Rodriguez, Raul Manikan; and bowed instrument makers Amador Tamayo (violin/viola/cello), Angel Gabute (violin/double bass), and Efren Tapao, Dante Gabute, Romeo Gabute, and Bening Abarrientos (double bass). Most of them are still producing quality instruments until today, supplying instruments to concert artists and music students from different schools in Manila and in the provinces, including international classical performers. Aside from these individual makers, big shops with lots of instrument makers are still flourishing in the country today like in Raon, Quiapo, and Santa Mesa in Manila, in Guagua, Pampanga, and in Cebu.

The most significant guitar maker in the 21st century is Cebu native Armando Derecho aka Tabo. He is considered one of the best Filipino classical guitar makers who just officially started to market his guitar recently. In 1982, Derecho enrolled in University of the Philippines College of Music as a guitar major. He is one of the original members of the UP Guitar Ensemble that toured in Australia during the 1980s. Derecho also became a guitarist of the UP Concert Chorus and the UP Filipiniana Dance Troupe in the late 80s to the early 90s. After hearing good quality classical guitars in UP, specifically his professor’s imported guitar, Derecho asked himself why Cebuanos could not make that kind of guitar. Derecho challenged himself and started learning how to build guitars.

Derecho had formal studies on guitar making with Mario Rodriguez, a guitar maker and a teacher at the UST Conservatory of Music. He went to Rodriguez’s house in Cainta almost every day for more than two years to observe and try building guitars under the supervision of his teacher. In the late 1990s, Rodriguez left the country for the United States, and this was the time when Derecho tried making his own guitars. Rodriguez gave him a second hand mold and some guitar making books to start his guitar making hobby. During that time, he was a full-time performer in hotels and restaurants in Metro Manila. Derecho constructed his guitars in his boarding house during his free time before going to his gigs.

Derecho, together with his wife, decided to move to Marikina City in 1999. In April of the same year, he rented a lot behind his backyard and turned it into a guitar shop, which he later transferred beside his house. Nardo Ompad, a former worker in Guitarmasters, met Derecho and applied to be his assistant. To this date, Ompad still works at Derecho’s shop in Marikina. Derecho guitars use high quality imported materials such as spruce, cedar, rosewood, and pine. Since 1999, Derecho has built more than 100 guitars. Derecho guitars became very significant during the early 2000s because they gave classical guitar players access to locally made quality guitars. These guitars are as good as the imported ones but come with a lower tag price. He is presently one of the Filipino guitar makers, if not the only one, in the country who can make classical guitars that can match the quality of imported concert model guitars. Written by Nathan Neil V. article.value: Indigenous and Western musical instruments are both used in the Philippines. Around 10 percent of the Philippine population plays indigenous music during religious rituals and feasts, and in secular activities, while the remaining percent performs using instruments that are mostly Western in origin. Among the indigenous musical instruments used are bamboo instruments such as buzzers, clappers, scrapers, paired-string zithers, slit drums, mouth harps, flutes, reed pipes, and polychordal zithers; bronze instruments like flat gongs and suspended gongs; and two-string lutes called kutyapi (boat lute). On the other hand, Western musical instruments, which the Philippines adopted through more than three hundred years of Spanish occupation (from 1565 to 1898), include string, wind, percussion, and keyboard instruments.
