article.value: Performers who work with musical instruments must be complemented by skilled instrument makers to assure their artistic survival and growth. This article focuses on makers of Western instruments in the Philippines, particularly stringed instrument makers.

The migration of craftsmen, including makers of musical instruments, from Mexico to the Philippines happened during the transpacific galleon trade in the 16th century. These Mexican luthiers spread across the Philippines and became responsible for the arrival of many types of stringed instruments in the islands. Unfortunately, records did not mention specific names of early luthiers who built stringed instruments in the country until the late 19th century.

Pedro Buencamino was the earliest stringed instrument maker and repairer on record. He was born on 1 Aug 1866 in Abukay, Bataan. Buencamino never finished his schooling and became a circus performer at thirteen years old. He toured around the country as part of the circus, from which he learned to play the guitar. After ten years of performing in the circus, Buencamino decided to retire and settled in Manila, then later on began repairing guitars in his house at Isaac Peral Street. It is believed that he acquired his skill from his frequent visits to repair shops in Ongpin Street, Manila. During the revolution in 1896, he and his wife Petra Martin evacuated to San Fernando, Pampanga where they established a music store cum barber shop. After three years, the couple decided to go back to Manila. Later on, Buencamino was awarded a medal in 1904 when he exhibited his stringed instruments at the Philippine Exposition. He established the music store El Sol Mayor in 1916. This store, located in Rizal Avenue, Santa Cruz, Manila, he maintained until his death in 1923.

Aside from guitars, Buencamino also manufactured violins, violoncellos, and basses. Moreover, Buencamino, together with another luthier named Andres, operated another guitar factory in San Miguel District in Manila. To commemorate the existence of the factory in that neighborhood, the district’s bridge was named Puente Guitarrero or Guitarist’s Bridge. Buencamino used local woods for his guitars like narra, laniti, and langka for the backs and sides; palochina or white pine for the top; and kamagong for the fingerboard.

Buencamino’s former workers, namely Fausto Martin and Alejandro de la Rosa, continued the tradition of stringed instrument making in the country. Martin became an expert violin and cello repairman. He was known because of the recommendation of famous musicians during the time such as Ramon Corpus, Bonifacio Abdon, Alejandro Arellano, Ernesto Vallejo, and Antonio Molina, who lauded his ability to improve the appearance as well as the tonality of the instruments.

Meanwhile, de la Rosa opened a violin repair shop in Tondo, Manila. His specialization in enhancing and refining the tonal features of the violin earned him the title “Hari” or “King of Filipino Repairmen.” Alejandro de la Rosa was made famous by foreign violin virtuosi who visited the country, as these violinists like Cecilia Hanson and Piastro were impressed with his work when they asked him to restore their Stradivarius violins. Because of his exceptional ability, these foreigners recommended him to others after going back to their countries. As a result, de la Rosa was highly regarded not only in the Philippines but also in other countries—he even got offers from repair shops in the United States, France, Italy, Germany, and Russia to supervise their manufacturing and repairing of violins, but he decided to stay in the country. Besides violin repairing and manufacturing, de la Rosa was also a famous guitar maker. He started making toy guitars from coconut shells before the age of ten, and before he was twenty, the guitars he made became very popular in the cities and provinces of the country.

Innovation and experimentation were also seen in the early part of the history of Filipino stringed instrument makers. One of those who dared was Casto Maria de Nieva. He was born 1 Jul 1873 in Boac, Marinduque. In 1882, de Nieva went to Manila and studied at the Ateneo de Manila then finished his bachelor of arts degree at the University of Santo Tomas in 1894. He was known for being innovative as he made his own repairing and manufacturing tools. He also experimented on the use of a wood in 1925, as he made a special violin using one wood, the laniti, for the top, back and sides, neck, and scroll. It had been said that to produce a good sound, the violin’s body should not be made of a single kind of wood. But, de Nieva’s experiment proved to be successful, as observed by the former National Library Director Epifanio de los Santos. He also built cellos or violoncellos, based on the paper labels of his instruments which said “Casto Nieva, Constructor de Violines y Violoncellos, Manila, Islas Filipinas.” He died on 21 May 1935, leaving behind violins which were products of his creativity.

Another expert violin repairman was Domingo Pesigan, born in Calamba, Laguna on 24 Jul 1906 and recognized during the early part of the 20th century. He became a worker of well-known violinmaker Alejandro de la Rosa, but later, after honing his skills, he established his own music shop in Manila. He also explored the use of Philippine woods like laniti, pino, and kamagong. Among his customers and patrons who kept his shop busy and thriving were Ramon Tapales, Servilla Castillejos, Pablo Palomo, Manuel Bautista, and Basilio Manalo.

In 1911, a shop named Compositor de Instrumentos de Cuerda was established by Eusebio Cabiluña. Cabiluña was a famous repairman of wind and percussion instruments as well as a maker of guitars, banjos, ukuleles, and rondalla. Cabiluña supplied instruments to Cebu’s rondalla group La Juventud Filipina.

One of the most significant guitar makers in the Philippines during the second half of the 1900s was Michael Romero. A native of Baliangao, Misamis Occidental, Romero used to be a customs officer in Manila during the 1960s. He started to become curious about why imported classical guitars passing through their office were always being declared of high value. He started researching on the materials and process used for making classical guitar. He bought books and tools on making quality classical guitars. In 1969, Romero started building quality guitars in his house in Magallanes Village, Makati City. On 19 Apr 1970, he decided to commercially open a guitar store and shop in Mercedes Street, Pinagkaisahan, Makati City. He named his shop Guitarmasters. He recruited guitar makers from the Visayas to become his workers. The number one luthier in the shop was Flavio Bilbao from the province of Bohol. In addition, Romero also hired guitar luthiers from Cebu province such as Demetrio Aying, Nardo Ompad, and Alex Ompad.

Guitarmasters was considered one of the first to make high quality guitars in Metro Manila. The shop used imported quality woods like spruce and rosewood to be able to build good-sounding guitars. It also experimented in using local woods such as langka for the top and ipil for the back and sides. During the 1970s, the shop also became the favorite hangout place of classical guitarists Jose Valdez, Raul Manikan, and Mario Rodriguez. Aside from making and selling guitars, the shop also offered guitar lessons to aspiring students.

Another achievement of Guitarmasters was that it provided quality instruments to concert guitarists during this time when guitar concertizing in the country was only beginning. The elite classical guitarists helped in promoting Guitarmasters by using its guitars during concerts and recommending them to their students, friends, and guitar aficionados. Romero also made a ten-string guitar exclusively for Jose Valdez in 1973. On 14 Dec of the same year, Valdez held a concert at the Philamlife Auditorium using the Imelda Model, a specially made guitar by Guitarmasters inspired by then-First Lady Imelda Marcos’s efforts to revive music in the country. Guitarmasters flourished from 1970 to 1983. Because of unfortunate events in the family of the owner, Guitarmasters experienced financial instability and closed down in the latter part of the 1980s.

The tradition of stringed instrument making in the country developed with the help and contributions of the luthiers in the latter part of the 20th century. Some of these are guitar makers Dominguez Javier, Mario Rodriguez, Raul Manikan; and bowed instrument makers Amador Tamayo (violin/viola/cello), Angel Gabute (violin/double bass), and Efren Tapao, Dante Gabute, Romeo Gabute, and Bening Abarrientos (double bass). Most of them are still producing quality instruments until today, supplying instruments to concert artists and music students from different schools in Manila and in the provinces, including international classical performers. Aside from these individual makers, big shops with lots of instrument makers are still flourishing in the country today like in Raon, Quiapo, and Santa Mesa in Manila, in Guagua, Pampanga, and in Cebu.

The most significant guitar maker in the 21st century is Cebu native Armando Derecho aka Tabo. He is considered one of the best Filipino classical guitar makers who just officially started to market his guitar recently. In 1982, Derecho enrolled in University of the Philippines College of Music as a guitar major. He is one of the original members of the UP Guitar Ensemble that toured in Australia during the 1980s. Derecho also became a guitarist of the UP Concert Chorus and the UP Filipiniana Dance Troupe in the late 80s to the early 90s. After hearing good quality classical guitars in UP, specifically his professor’s imported guitar, Derecho asked himself why Cebuanos could not make that kind of guitar. Derecho challenged himself and started learning how to build guitars.

Derecho had formal studies on guitar making with Mario Rodriguez, a guitar maker and a teacher at the UST Conservatory of Music. He went to Rodriguez’s house in Cainta almost every day for more than two years to observe and try building guitars under the supervision of his teacher. In the late 1990s, Rodriguez left the country for the United States, and this was the time when Derecho tried making his own guitars. Rodriguez gave him a second hand mold and some guitar making books to start his guitar making hobby. During that time, he was a full-time performer in hotels and restaurants in Metro Manila. Derecho constructed his guitars in his boarding house during his free time before going to his gigs.

Derecho, together with his wife, decided to move to Marikina City in 1999. In April of the same year, he rented a lot behind his backyard and turned it into a guitar shop, which he later transferred beside his house. Nardo Ompad, a former worker in Guitarmasters, met Derecho and applied to be his assistant. To this date, Ompad still works at Derecho’s shop in Marikina. Derecho guitars use high quality imported materials such as spruce, cedar, rosewood, and pine. Since 1999, Derecho has built more than 100 guitars. Derecho guitars became very significant during the early 2000s because they gave classical guitar players access to locally made quality guitars. These guitars are as good as the imported ones but come with a lower tag price. He is presently one of the Filipino guitar makers, if not the only one, in the country who can make classical guitars that can match the quality of imported concert model guitars. Written by Nathan Neil V.
